[Skip to content]

parent nodes: Accessibility

Skip to content

[camelCaseWordsEnabled: false]

Source: http://www.mediacurrent.com/blog/5-simple-things-you-can-do-make-your-site-more-accessible

1. ADD A SKIP TO CONTENT LINK
Try navigating your website with just a keyboard. Load a page and just start pressing the tab key. Follow the outline of the content in focus as you tab through the page. Now imagine that you’re on a page with a list of 50 nested menu items down the left side of page and in order to fill out a form in the main content of the page, you have to tab through every single menu item. That gets old quickly. There’s a simple solution. Add a “skip to content” link as the first piece of content in the body section on the page that links to the page’s main content. This way, when a page is loaded, all a user needs to do is press enter and voila, they’re at the page’s main content.
    Skip to main content

There is debate over whether this link should be visible or not. My preference is a combination of the two - hide the link until it receives keyboard focus. That way sighted keyboard users get a visual when they tab to it. Note that it should be hidden by positioning the content off-screen, not by using display:none or visibility:hidden, which hides the link from screen readers.
#a11y-hidden {
    position:absolute;
    left:-10000px;
    top:auto;
    width:1px;
    height:1px;
    overflow:hidden;
}
Additional information on Skip Navigation links can be found at:
http://webaim.org/techniques/skipnav/
http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwebaim.org%2Ftechniques%2Fcss%2Finvisiblecontent%2F&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AFQjCNEllmkmNjl6uE4_6db_VT5cfEp8Lw

ASP

[camelCaseWordsEnabled: false]

Building and Security a RESTful API for Multiple Clients in ASP.NET Course not finishes (maybe not really applicable)
Implementing an API in ASP.NET Web API
Example - Form with preview once form is posted on same page

ASP.NET Classes Reference: http://www.w3schools.com/aspnet/webpages_ref_classes.asp
ASP.NET Database Object Reference: http://www.w3schools.com/aspnet/webpages_ref_database.asp
ASP.NET WebMail Object: http://www.w3schools.com/aspnet/webpages_ref_webmail.asp
ASP.NET MVC Tutorial: http://www.w3schools.com/aspnet/mvc_intro.asp
Tutorial: Creating a Data Access Layer: https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/aa581776.aspx
ASP.NET Repeater: http://www.w3schools.com/aspnet/aspnet_repeater.asp
Data binding: https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/kb/307860

ASP: Active Server Pages

An ASP.NET page has the extension .aspx. If a browser requests an ASP.NET page, the server processes any executable code in the page, before the result is sent back to the browser.

To demonstrate how ASP can display pages with dynamic content, we have added some executable code (in red) to the previous example:

<html>
    <body bgcolor="yellow">
      <center>
        <h2>Hello W3Schools!</h2>
        <p><%Response.Write(Now())%></p>
      </center>
    </body>
</html>

The code inside the tags is executed on the server.

Response.Write is ASP code for writing something to the HTML output stream.

Now() is a function returning the servers current date and time.

Server Controls

ASP.NET has solved the "spaghetti-code" problem described above with server controls.

Server controls are tags that are understood by the server.

There are three kinds of server controls:
- HTML Server Controls - Traditional HTML tags
- Web Server Controls - New ASP.NET tags
- Validation Server Controls - For input validation

HTML Server Controls

HTML elements in ASP.NET files are, by default, treated as text. To make these elements programmable, add a runat="server" attribute to the HTML element. This attribute indicates that the element should be treated as a server control. The id attribute is added to identify the server control. The id reference can be used to manipulate the server control at run time.

Note: All HTML server controls must be within a
tag with the runat="server" attribute. The runat="server" attribute indicates that the form should be processed on the server. It also indicates that the enclosed controls can be accessed by server scripts.

In the following example we declare an HtmlAnchor server control in an .aspx file. Then we manipulate the HRef attribute of the HtmlAnchor control in an event handler (an event handler is a subroutine that executes code for a given event). The Page_Load event is one of many events that ASP.NET understands:

<script runat="server">
Sub Page_Load
link1.HRef="http://www.w3schools.com"
End Sub
</script>

<html>
<body>

<form runat="server">
<a id="link1" runat="server">Visit W3Schools!</a>
</form>

</body>
</html>

The executable code itself has been moved outside the HTML.

Web Server Controls

Web server controls are special ASP.NET tags understood by the server.

Like HTML server controls, Web server controls are also created on the server and they require a runat="server" attribute to work. However, Web server controls do not necessarily map to any existing HTML elements and they may represent more complex elements.

The syntax for creating a Web server control is:

<asp:control_name id="some_id" runat="server" />

In the following example we declare a Button server control in an .aspx file. Then we create an event handler for the Click event which changes the text on the button:

<script runat="server">
Sub submit(Source As Object, e As EventArgs)
button1.Text="You clicked me!"
End Sub
</script>

<html>
<body>

<form runat="server">
<asp:Button id="button1" Text="Click me!"
runat="server" OnClick="submit"/>
</form>

</body>
</html>

Page_Load Event

The Page_Load event is one of many events that ASP.NET understands. The Page_Load event is triggered when a page loads, and ASP.NET will automatically call the subroutine Page_Load, and execute the code inside it:

<script runat="server">
Sub Page_Load
lbl1.Text="The date and time is " & now()
End Sub
</script>

<html>
<body>
<form runat="server">
<h3><asp:label id="lbl1" runat="server" /></h3>
</form>
</body>
</html>

The Page.IsPostBack Property

The Page_Load subroutine runs EVERY time the page is loaded. If you want to execute the code in the Page_Load subroutine only the FIRST time the page is loaded, you can use the Page.IsPostBack property. If the Page.IsPostBack property is false, the page is loaded for the first time, if it is true, the page is posted back to the server (i.e. from a button click on a form):

<script runat="server">
Sub Page_Load
if Not Page.IsPostBack then
    lbl1.Text="The date and time is " & now()
end if
End Sub

Sub submit(s As Object, e As EventArgs)
lbl2.Text="Hello World!"
End Sub
</script>

<html>
<body>
<form runat="server">
<h3><asp:label id="lbl1" runat="server" /></h3>
<h3><asp:label id="lbl2" runat="server" /></h3>
<asp:button text="Submit" onclick="submit" runat="server" />
</form>
</body>
</html>

The example above will write the "The date and time is...." message only the first time the page is loaded. When a user clicks on the Submit button, the submit subroutine will write "Hello World!" to the second label, but the date and time in the first label will not change.

Note: An .aspx page can only contain ONE control!

Master Pages

Master pages allow you to create a consistent look and behavior for all the pages (or group of pages) in your web application.

A master page provides a template for other pages, with shared layout and functionality. The master page defines placeholders for the content, which can be overridden by content pages. The output result is a combination of the master page and the content page.

The content pages contain the content you want to display.

When users request the content page, ASP.NET merges the pages to produce output that combines the layout of the master page with the content of the content page.

<%@ Master %>

<html>
<body>
<h1>Standard Header From Masterpage</h1>
<asp:ContentPlaceHolder id="CPH1" runat="server">
</asp:ContentPlaceHolder>
</body>
</html>

The master page above is a normal HTML page designed as a template for other pages.

The @ Master directive defines it as a master page.

The master page contains a placeholder tag for individual content.

The id="CPH1" attribute identifies the placeholder, allowing many placeholders in the same master page.

This master page was saved with the name "master1.master".

<%@ Page MasterPageFile="master1.master" %>

<asp:Content ContentPlaceHolderId="CPH1" runat="server">
    <h2>Individual Content</h2>
    <p>Paragraph 1</p>
    <p>Paragraph 2</p>
</asp:Content>
The content page above is one of the individual content pages of the web.

The @ Page directive defines it as a standard content page.

The content page contains a content tag with a reference to the master page (ContentPlaceHolderId="CPH1").

This content page was saved with the name "mypage1.aspx".

When the user requests this page, ASP.NET merges the content page with the master page.

REST: Representational State Transfer










[Example - Form with preview once form is posted on same page]

parent nodes: ASP

Example - Form with preview once form is posted on same page

[camelCaseWordsEnabled: false]

<% @ Page Language="C#" MasterPageFile="~/layouts/wet4/1cole.master" CodeBehind="exitsurvey.aspx.cs"
    CodeFile="exitsurvey.aspx.cs" Inherits="ExitSurvey" AutoEventWireup="False" %>
    <%@ Import Namespace="System.IO" %>
<asp:Content ID="PageTitle" ContentPlaceHolderID="PageTitle" Runat="Server">
    Exit Survey
</asp:Content>

<asp:Content ID="JS" ContentPlaceHolderID="JS" Runat="Server">
    <script type="text/javascript" src="exitsurvey.js"></script>
</asp:Content>

<asp:Content ID="Metadata" ContentPlaceHolderID="Metadata" Runat="Server">
    <meta name="dcterms.title" content="Exit Survey" />
    <meta name="dcterms.creator" content="Government of Canada, Canadian Food Inspection Agency, Human Resources" />
    <meta name="dcterms.subject" title="scheme" content="Forms" />
    <meta name="dcterms.issued" title="W3CDTF" content="2015-05-08" />
    <meta name="dcterms.modified" title="W3CDTF" content="2015-05-08" />
    <meta name="dcterms.valid" title="W3CDTF" content="2017-03-20" />
    <meta name="dcterms.language" title="ISO639-2" content="eng" />
    <meta name="dcterms.contributor" content="Human Resources" />
    <meta name="dcterms.description" content="Exit Survey - Questionnaire for departing employees." />
    <meta name="description" content="Questionnaire for departing employees." />
    <meta name="keywords" content="instructions, submission" />
</asp:Content>

<asp:Content ID="Breadcrumb" ContentPlaceHolderID="Breadcrumb" Runat="Server">
    <!--#include virtual="/nav/breadcrumbs/0e.inc"-->
    <li>Exit Survey</li>
</asp:Content>

<asp:Content ID="Content" ContentPlaceHolderID="Main" Runat="Server">
    <h1 id="wb-cont">Exit Survey</h1>
    <h2 >Questionnaire for departing employees</h2>
    <p>Today's Date: <time id="DateToday"></time></p>


    <% if (System.Web.HttpContext.Current.Request.HttpMethod.ToString() == "POST")
      { %>
        <h4>Background Information</h4>
        <p>Work Organization: <%= Request.Form["workOrg"] %>
        <% if (Request.Form["workOrg"] == "Other")
        {%>
          - <%= Request.Form["OtherWorkOrg"] %>
        <%}%></p>
        <p>Highest level of education: <%= Request.Form["education"] %>
        <% if (Request.Form["education"] == "Other")
        {%>
          - <%= Request.Form["OtherEduc"] %>
        <%}%></p>
        <p>Area: <%= Request.Form["area"] %></p>
        <p>Province/Territory: <%= Request.Form["prov"] %></p>
        <p>Number of years of service</p>
        <p>...at your substantive classification level: <%= Request.Form["yearSub"] %></p>
        <p>...at CFIA: <%= Request.Form["yearCFIA"] %></p>
        <p>...in an acting or assignment position on departure: <%= Request.Form["yearActing"] %></p>
        <p>...at the Federal Public Service: <%= Request.Form["yearPublicService"] %></p>
        <p>Age: <%= Request.Form["age"] %></p>
        <p>First Official Language: <%= Request.Form["lang"] %></p>
        <p>Employment Equity: <%= Request.Form["ee"] %></p>
        <p>Employment Status: <%= Request.Form["status"] %></p>
        <p>Sex: <%= Request.Form["sex"] %></p>
        <p>Classification:</p>
        <p>... Group/Level upon joining CFIA: <%= Request.Form["groupJoining"] %>-<%= Request.Form["levelJoining"] %></p>
        <p>... Group/Level upon leaving CFIA: <%= Request.Form["groupLeaving"] %>-<%= Request.Form["levelLeaving"] %></p>
        <p>Departure Type: <%= Request.Form["depType"] %>
        <% if (Request.Form["depType"] == "Other")
        {%>
          - <%= Request.Form["otherDepartType"] %>
        <%}%></p>
        <p>Reason for Departure: <%= Request.Form["reason"] %>
        <% if (Request.Form["reason"] == "Other")
        {%>
          - <%= Request.Form["OtherReason"] %>
        <%}%></p>
        <p>Destination: <%= Request.Form["dest"] %>
        <% if (Request.Form["dest"] == "Other")
        {%>
          - <%= Request.Form["otherDest"] %>
        <%}%></p>

        <h4>Work Environment Indicators</h4>

        <p>Performance Feedback and Review: <%= Request.Form["envInd2"] %></p>
        <p>Recognition of your work accomplishment: <%= Request.Form["envInd3"] %></p>
        <p>Learning/training and development opportunities: <%= Request.Form["envInd4"] %></p>
        <p>Availability of tools and services to help you manage your career: <%= Request.Form["envInd5"] %></p>
        <p>Working relationship with your immediate supervisor/manager: <%= Request.Form["envInd6"] %></p>
        <p>Accessibility to your immediate supervisor/manager:<%= Request.Form["envInd7"] %></p>
        <p>Working relationship with co-workers: <%= Request.Form["envInd8"] %></p>
        <p>Availability and access to new technology: <%= Request.Form["envInd9"] %></p>
        <p>Morale in the immediate work environment: <%= Request.Form["envInd10"] %></p>
        <p>Respect of official language rights: <%= Request.Form["envInd11"] %></p>
        <p>Provision of a discrimination free workplace: <%= Request.Form["envInd12"] %></p>
        <p>Provision of an harassment free workplace: <%= Request.Form["envInd13"] %></p>
        <p>Physical work environment (location, air, space, etc.): <%= Request.Form["envInd14"] %></p>
        <p>Flexibility to balance family and work responsibilities: <%= Request.Form["envInd15"] %></p>
        <p>Accessibility to flexible work arrangements (part-time, compressed hours, telework, etc.): <%= Request.Form["envInd16"] %></p>

        <p>If there was an opportunity to work for the Canadian Food Inspection Agency again would you choose to do so? <%= Request.Form["work"] %></p>
        <p>Will you be participating in an exit interview in addition to completing this questionnaire? <%= Request.Form["interview"] %></p>

        <div class="well well-sm">
          <section>
            <p>Completed surveys will be sent directly to the <strong>Human Resources Planning and Programs</strong> Section of the Human Resources Policy, Systems and Programs Division:</p>
            <p>159 Cleopatra Drive<br>
            Ottawa ON K1A 0Y9<br>
          </section>
        </div>

        <form action="exitsurveye.aspx" method="get" id="exitsurveysubmit" role="form" enctype="multipart/form-data">
          <input type="submit" class="btn btn-default" name="btnPrint" value="Print" id="btnPrint" />
          <input type="submit" class="btn btn-primary" name="btnSubmit" value="Submit" id="btnSubmit" />
          <input type="submit" class="btn btn-default" name="btnBack" value="Back" id="btnBack" />
        </form>

        <!-- Method

        So I think instead I will hide a div at the bottom that will become visible when you click on Preview.
        I will hide the div as soon as something is changed in the form
        I will have links everywhere to easily go back where it should to update values
        The button back will not exist anymore
        The button submit will be in the div
        The div will be included in the form

        -->

      <%}
      else
      { %>
        <section class="alert alert-info">
          <h3>Information</h3>
          <p>Please complete this questionnaire in relation to your LAST position in the Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA) including an acting or an assignment position.</p>
        </section>
        <noscript>
          <section class="alert alert-danger">
            <h3>Alert</h3>
            <p>Your browser must support Javascript to complete this form</p>
          </section>
        </noscript>

        <div class="wb-frmvld">
          <form action="exitsurveye.aspx" method="post" id="exitsurveyform" role="form" enctype="multipart/form-data">
            <input type="hidden" name="language" value="e" />
            <input type="hidden" name="prevUrl" id="prevUrl" />

            <!--
            *********************
              EXIT SURVEY
            *********************
            -->


            <!--
            **************************
              WORK ORGANIZATION
            **************************
            -->



            <div class="form-group">
              <label for="workOrg" class="required">
                <span class="field-name">Work Organization</span>
                <strong class="required">(required)</strong>
              </label>

              <asp:Repeater ID="WorkOrgList" runat="server">
                <HeaderTemplate>
                  <select class="form-control" name="workOrg" id="workOrg" required="required">
                  <option label="Select a Work Organization"></option>
                </HeaderTemplate>
                <ItemTemplate>
                  <option value="<%# DataBinder.Eval(Container.DataItem, "organization_en")%>">
                    <%# DataBinder.Eval(Container.DataItem, "organization_en")%></option>
                </ItemTemplate>
                <FooterTemplate>
                  </select>
                </FooterTemplate>
              </asp:Repeater>
            </div>
            <div class="form-group">
              <!-- Hidden on Pageload -->
              <div id="ifOtherOrg">
                <label class="label-control required" for="otherWorkOrg">
                  <span class="field-name">Specify work organization</span>
                  <strong class="required">(required)</strong>
                </label>

                <input class="form-control" id="otherWorkOrg" name="otherWorkOrg" type="text" required="required" />
              </div>
            </div>

            <!--
            **********
              AGE
            **********
            -->

            <div class="form-group">
              <label for="age" class="required">
                <span class="field-name">Age</span>
                <strong class="required" aria-required="true">(required)</strong>
              </label>
              <asp:Repeater ID="AgeList" runat="server">
                <HeaderTemplate>
                  <select class="form-control" name="age" id="age" required="required">
                </HeaderTemplate>
                <ItemTemplate>
                  <option value="<%# DataBinder.Eval(Container.DataItem, "age_en")%>">
                    <%# DataBinder.Eval(Container.DataItem, "age_en")%></option>
                </ItemTemplate>
                <FooterTemplate>
                  </select>
                </FooterTemplate>
              </asp:Repeater>
            </div>


            <!--
            ***********************************
              HIGHEST LEVEL OF EDUCATION
            ***********************************
            -->

            <div class="form-group">
              <label for="education" class="required">
                <span class="field-name">Highest Level of Education</span>
                <strong class="required">(required)</strong>
              </label>

              <asp:Repeater ID="EducationList" runat="server">
                <HeaderTemplate>
                  <select class="form-control" id="education" name="education" required="required">
                  <option label="Select a Level of Education"></option>
                </HeaderTemplate>
                <ItemTemplate>
                  <option value="<%# DataBinder.Eval(Container.DataItem, "education_en")%>">
                    <%# DataBinder.Eval(Container.DataItem, "education_en")%></option>
                </ItemTemplate>
                <FooterTemplate>
                  </select>
                </FooterTemplate>
              </asp:Repeater>
            </div>

            <div class="form-group">
              <div id="ifOtherEduc">
                <label class="label-control required" for="otherEduc">
                  <span class="field-name">Specify Highest Level of Education</span>
                  <strong class="required">(required)</strong>
                </label>


                <input class="form-control" id="otherEduc" name="otherEduc" type="text" required="required" />
              </div>
            </div>


            <!--
            *************
              AREA
            *************
            -->

            <fieldset>
            <legend class="required fixLegend"><span class="field-name">Area</span> <strong class="required">(required)</strong></legend>

            <!--<div class="form-group"> -->
              <asp:Repeater ID="AreaList" runat="server">
                <ItemTemplate>
                  <div class="radio">
                    <label for="area<%# DataBinder.Eval(Container.DataItem, "area_id")%>">
                      <input type="radio" name="area" value="<%# DataBinder.Eval(Container.DataItem, "area_en")%>" id="area<%# DataBinder.Eval(Container.DataItem, "area_id")%>" required="required" /><%# DataBinder.Eval(Container.DataItem, "area_en")%>
                    </label>
                  </div>
                </ItemTemplate>
              </asp:Repeater>
            <!--</div> -->

            </fieldset>

            <!--
            *****************
              PROVINCE
            *****************

            The list is manually generated so that it can be easily modified with jQuery based on the Area selected
            -->
            <div class="form-group">
              <label for="prov" class="required">
                <span class="field-name">Province/Territory</span>
                <strong class="required">(required)</strong>
              </label>

              <select class="form-control" id="prov" name="prov" required="required">
                <option label="Please select an Area first"></option>
              </select>
            </div>



            <!--
            ***********************************
              NUMBER OF YEARS OF SERVICE
            ***********************************
            -->

            <legend class="required"><span class="field-name">Number of years of service</span> <strong class="required">(required)</strong></legend>

            <div class="form-group">
              <!-- At your substantive classification level -->
              <label class="label-control required" for="yearSub">
                <span class="field-name">At your substantive classification level</span>
                <strong class="required">(required)</strong>
              </label>

              <asp:Repeater ID="YearListSub" runat="server">
                <HeaderTemplate>
                  <select class="form-control" id="yearSub" name="yearSub" required="required">
                  <option label=""></option>
                </HeaderTemplate>
                <ItemTemplate>
                  <option value="<%# DataBinder.Eval(Container.DataItem, "years_service_en")%>">
                    <%# DataBinder.Eval(Container.DataItem, "years_service_en")%></option>
                </ItemTemplate>
                <FooterTemplate>
                  </select>
                </FooterTemplate>
              </asp:Repeater>
            </div>

            <!-- At CFIA -->
            <div class="form-group">
              <label class="label-control required" for="yearCFIA">
                <span class="field-name">At the Canadian Food Inspection Agency:</span>
                <strong class="required">(required)</strong>
              </label>

              <asp:Repeater ID="YearListCFIA" runat="server">
                <HeaderTemplate>
                  <select class="form-control" id="yearCFIA" name="yearCFIA" required="required">
                  <option label=""></option>
                </HeaderTemplate>
                <ItemTemplate>
                  <option value="<%# DataBinder.Eval(Container.DataItem, "years_service_en")%>">
                    <%# DataBinder.Eval(Container.DataItem, "years_service_en")%></option>
                </ItemTemplate>
                <FooterTemplate>
                  </select>
                </FooterTemplate>
              </asp:Repeater>
            </div>

            <!-- In an acting or assignment position on departure -->
            <div class="form-group">
              <label class="label-control required" for="yearActing">
                <span class="field-name">In an acting or assignment position on departure:</span>
                <strong class="required">(required)</strong>
              </label>

              <asp:Repeater ID="YearListActing" runat="server">
                <HeaderTemplate>
                  <select class="form-control" id="yearActing" name="yearActing" required="required">
                  <option label=""></option>
                </HeaderTemplate>
                <ItemTemplate>
                  <option value="<%# DataBinder.Eval(Container.DataItem, "years_service_en")%>">
                    <%# DataBinder.Eval(Container.DataItem, "years_service_en")%></option>
                </ItemTemplate>
                <FooterTemplate>
                  </select>
                </FooterTemplate>
              </asp:Repeater>
            </div>

            <!-- Federal Public Service -->
            <div class="form-group">
              <label class="label-control required" for="yearPublicService">
                <span class="field-name">At the Federal Public Service:</span>
                <strong class="required">(required)</strong>
              </label>

              <asp:Repeater ID="YearListPublicService" runat="server">
                <HeaderTemplate>
                  <select class="form-control" id="yearPublicService" name="yearPublicService" required="required">
                  <option label=""></option>
                </HeaderTemplate>
                <ItemTemplate>
                  <option value="<%# DataBinder.Eval(Container.DataItem, "years_service_en")%>">
                    <%# DataBinder.Eval(Container.DataItem, "years_service_en")%></option>
                </ItemTemplate>
                <FooterTemplate>
                  </select>
                </FooterTemplate>
              </asp:Repeater>
            </div>

            <!--
            *********************************
              FIRST OFFICIAL LANGUAGE
            *********************************
            -->

            <fieldset>
              <legend class="required"><span class="field-name">First Official Language</span> <strong class="required">(required)</strong></legend>

              <asp:Repeater ID="LangList" runat="server">
                <ItemTemplate>
                  <div class="radio">
                    <label for="lang<%# DataBinder.Eval(Container.DataItem, "lang_id")%>">
                      <input type="radio" name="lang" value="<%# DataBinder.Eval(Container.DataItem, "lang_en")%>" id="lang<%# DataBinder.Eval(Container.DataItem, "lang_id")%>" required="required" /><%# DataBinder.Eval(Container.DataItem, "lang_en")%>
                    </label>
                  </div>
                </ItemTemplate>
              </asp:Repeater>
            </fieldset>



            <!--
            ************
              SEX
            ************
            -->

            <fieldset>
              <legend class="required"><span class="field-name">Sex</span> <strong class="required">(required)</strong></legend>

              <asp:Repeater ID="SexList" runat="server">
                <ItemTemplate>
                  <div class="radio">
                    <label for="sex<%# DataBinder.Eval(Container.DataItem, "sex_id")%>">
                      <input type="radio" name="sex" value="<%# DataBinder.Eval(Container.DataItem, "sex_en")%>" id="sex<%# DataBinder.Eval(Container.DataItem, "sex_id")%>" required="required" /><%# DataBinder.Eval(Container.DataItem, "sex_en")%>
                    </label>
                  </div>
                </ItemTemplate>
              </asp:Repeater>
            </fieldset>

            <!--
            **************************
              EMPLOYMENT EQUITY
            **************************
            -->

            <fieldset>
              <legend><span class="field-name">Employment Equity</span></legend>

              <asp:Repeater ID="EquityList" runat="server">
                <ItemTemplate>
                  <div class="checkbox">
                    <label for="ee<%# DataBinder.Eval(Container.DataItem, "equity_id")%>">
                      <input type="checkbox" name="ee" value="<%# DataBinder.Eval(Container.DataItem, "equity_en")%>" id="ee<%# DataBinder.Eval(Container.DataItem, "equity_id")%>" /><%# DataBinder.Eval(Container.DataItem, "equity_en")%>
                    </label>
                  </div>
                </ItemTemplate>
              </asp:Repeater>
            </fieldset>

            <!--
            **************************
              EMPLOYMENT STATUS
            **************************
            -->

            <fieldset>
              <legend class="required"><span class="field-name">Employment Status</span> <strong class="required">(required)</strong></legend>

              <asp:Repeater ID="StatusList" runat="server">
                <ItemTemplate>
                  <div class="radio">
                    <label for="status<%# DataBinder.Eval(Container.DataItem, "status_id")%>">
                      <input type="radio" name="status" value="<%# DataBinder.Eval(Container.DataItem, "status_en")%>" id="status<%# DataBinder.Eval(Container.DataItem, "status_id")%>" required="required" /><%# DataBinder.Eval(Container.DataItem, "status_en")%>
                    </label>
                  </div>
                </ItemTemplate>
              </asp:Repeater>
            </fieldset>

            <!--
            ***********************
              CLASSIFICATION
            ***********************
            -->

            <!-- Upon Joining CFIA -->
            <legend class="required"><span class="field-name">Classification</span> <strong class="required">(required)</strong></legend>

            <div class="form-group">
              <label class="label-control required" for="groupJoining">
                <span class="field-name">Group upon joining CFIA</span>
                <strong class="required">(required)</strong>
              </label>

              <asp:Repeater ID="GroupJoinList" runat="server">
                <HeaderTemplate>
                  <select class="form-control" id="groupJoining" name="groupJoining" required="required">
                  <option label=""></option>
                </HeaderTemplate>
                <ItemTemplate>
                  <option value="<%# DataBinder.Eval(Container.DataItem, "group_en")%>">
                    <%# DataBinder.Eval(Container.DataItem, "group_en")%></option>
                </ItemTemplate>
                <FooterTemplate>
                  </select>
                </FooterTemplate>
              </asp:Repeater>
            </div>

            <div class="form-group">
              <label class="label-control required" for="levelJoining">
                <span class="field-name">Level upon joining CFIA</span>
                <strong class="required">(required)</strong>
              </label>

              <asp:Repeater ID="LevelJoinList" runat="server">
                <HeaderTemplate>
                  <select class="form-control" id="levelJoining" name="levelJoining" required="required">
                  <option label=""></option>
                </HeaderTemplate>
                <ItemTemplate>
                  <option value="<%# DataBinder.Eval(Container.DataItem, "level_en")%>">
                    <%# DataBinder.Eval(Container.DataItem, "level_en")%></option>
                </ItemTemplate>
                <FooterTemplate>
                  </select>
                </FooterTemplate>
              </asp:Repeater>
            </div>

            <!-- Upon Leaving CFIA -->

                  <option value="<%# DataBinder.Eval(Container.DataItem, "group_en")%>">
                    <%# DataBinder.Eval(Container.DataItem, "group_en")%></option>
                </ItemTemplate>
                <FooterTemplate>
                  </select>
                </FooterTemplate>
              </asp:Repeater>
            </div>

                <span class="field-name">Level upon leaving CFIA</span>
                <strong class="required">(required)</strong>
              </label>

              <asp:Repeater ID="LevelLeaveList" runat="server">

                  <select class="form-control" id="levelLeaving" name="levelLeaving" required="required">
                  <option label=""></option>
                </HeaderTemplate>
                <ItemTemplate>
                  <option value="<%# DataBinder.Eval(Container.DataItem, "level_en")%>">
                    <%# DataBinder.Eval(Container.DataItem, "level_en")%></option>
                </ItemTemplate>
                <FooterTemplate>
                  </select>

            </div>

            <!--

            ***********************
            -->

            <div class="form-group">

                </ItemTemplate>
                <FooterTemplate>

            <div class="form-group">

            <!--

                </label>

                <input class="form-control" id="otherDest" name="otherDest" type="text" required="required" />
              </div>
            </div>


            <!--
            ******************************
              ENVIRONMENT_INDICATORS
            ******************************
            -->
            <legend>Work environment indicators</legend>
            <p>How would you rate your overall experience concerning the following aspects of your last position?</p>

            <div class="form-group">
              <asp:Repeater ID="EnvIndList" runat="server" OnItemDataBound="ItemBound">
                <ItemTemplate>
                  <div class="form-group">
                    <label class="label-control required" for="envInd<%# DataBinder.Eval(Container.DataItem, "env_indicator_id")%>">
                      <span class="field-name"><%# DataBinder.Eval(Container.DataItem, "env_indicator_en")%></span>
                      <strong class="required">(required)</strong>
                    </label>

                    <asp:Repeater ID="ChildRepeater" runat="server">
                      <HeaderTemplate>
                        <select class="form-control" id="envInd<%# DataBinder.Eval(((RepeaterItem)Container.Parent.Parent).DataItem, "env_indicator_id")%>" name="envInd<%# DataBinder.Eval(((RepeaterItem)Container.Parent.Parent).DataItem, "env_indicator_id")%>" required="required">
                        <option label="Select a rating"></option>
                      </HeaderTemplate>
                      <ItemTemplate>
                        <option value="<%# DataBinder.Eval(Container.DataItem, "indicator_code_en")%>">
                          <%# DataBinder.Eval(Container.DataItem, "indicator_code_en")%></option>
                      </ItemTemplate>
                      <FooterTemplate>
                        </select>
                      </FooterTemplate>
                    </asp:Repeater>
                  </div>
                </ItemTemplate>
              </asp:Repeater>
            </div>

            <!--
            **********************************
              YES/NO WORK AGAIN AT CFIA
            **********************************
            -->

            <fieldset>
              <legend class="required"><span class="field-name">If there was an opportunity to work for the Canadian Food Inspection Agency again would you choose to do so?</span> <strong class="required">(required)</strong></legend>

                </label>
              </div>

                  <input type="radio" name="work" value="No" id="work2" >No
                </label>
              </div>
            </fieldset>

            **********************************
              YES/NO EXIT INTERVIEW
            **********************************
            -->

            <fieldset>

                  <input type="radio" name="interview" value="Yes" id="interview1" required="required" />Yes
                </label>
              </div>

              <div class="radio">
                <label for="interview2">
                  <input type="radio" name="interview" value="No" id="interview2" >No
                </label>
              </div>
            </fieldset>

            <div class="form-group">
              <label class="label-control" for="comments">
                <span class="field-name">Comments</span>
              </label>
              <p>The space below is for you to provide any comments regarding your work experience with the Canadian Food Inspection Agency and suggestions that you would like to make in order to improve the quality of the work environment.(maximum 750 characters)</p>

              <textarea class="form-control form-group-lg" id="comments" name="comments" type="text" rows="5" cols="100" > </textarea>
              <div id="charNum">750</div>
            </div>

            <section class="alert alert-info">
              <h3>Information</h3>
              <p>You must preview this form before you are able to submit.</p>
            </section>

            <p>
              <input type="submit" class="btn btn-primary" name="btnPreview" value="Preview" id="btnPreview" />
              <input type="reset" class="btn btn-default" name="btnReset" value="Clear Information" id="btnReset" />
            </p>
          </form>
        </div>
    <% } %>
</asp:Content>











[Implementing an API in ASP.NET Web API]

parent nodes: ASP

Implementing an API in ASP.NET Web API

[camelCaseWordsEnabled: false]

HTTP/RPC: Remote Procedure Call
- URI endpoints
- Verbs included in API
- older model

REST-ful
- URI endpoints
- Resource URI
- HTTP verbs
- Stateless Server
- Content Negotiation

HATEOAS (Hypermedia as the Engine of Application State)
- Resource URI
- HTTP verbs
- Stateless Server
- Content Negotiation
- Link Relations (Ex. Hypermedia)
(the idea is to extend REST to include hypermedia)

File > New Project > C# > Web > Web API

In Global.asax, you will see a function called Application_Start(). This is when your application is sarted up, NOT once per request. There is a number of configurations that happen:

AreaRegistration.RegisterAllAreas();
GlobalConfiguration.Configure(WebApiConfig.Register);
FilterConfig.RegisterGlobalFilters(GlobalFilters.Filters);
RouteConfig.RegisterRoutes(RouteTable.Routes);
BundleConfig.RegisterBundles(BundleTable.Bundles);

We are interested in this line: GlobalConfiguration.Configure(WebApiConfig.Register);

If you click on Register and do F12, you will be brought to the function (which resides in a file located under the App_start folder)

This part configures a default route for the API:

config.Routes.MapHttpRoute(
    name: "DefaultApi",
    routeTemplate: "api/{controller}/{id}", //CL - mapping
    defaults: new { id = RouteParameter.Optional }
This API has creates default controllers located in the Controllers folder (example: ValuesController.cs)

As you can see from this line: public class ValuesController : ApiController, it is an API controller as opposed to a generic controller.

So if you look under api/values/ it will use the mapping above to use ValuesControlle









[Content]

parent nodes: WebDesign

Content

[camelCaseWordsEnabled: false]

Blog title: Should be 5 to 7 words

Today, the new standard sets paragraph text at 16 pixels, heading three at 18, heading two at 24, heading one at 36.











[CSS]

parent nodes: WebDesign

CSS

[camelCaseWordsEnabled: false]

Bootstrap
CSS with SASS and Compass
Foundation
Fonts
Styling links

Neat select: https://select2.github.io/examples.html

Control the way your document looks based on what type of screen you're looking at:
screen.css
print.css
mobile.css

Different browsers have different "default styling" that you can remove by using css reset. http://meyerweb.com/eric/tools/css/reset/

p {font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;
    font-size: 1em;
}

selector: p
declaration: anything between {}
property: font-family:
value: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;

Different types of selectors

- Element selectors: Global selectors based on individual HTML elements (example: p, ul, h1, etc.)

- Class selectors: Attribute selector based on class attributes applied to HTML elements
    HTML: <h2 class="subheading"> Item 2 </h2>
    CSS: .subheading {color: blue;}

- ID selectors: Attribute selector based on ID attributes applied to HTML elements (IDs must be unique)
    HTML: <div id="sidebar">[...]</div>
    CSS: #sidebar {font-size: 80%;}
- Element-specific selectors: Modified class or ID selector which limits application to a specific elements. Require more processing work from browser.
    CSS: h2.subheading {color:blue;} (h2s with a class of subheading)
    CSS: div#sidebar {font-size: 80%;} (divs within an ID of sidebar)
- Descendent selectors: Highly specific selectors that target elements based on their location within other elements
    CSS: div p span {color: blue;} (parent selector first followed by each successive nested selector)
      In this example, it would affect span elements that are inside p which are inside a div. More than 3 layers starts to become inefficient.
- Grouping selectors: Allows you to group selectors together that share formatting
    CSS: h1, h2, .quote {font-weight: normal; color: blue;}
- Universal selector: Affects every single element on the page. Author said he never ever needed to use it.
  • {color:blue;}
- Child selectors: Similar to descendant selectors, however they don't apply to every single descendant elements. Only those that are direct descendants.
    article > h2 {color=#7D6855;}
- Adjacent selector: Let you style an element based on which element comes before it in the document, provided that both are inside the same parent. For example you might want to italicize first paragraph right after a heading.
    h2 + p {font-style: italic;}
- Attribute selector (support is not always good in older browsers)
    HTML:
    <p class="red blue green">Red, blue and green classes are applied</p>
    <p class="red">Red is the only one applied</p>

    CSS:
    a[title] {
      color:red; //targets the "a" elements that have a title attribute applied to it
    }

    a[title="Visit Lynda.com"]{
      color:red; //targets the "a" elements that have a SPECIFC title attribute
    }

    p[class="red"]{
      color:red; //will only target the second "p" in the HTML code above (not the first). Exactly the same as saying p.red
    }

    p[class~="red"]{
      color:red; //Added an extra ~ after class. Now it will target first and second "p" from HTML above
    }

    a[href^="http://"] {
      color:red; //Because of ^, it will target everything that has an href attribute that STARTS WITH "http://"
        //It's a good way of targeting external links
    }

    a[href$="pdf"] {
      color:red; //Because of $, it will target everything that has an href attribute that ENDS WITH "pdf"
        //It's a good way of adding a PDF icon next to links that are PDF files
    }

    a[title*="Visit"]{
      color:red; //Because of $, it will target everything that has a title attribute that CONTAINS "Visit"
    }
Pseudo-class selectors

Helps you target elements outside of the DOM (Document Object Model) such as user hovering over an element or focusing on a form element, or elements that are too specific for simple selectors to target.
    :hover -> pseudo-class selector
    a:hover -> targeted pseudo-class selector
    ul a:hover -> descendant selector with a pseudo-class selector
- Dynamic pseudo-class selectors: Target elements based on something other than attributes, content or element type. Usually refers to something that can change over time, or that is based on user interaction.
    a:link {...} //will target but not
    a:visited{color:black;}
    a:hover{background:orange;}
    a:active{background:green;} //Either in focus or currently being clicked on
    //You must put the above selectors in that order, otherwise some styling will overwrite others.
    a:target{color:red;} //it goes with     . If your URL finishes with .html#section1, then the styling target applies to section1
UI Element state pseudo-class selectors: Target specific user interface elements in regards to whether or not they are currently enabled. (relatively new as of 2011)

- Structural pseudo-class selectors: Target elements based on specialized information within the DOM that simple selectors cannot target. This can be pattern-matching, child-to-parent relationship or other structural information.
    span:first-child{font-weight:bold} //Targets span elements that are the first child of their parent. There is also a last-child option.
    h2:first-of-type{border-bottom: 1px solid #42403E;} //Only the first h2 under a parent. There is also a last-of-type option
    p:only-child{font-style:italic;}

    nth:
    - nth-child
    - nth-of-type
    - nth-last-child
    - nth-last-of-type

    Examples of simple nth-child:
    li:nth-child(odd){color:red;} //change color of odd elements (just like iTunes)
    li:nth-child(2) {color:tan;} //change color of second element only
    li:nth-child(2n) {color:tan;} //targets every second element (synonym to saying nth-child(even)
    li:nth-child(2n+1) {color:tan;} //the offset (+1) changes where you start counting. "start to count at 1, and then target every 2nd element"
    li:nth-child(5n+5) {color:tan;} //start to count at 5, and then target every fifth element
    li:nth-child(-2n+1) {color:tan;} //start to count at 8 and then go backward and target every second element (going UP the list instead of DOWN)
    li:nth-child(5n-1) {color:tan;} //start to count at -1 (which does not exist), so the first colored element is 4.

    Examples of complex nth-child:
    li:nth-child(1n+6):nth-last-child(1n+6){color:tan;}
    li:nth-child(-1n+6), li:nth-last-child(-1n+5){color:tan;}
Using Structural pseudo-class selectors helps you to select specific elements without going through classes. Not all supported evenly by all browsers.

Other pseudo-class selectors: Can't be really grouped into any one category. These selectors give you even more specific targeting capabilities based on things like language or URL targeting.

Pseudo-element selectors

Allow you to target first line or first letter of an element. Also allows you to create what is known as generated content (place content on the page that is not contained in the structure of the document).
    h1 + p::first-line{font-style: italic;} //The double colon is the W3C standard, however it is not recognized by IE8. You CAN use single colon.
    h1 + p::first-letter{font-size: 3em;}
Generated content:
Use a property called "content". Here is what is available to use:
- string
- uri (like a picture for example)
- counter (count count chapters?)
- open-quote and close-quote
- no-open-quote and no-close-quote (no " but content will be offset
- attr(X) (will show value of attribute)

a::after{content: " (outside link)";} //will add a text saying (outside link) after an A tag
a::after{content: attr(href);} //will show the href value of a
a::after{content: " [" attr(href) "]";} //concatenate strings and attr stuff.
    //This is very useful to do in the "print" style sheet, otherwise you would never know where the link goes
Class and ID Naming:
- No whitespace or special character
- Case sensitive

Style locations:
- External styles (main.css)
- Embedded styles (index.htm, in the head of the HTML document)
- Inline style (in HTML file, style can be applied directly to an HTML element)

To write a rule that applies to every single element on the page, use "body"
    body {font-family: Arial;}
External styles
You need to link them in the HTML file in the head section
    <html>
    <head>
      <link href:"main.css" rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" media="screen">
    </head>
    </html>
Media controls where the style is to be applied, on computer or when printing)

Embedded styles
Inefficient to style a whole site but perfect to style a page differently

Inline style
It is discouraged
Only used in HTML e-mails

Cascade
External styles are applied first
Followed by Embedded styles
Followed by Inline styles

If they conflict, the last rule applied wins (inline styles in this case)

Rendering engine for each browser
IE & AOL: Trident
Opera: Presto
Firefox: Gecko
Safari & Chrome: Webkit

Vendor prefix:
Microsoft: -ms-
Mozilla: -moz-
Opera: -o-
Konqueror: -khtml-
Webkit: -webkit-

The following syntax:

p {
    font-family: Arial, Helvetica, Verdana, sans-serif; //if Arial is not find, use Helvetica. If not found, use Verdana etc.
}

Difference between pixels and ems
Pixels are FIXED units, displayed at the requested size regardless of device or context
Ems are RELATIVE units, displayed relative to the environment in which they are found. 1em = 100% of it's default font size

Sizing with ems

Example 1:

body{
    font-size: 100%;
}

which means the base font size will be: 16px

16px = 1.00em = 100% = 12pt = p
18px = 1.125em = 112.5% = 14pt = h3
24px = 1.50em = 150% = 18pt = h2
48px = 2.250em = 300% = 36pt = h1

Example 2:

body {
    font-size: 62.5%;
}

which means the base font size will be: 10px

So it's easier to convert ems into pixels in your mind thanks to the 10 multiplier.

16px = 1.6em
18px = 1.8em
24px = 2.4em
48px = 4.8em
etc.

pxtoem.com

Most important font-related CSS attributes

font-size: size of the text
font-weight: different level of bold-ness
font-style: normal/italic etc.
font-variant: small-caps for example
font-color
background-color
text-transform: upper-case / small-caps etc.
text-align: choose alignment
text-decoration: undecorate / underline / overline / strike-through / blink
text-indent: Indent the first line
letter-spacing
word-spacing
line-height: space between lines

Font Shorthand notation
Allows you to control these properties all at once:
- font-weight
- font-style
- font-variant
- font-size
- line-height
- font-family

Syntax:
font: normal normal normal 100%/1.5 Georgia; //all of the above in order
font: 100% Georgia; //most minimal version (font-size, font-family). Normal will be passed by default

If you want to pass all three values that were normal that we skipped in version 2, you can pass only one of them and that'll work
font: bold 100% Georgia;

Box model http://guistuff.com/css/css_boxmodel.html

Definition: refers to the physical properties of an element's rectangular box. Margins, borders, padding and content width and height.

Properties:
- border-width
- border-style (solid, dashed, dotted or double)
- border-color
- border-radius (rounded corners)
- border-image
And you can control each of the 4 sizes individually (this is true too for padding and margins)

Total element width = left border + left padding + content width + right padding + right border
    Margin values are not calculated as part of an element's total width
For example:

p{
    padding: 20px;
    border: 1px solid black;
    width: 200px;
}

total width = 1px + 20px + 200px + 20px + 1px = 242px

Considerations:
- If a property is not declared, don't assume that the value is 0
- Elements often have default margins that you need to account for
- A 100% width property when combined with padding and borders will create elements that are larger than their parent

padding: 10px 20px 15px 10px; (applied to top, right, bottom, left)
padding: 10px 20px 15px; (applied to top, right & left, bottom)
padding: 10px 20px; (applied to top & bottom, right & left)
padding: 10px; (applied to all sides equally)

Unlike padding, most elements have a default margin that you must account for

Two elements side by side: Both of the element's margins will apply
Two elements on top of each other: Only one margin will apply (higher value wins)

individual properties of borders can be quite specific. Examples:
border-top-style
border-bottom-width
border-right-color

border style "none" and "hidden" are very similar except when tables come into play

Background properties:
- background-color
- background-image
- background-position
- background-origin
- background-repeat
- background-size
- background-clip (crop the image)

You can have both a background color AND a background image. You can even have multiple images for the background.

Backgrounds extend all the way to the inside edge of an element's border.

opacity attribute range from 0 to 1

Pixels
The size of the pixel is relative to the display of the device that it's shown on.

Ems
When used with font-size, 1em is equal to the default font size of the device.
The value of em changes depending upon where it's used within your CSS. If it's used to define fonts, 1em is equal to the value of it's parent element's font size. An em tells an element to calculate its size relative to the size of the parent.

body {font-size: 100%;}
h1 {font-size: 1.6em;}
h2 {font-size: 1.4em;}
h3 {font-size: 1.2em;}
P {font-size: 1em;}

The starting size of the text is up to the device

If an em value is set outside of a font-size, it's equal to the computed size of the text of that element

h1{
    font-size: 2em;
    margin-bottom: 1em;
}

device font size: 16px

SO
- font-size will be 32px
- margin-bottom will ALSO be 32 because it is based on the text value of that element. If margin-bottom was 2em, it would be 64px

EX and REM
Based on the "x-height" of a font
Root ems (rem) are like ems but they are relative to the root unit (body, html), not the element's immediate parent
rems not fully supported yet (as of 2011)

Percentages
They are great to build fluid layouts

You can also use centimetres and inches as a measure, this is mostly done for the printing look.

Positioning elements

3 position schemes:
- Normal flow (static): that's what happens when you do nothing at all
- Element floating
- Absolute positioning

position value:
- static (this is the normal flow)
- relative (still considered part of normal flow but you can offset the element from it's original position relative to another element)
- absolute (not normal flow. Elements are placed relative to the nearest positioned ancester)
- fixed (considered "absolutely" positioned but they are always positioned relative to the active viewport. Meaning if you scroll down, the element stays exactly where it is)
- inherit

As soon as you declare a position that is NOT static, you escape from the normal flow and open up the ability to call on four new properties: top, right, bottom and left

Example relative:
.box1 {
    position: relative;
    left: 100px;
    top: 50px;
}

The box will move 100px to the right and down 50px. It will create a hole where the element would normally be (instead of the other elements to take it's place)

Example absolute:
.box1 {
    position: absolute;
    left: 100px;
    top: 50px;
}

The box will move 100px to the right and down 50px. The other elements under will replace the empty spot and move up.

.content {
    position:relative; //this is done so that the content is now positioned and .quote will be placed based on the top and left of the content. Otherwise, it would use the body of the page as a base.
}

. quote{
    position: absolute;
    left: 20px;
    top: 40px;
}

Example fixed:
.ad {
    position: fixed;
    top: 50px;
    right: 100px;
}

Elements can stack one on top of each other. Can be controlled by the z-index property, which allows you to control which elements are on top of others. By default, positioned elements will appear on top of non-positioned elements if those two overlap.

The default value for z-index is 0. If you want something to go behind your main working layer, give it a negative value. If you want it in front, give it a number greater than 0.

Floats

One of the most popular CSS technique

Definition: Basically an element that's been shifted to the right or to the left of its current position.

.box1 {float: right;}

box1 will move as far to the right as possible. The elements below will move up to occupy the space where box1 was (so floating an element removes it from normal document flow). Different elements react differently to floated elements. "Inline" elements will react to floated elements by wrapping around them if they have enough room.

.content {float:right;}
.sidebar {float: left;}

If you leave just these two, the footer will move up. But if you add this:

.footer{clear: both;}

...then this means that the floating has been cleared. It tells the browser to stop floating elements and go back to normal flow.

Additional learning to develop:
- Learn how floated elements affect their parents
- Learn how clearing works
- Learn how margins work between floated elements and static elements
- Learn how the width of parent elements affect the floating ability of nested elements
- Look into best practices that have evolved around floats
- Learn how browser rendering differences affect layout
- Research multiple layout techniques

Interesting Layout concept: Header (and probably others as well), if you don't define a height it will be determined by its content.

Media type
List of media types:
- all
- braille
- embossed
- handheld (mobile devices)
- print
- projection
- screen
- speech
- tty
- tv

Many phones use screen media type rather than handheld

List of media features:
- width
- height
- device-width
- device-height
- orientation
- aspect-ratio
- device-aspect-ratio
- color
- color-index
- monochrome
- resolution
- scan
- grid

media query syntax:
link rel="stylesheet" href="desktop.css"
media="only screen and (min-width:0px) and (max-width:480px)"

CSS Reset http://www.cssreset.com
Definition: A set of styles that nullify a browser's default style sheet, allowing designers to avoid conflicts between their styles and browser default styles

Common reset properties:
- margins
- padding
- borders
- font-size
- line-height

CSS-reset must be at the top of the CSS style sheet

//css-reset
body{
    margin: 0;
    padding: 0;
}

Pros and cons:
- Often setting the same property twice
- Large resets can cause the browser to do intensive parsing & styling
- Gives designers a consistent baseline for building styles

CSS Frameworks
Pre-prepared CSS files that provide a templating system for site layout and design

Common content:
- CSS reset
- Basic element styling
- Basic structural styling
- Browser inconsistencies
- Form and table styling
- Typography
- CSS grid

Pros:
- Save considerable time when designing sites
- Most of them assist with creating cross-browser compliant code
- Built-in CSS grids speed up layout development
- Consistent code base for teams
- Well written frameworks are a good way to learn certain techniques

Cons:
- Most sites do not use all the features contained within framworks (lots of codes that you don't use)
- Some frameworks are structured with multiple CSS files
- Tends to rely heavily on classes
- Class structure is usually not user-friendly
- Can be difficult to update or debug
- Adding functionality can be time-consuming
- Be prepared to spend time mastering the Framework

Might not be good for beginners

Popular Frameworks:
- Blueprint (blueprintcss.org)
- 52 framework (52framework.com)
- 960 grid system (960.gs)
- YUI 2 (developer.yahoo.com/yui/grids)
- CSS-boilerplate (code.google.com/p/css-boilerplate
- Baseline (baselinecss.com)

Online Tools
- http://www.css3generator.com
- http://www.css3.me
- http://www.css3please.com
- http://www.layerstyles.org/builder.html
- http://www.css3.mikeplate.com
- http://www.css3maker.com
- http://www.colorzilla.com/gradient-editor
- http://www.westciv.com/tools
- http://www.validator.w3.org
- http://www.csslint.net
- http://www.alvit.de/handbook
- http://www.reference.sitepoint.com/css
- http://www.css-tricks.com


Author's blog: http://www.simpleprimate.com

Using this way, you can style dates a certain way:

<ul>
<li> Tobias will be there on <span class="date">August 23 </span></li>
<li> <span class="date">August 24</span> is Pride Parade</li>
</ul>

A lot of people use IDs in HTML because javascript allows us to target IDs on the page

Conflicts

p{
    font-size: 1em;
    color: white;
    background: tan;
}
p{
    font-size: 1.2em;
    color: black;
    padding: 10px;
}

In this case, the rules applied will be the following:
- font-size: 1.2em; //From the 2nd p
- color: black; //From the 2nd p
- padding: 10px; //From the 2nd p
- background: tan; //From the 1st p

Cascade
The last rule applied WINS

If you have a style in an external CSS file that conflict with a style in the <style> tag in the HTML file, the HTML file wins, unless the link to the external file comes AFTER the style tag.

Inheritance
If you apply a property to a parent element, all the elements inside of it will have that property applied to it as well

Specificity
Usually the culprit when styling errors.

#mainContent p{color:red;}
p{color:blue;}

You would think that because the "blue" p comes last, it wins. But NO! The one with main content has a higher specificity so it wins!

IDs are worth 100
Classes are worth 10
Elemens and selectors are worth 1

If you are trying to apply a style and it does not work, it could be because there is another selector somewhere with a higher degree of specificity. This is one reason why some people avoid using ID selectors.

Low specificity rules are easier to parse and easier to overwrite later on

!important
In the event of a conflict, the !important declaration wins

p{color:red !important;} //this one wins
#mainContent p {color:green;} //even though this one is more specific

Recommended not to use it much, only in last resort.
Author: I have NEVER used it

Advices
- Avoid using local styles whenever possible
- Do not use inline styles except for very specific circumstances
- Don't mix class and ID selectors without having a plan that guides when they are to be used
- Sections of ID selectors can be hard to overwrite later if not accounted for
- If you find yourself writing descendant selectors with three of more selectors, consider revising your strategy
- If you are familiar with your page structure, you should be able to identify global formatting across your site
- Those formatting needs can be written as global styles on parent elements, and inherited by the rest of the site
- This results in fewer rules to write and easier styles to maintain
- Think about how styles relate to one another
- New designers often make the mistake of styling each element individually, as it is encountered
- This can lead to bloated style sheets and hard to maintain styles
- Thinking of styles as related formatting allows you to plan and write organized style sheets

Generic Font Families
- serif
- sans-serif
- monospace
- cursive
- fantasy

When using @font-face, if you have several declarations for normal, italic, bold and bold-italic, you want to put them in the order I just put them in.

access to bootstrap? (to be placed in head section)
    <link rel="stylesheet" href="http://s3.amazonaws.com/codecademy-content/courses/ltp/css/bootstrap.css">
Block Elements vs. Inline Elements

Block:
- Paragraphs (p)
- Headers (h1, h2...)
- Lists (ul, ol, li)
- Divs (div)

Inline:
- Hyperlink (a)
- Images (img)
- Form fields (input)
- Spans (span)

If you use text-align: right on an inline element, it won't work. Instead, you can use float.

Gradients

Radial gradients radiate outward in all directions from a central point
Lineau gradients only go in one direction in a line

IE does not support gradients, but if you put background-color FIRST, IE will be safe! You also need vendor prefixes for now.

p {
    background-color: black;
    background: linear-gradient(bottom, rgba(0,0,0,1), rgba(0,0,0, .4));
    background: -webkit-linear-gradient(bottom, rgba(0,0,0,1), rgba(0,0,0, .4));
    background: -moz-linear-gradient(bottom, rgba(0,0,0,1), rgba(0,0,0, .4));
}

div{
    background: radial-gradient(shape, centercolor, outercolor);
}

Shape: circle or ellips

Border-radius

To create a perfectly circular curve, make the radius at least HALF the lenght of the shape's edge.

.circle{
    height: 40px;
    width: 40px;
    border-radius: 20px;
}

Animation

There are two parts to CSS animation:
1. You define it
2. You assign it

@keyframes blink{
    50% {
      background: radial-gradient(circle, red 15%, transparent 40%), #cc5;
    }
}

@-webkit-keyframes blink{
    50% {
      background: -webkit-radial-gradient(circle, red 15%, transparent 40%), #cc5;
    }
}

@-moz-keyframes blink{
    50% {
      background: -moz-radial-gradient(circle, red 15%, transparent 40%), #cc5;
    }
}

.brain{
    animation: blink .5s infinite;
    -webkit-animation: blink .5s infinite;
    -moz-animation: blink .5s infinite;
    background: radial-gradient(circle, white 15%, transparent 40%), #cc5;
}

Other notes

It's a good idea to include normalize.css in all your projects (maybe you don't need to when it's Bootstrap?)

If you use max-width: 500px instead of width: 500px, your website becomes responsive...

To use absolute and relative...

let's say you have 3 divs, each with a paragraph in it.

div{
    position: relative;
}

p{
    position: absolute;
    bottom: 0;
}

This will put the paragraph at the bottom of the divs.









[Bootstrap]

parent nodes: CSS

Bootstrap

[camelCaseWordsEnabled: false]

Step 1: Create a new folder somewhere for your new project

Step 2: Follow instructions below to download Bootstrap

Download Bootstrap from github

1. Go to http://getbootstrap.com/ and click on github at the bottom of the screen (which should bring you here: https://github.com/twbs/bootstrap)
2. Click on the download ZIP button. Downloading the github version should ensure you have the latest bootstrap version, also you will have more content
3. Unzip bootstrap
4. In your project folder, create two folders, one called "_" and one called "images"
5. Inside _ create a folder called components
6. Copy the fonts folder to _ folder
7. Copy the js and less folders to the components folder
8. Open the js folder and get rid of the test folder
9. Inside _ folder, create two folders: css and js. In these folders, we will be put the compressed versions of the LESS and js documents
10. Download jquery (bootstrap needs jquery to work)at http://jquery.com/ You can download uncompressed since we will be compressing all javascript files later
11. Rename the jquery file into jquery.js

Compressing files

1. Create another file in the folder _/components/less called _mystyles.less
2. Create another file in the folder _/components/js called _myscript.js
3. Go to grunt.txt in the documentation and follow the steps to get grunt going

The following steps are to be done in cmd:

4. Type grunt less:lessbootstrap (this will compress the bootstrap files)
5. Type grunt cssmin (this will minify the bootstrap css)
6. Type grunt concat (this will concatenate all javascript files)
7. Type grunt uglify:uglifybootstrap (this will make the bootstrap.js file all on one line)
8. Type grunt (now your grunt is in wait mode and will make necessary changes as soon as _myscript.js or _mystyles.less are updated

Now you can go to bootstrap's website (http://www.getboostrap.com) and under getting started, you can grab the starting HTML code. You will have to update the link to the bootstrap location properly though.

Building the structure of the page

It's a good idea to give an ID to each page so that they are easy to target in CSS
<body id="home">

<section class="container">
    <div class="content row">
      <section class="main col col-lg-8">
    </section> <!-- main-->

    <section class="sidebar col col-lg-4">
    </section><!-- sidebar-->
    </div> <!-- content-->
</section> <!-- container -->

Row is the technical term that you use in Bootstrap to define each row of your document. Content is a class that I'm defining to identify the main section of the code that's going to allow us to center this main layout on the page.

The two sections (col-lg-8 and col-lg-4) they have to add up to 12

I like to alternate between divs and sections to make things easier to read

Now that we have the structure in place, we can copy paste index.php to create all our other documents (about.php etc. etc.)

The reason why we named all our files with the php extension is so that we can call the header and footer from another document every time (yay!)
<?php include "_/components/php/header.php"; ?>

Now I can create a navbar like this:
<nav class="navbar navbar-default">
    <div class="container-fluid">
      <div class="navbar-header">
        <div class="navbar-header">
          <button type="button" class="navbar-toggle collapsed" data-toggle="collapse" data-target="#bs-example-navbar-collapse-1">
          <span class="sr-only">Toggle navigation</span>
          <span class="icon-bar"></span>
          <span class="icon-bar"></span>
          <span class="icon-bar"></span>
          </button>
        </div>
        <div class="collapse navbar-collapse" id="bs-example-navbar-collapse-1">
          <ul class="nav navbar-nav">
            <li><a href="index.php">Home</a></li>
            <li><a href="venuetravel.php">Venue/Travel</a></li>
            <li><a href="schedule.php">Schedule</a></li>
            <li><a href="Register.php">Register</a></li>
          </ul>
        </div>
      </div>
    </div>
</nav>

Other options:
- If you add a class of navbar-fixed-top to the top div, it will remain at the top all the time.
- If you add a class of active to one of the li element, it will mark it as active
- If you add a class of navbar-inverse to the top div, the navbar will become black
- the div at the top can be a div or section, it doesn't matter

To make an element a drop down:
<li class="dropdown">
    <a href="#" class="dropdown-toggle" data-toggle="dropdown" role="button" aria-expanded="false">Artists <span class="caret"></span></a>
    <ul class="dropdown-menu" role="menu" aria-labelledby="dropdownMenu">
      <li><a tableindex="-1" href="artists.php">All artists</a></li>
    </ul>
</li>

To add a divider:
<li class="divider"></li>

To make the dropdown drop down automatically, add the following code to _myscript.js:
$(function(){
    //Make menu drop down on hover

    $('ul.nav li.dropdown').hover(function(){
      $('.dropdown-menu', this).fadeIn();
    }, function(){
      $('.dropdown-menu', this).fadeOut('fast');
    }); //hover
}); //on jQuery loads

Highlight the current nav:
$("#home a:contains('Home')").parent().addClass('active'); //double quotation mark because there is a single quote around the word Home
$("#schedule a:contains('Schedule')").parent().addClass('active');
$("#artists a:contains('Artists')").parent().addClass('active');
$("#venuetravel a:contains('Venue/Travel')").parent().addClass('active');
$("#register a:contains('Register')").parent().addClass('active');

And then we add the footer, also called by php

Now we create a carousel! Add a new php document called snippet-carousel.php
<div id="myCarousel" class="carousel slide" data-ride="carousel">
    <!--Indicators -->
    <ol class="carousel-indicators">
      <li data-target="#myCarousel" data-slide-to="0" class="active"></li>
      <li data-target="#myCarousel" data-slide-to="1"></li>
      <li data-target="#myCarousel" data-slide-to="2"></li>
      <li data-target="#myCarousel" data-slide-to="3"></li>
      <li data-target="#myCarousel" data-slide-to="4"></li>
    </ol>

    <!-- Wrapper for slides -->
    <section class="carousel-inner">
      <div class="item active">
        <img src="images/carousel/seattle_skyline.jpg" alt="Photo of Seattle Skyline">
      </div>
      <div class="item">
        <img src="images/carousel/jewelry_workshop.jpg" alt="Photo of Jewelry Workshop">
      </div>
      <div class="item">
        <img src="images/carousel/painting_workshop.jpg" alt="Photo of Painting Workshop">
      </div>
      <div class="item">
        <img src="images/carousel/pottery_workshop.jpg" alt="Photo of Pottery Workshop">
      </div>
      <div class="item">
        <img src="images/carousel/quicksketch_workshop.jpg" alt="Photo of Quicksketch Workshop">
      </div>
    </section>
    <!-- Controls -->
    <a class="left carousel-control" href="#myCarousel" role="button" data-slide="prev">
      <span class="glyphicon glyphicon-chevron-left"></span>
    </a>
    <a class="right carousel-control" href="#myCarousel" role="button" data-slide="next">
      <span class="glyphicon glyphicon-chevron-right"></span>
    </a>
</div>

Bootstrap allows you to make certain things visible only when the site is visited by certain device sizes: http://getbootstrap.com/css/#responsive-utilities

Example, this paragraph will not appear on a phone: <p class="hidden-xs">

Buttons: http://getbootstrap.com/css/#buttons
Example:
<a href="artists.php" class="btn btn-primary">About the artists</a>

Tooltips: http://getbootstrap.com/javascript/#tooltips
Example:
<a href="artists.php#Barot_Bellingham"><img data-toggle="tooltip" data-original-title="Barot Bellingham" src="images/artists/Barot_Bellingham_tn.jpg" alt="Photo of Barot Bellingham"></a>

Must add this line to _myscript.js: $('[data-toggle: tooltip]').tooltip({animation: true})

Media indent (image next to the text): http://getbootstrap.com/components/#media
media-left must be placed BEFORE media-body, media-right must be placed AFTER media-body

Example:
<article class="aboutthevenue media">
    <h2>About the venue</h2>
    <div class="media-body">
      <p>Paragraph 1</p>
      <p>Paragraph 2</p>
    </div>
    <a class="media-right" href="venuetravel.php">
      <img src="images/hotels/contempo.jpg" alt="Photo of Hotel Contempo">
    </a>
</article>

Modals: http://getbootstrap.com/javascript/#modals

See the code in _myscript.js and in aside-lastyear

Accordion (also called Collapse): http://getbootstrap.com/javascript/#collapse

Please see aside-accordion.php

Ok so now we're building the other pages

Tabs: http://getbootstrap.com/javascript/#tabs

Have a look at the article-schedule page. Also we needed to add something in _myscript.js so that when you're in the home page and you click on a day, it brings you to the proper tab

Scrollspy: http://getbootstrap.com/javascript/#scrollspy and http://getbootstrap.com/javascript/#affix
Make sure you style the "active" element eh? (see article-artistlist.php and artists.php)

Forms: http://getbootstrap.com/css/#forms

LESS

http://lesscss.org/

You can update the variables.less file to personalize the colours and the look of your website.

Now we are going to play with _mystyles.less

Maybe we could add:
.navbar {
border-radius: 0px;
}









[CSS with SASS and Compass]

parent nodes: CSS

CSS with SASS and Compass

[camelCaseWordsEnabled: false]

SASS: Syntactically Awesome Style Sheets
- Functionality not available in CSS
- CSS-like syntax
- Compile to CSS

http://sass-lang.com/

Variables

$main_color: #023E54

.navbar{
    background: $main_color;
}

h1,h2,h3{
    background: $main_color;
}

Nesting

.pixgrid{
    ul{
      /*style goes here*/
      li{
        /*more style here*/
      }
      img{
        /*and style here too*/
      }
    }
}

Kind of similar to media queries

Operators

$border_thickness : 1px;
$thicker : $border_thickness * 5;

.sidebar{
    border: $thicker solid black;
}

Controls

$border_thickness : 1px;
$thicker : $border_thickness * 5;

.sidebar{
    @if ($border_thickness <= 1){
      background-color: red;
    } @else {
      background-color: yellow;
    }
}

Mixins (functions)

@mixin rounded($radius 10px){
    -webkit-border-radius: $radius;
    border-radius: $radius;
    background-clip: padding-box;
}

ul{
    padding: 0;
    margin: 0;
    list-system: none;
      li img{
        display: block;
        @include rounded(20px);
      }
}

Compass

Compass is nothing more then a group of preset mixins that run on top of Sass.

Sass and Compass take care of a lot of the pain of writing complex, backwards-compatible markup, and gives you a variety of tools that will streamline your workflow.

Gruntjs

GruntJS is a JavaScript task runner. Think of it as a tool for creating workflow macros. It doesn't support a specific workflow, but supports an infinite number of work flow tasks by using plugins to handle certain things.

Folder structure:

sassycompass
    _
      components
        js (this will hold uncompressed version)
        sass (this will hold uncompressed and uncompiled version)
      css (compressed and compiled)
      js (compressed)
Version control

1. Using command line, go to the folder where your project is (sassycompass in my case)
2. Type git init (this will create a hidden git folder)
3. Type git add . (this will add all the files into the staging area)
4. Type git commit -m "first commit" (this will do the first commit with a comment)
5. Type "git status" to check the status at any time
6. dir /a shows all files and folders including hidden ones
7. If there are some files you don't want to include, create a gitignore file: https://help.github.com/articles/ignoring-files/
    An example of such a file is here: https://gist.github.com/octocat/9257657
    I added the following line at the bottom *.sass-cache*
Node.js

When you install Node, you'll also get a really cool utility called NPM. Which stands for Node Package Manager. NPM is going to let you install plugins for Node into your system with a single command. Now later on, we're going to use that to install Grunt. NPM is also a way to extend the functionality of Node.js and your projects.

Now with NPM, you can also use something called a package.json file. That file is going to allow you to specify dependencies that your project needs in order to run. So, say for example that you're going to use Sass in your project. Well, you could go to the Sass website, download the installer, go through the installation, find the appropriate files, install a pre-processor and then get to work once you set up some settings in your pre-processor. Now multiply that times all of the different packages you're going to be using for your project. And what if your working with a team? You would have to write some instructions for all the members of your team to let them know which versions of the packages you're using.

What pre-processors and what the settings are for those pre-processors, now that is obviously a nightmare. By having a package.json file you can have a single file that lists all the packages and the versions you're going to be using in your project.

Example of the content of package.json:

{
    "name" : "rouxmeetups",
