    "version" : "0.0.1",
    "dependencies" : {
      "grunt" : "~0.4.1",
      "grunt-contrib-watch" : "~0.5.3",
      "grunt-contrib-compass" : "~0.5.0",
      "grunt-contrib-uglify" : "~0.2.2",
      "matchdep" : "~0.1.2"
    }
}

In command line, go to your project folder (sassycompass for me) and type npm install to run package.json and install your projet's dependencies

More information about package.json: https://docs.npmjs.com/files/package.json

Grunt

1. Install Grunt (in cmd, type "npm install -g grunt-cli"
2. Create gruntfile.js in your main folder
3. Example content of gruntfile.js:

module.exports = function(grunt){
    grunt.loadNpmTasks('grunt-contrib-uglify');

    grunt.initConfig({
      uglify: {
        my_target: {
          files: {
            '_/js/script.js': ['_/components/js/*.js']
          }//files
        } //my_target
      } //uglify
    })//initConfig
} //exports

This basically runs all js scripts in _/components/js and will combine them and minify them in _/js/script.js

To call this script, just go to cmd in the proper folder and type grunt uglify

grunt-contrib-watch

This module allows you to monitor files and do something when the files are modified.

We can add another task to our gruntfile:

module.exports = function(grunt){
    grunt.loadNpmTasks('grunt-contrib-uglify');
    grunt.loadNpmTasks('grunt-contrib-watch');

    grunt.initConfig({
      uglify: {
        my_target: {
          files: {
            '_/js/script.js': ['_/components/js/*.js']
          }//files
        } //my_target
      }, //uglify

      watch: {
        files: ['_/components/js/*.js'],
        tasks: ['uglify']
      } //watch
    })//initConfig
} //exports

To execute, cmd + grunt watch. Now the task will be in a "waiting" state and will execute the uglify command as soon as you change one of the js files. Terminate with CTRL + C

Add this line to gruntfile and when you run grunt, you will have a default task running:
grunt.registerTask('default','watch');

And now you just need to run "grunt"

Livereload

Reloads your Chrome every time you make a change:

module.exports = function(grunt){
    grunt.loadNpmTasks('grunt-contrib-uglify');
    grunt.loadNpmTasks('grunt-contrib-watch');

    grunt.initConfig({
      uglify: {
        my_target: {
          files: {
            '_/js/script.js': ['_/components/js/*.js']
          }//files
        } //my_target
      }, //uglify

      watch: {
        options: { livereload: true },
        scripts: {
          files: ['_/components/js/*.js'],
          tasks: ['uglify']
        }, //scripts
        html: {
          files: ['*.html']
        }
      } //watch
    })//initConfig
    grunt.registerTask('default','watch');
} //exports

In order for this to work, you also need this line in your HTML:
<script src="http://localhost:35729/livereload.js"></script>

Auto compiling SASS files

For SASS to work, you need to have Ruby. Install Ruby from http://rubyinstaller.org

1. In cmd, type gem update --system
2. In cmd still, type gem install compass
3. Create a new file in sassycompass called config.rb

Content:

css_dir = '_/css'
sass_dir = '_/components/sass'
javascripts_dir = '_/js'
output_style = :nested (another option would be compressed)

Any question about this: http://compass-style.org/help/documentation/configuration-reference/

4. Update the grunt file to now include compass stuff
(compass doc: http://compass-style.org/)

module.exports = function(grunt){
    grunt.loadNpmTasks('grunt-contrib-uglify');
    grunt.loadNpmTasks('grunt-contrib-watch');
    grunt.loadNpmTasks('grunt-contrib-compass');

    grunt.initConfig({
      uglify: {
        my_target: {
          files: {
            '_/js/script.js': ['_/components/js/*.js']
          }//files
        } //my_target
      }, //uglify
      compass: {
        dev: {
          options: {
            config: 'config.rb'
          } //options
        } //dev
      }, //compass
      watch: {
        options: { livereload: true },
        scripts: {
          files: ['_/components/js/*.js'],
          tasks: ['uglify']
        }, //scripts
        sass: {
          files: ['_/components/sass/*.scss'],
          tasks: ['compass:dev']
        }, //sass
        html: {
          files: ['*.html']
        }
      } //watch
    })//initConfig
    grunt.registerTask('default','watch');
} //exports

Note: you have to have ruby and compass installed in your system path

5. From terminal: gem install susy
Susy doc: http://susy.oddbird.net/

6. Change config.rb to this:

require "susy"
css_dir = '_/css'
sass_dir = '_/components/sass'
javascripts_dir = '_/js'
output_style = :compressed

Coding in HTML

1. If not done already, under sassycompass, create a folder called images. Be mindful of naming
2. Add a "header" to the body of your HTML page
3. Create the nav
4. Create the footer
5. Add this line to the head of index.html:
<meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, user-scalable=no, initial_scale=1.0, maximum_scale=1.0 minimum_scale=1.0">
6. Add article(s) to your index.html
7. Create primary content and aside
8. Sometimes it's good to give IDs to all your articles to be able to target a specific one

SASS

1. In _/components/sass create files called "_base.scss", "_layout.scss", "_mixins.scss", "_modules.scss", "_variables.scss"


2. Add imports to style.scss

@import "compass";
@import "susy"; //or susyone?

@import "variables";
@import "mixins";
@import "base";
@import "layout";
@import "modules";

The order is important

Color Palette

http://ethanschoonover.com/solarized

Put a list of colours into your _variables.scss

For sass doc on colours and functions related to them such as lighten or darken or rgba: http://sass-lang.com/documentation/Sass/Script/Functions.html

CSS Reset

So when you use the following command "@import compass;" to work with compass (which we have, proof is in styles.scss), this website will show you what you are actually importing (and what you are NOT): http://compass-style.org/reference/compass/

Add @import "compass/reset"; right under import compass command in styles.scss

Fonts

1. From Google Fonts, add the fonts you're interested in to your collection, then do quick use and then copy JUST the url, such as:
http://fonts.googleapis.com/css?family=Bree+Serif|Merriweather

2. In _base.scss, type this:
@import url('http://fonts.googleapis.com/css?family=Bree+Serif|Merriweather');

3. Go to _variables.scss and type this:
$font-primary: Merriweather, serif;
$font-secondary: Bree Serif, serif;

4. In _base.scss, add another import:
@import url('http://maxcdn.bootstrapcdn.com/font-awesome/4.2.0/css/font-awesome.min.css');

5. Now you can add this code to your html:
<i class="fa fa-home">

Styling

1. Now we're adding some styling in _base.scss

For information about Compass selector helpers: http://compass-style.org/reference/compass/helpers/selectors/

For example:

#{headings()}{
    font-family: $font-secondary
    font-weight: normal;
    color: $darkgrey;
}

You can add clearfix easily in Compass, just like that:

#nextmeeting {
    @include clearfix;

    img{
      width: 30%;
      max-width: 130px;
      float: left;
      margin-right: 3%;
    }
}

And no need to add anything in your HTML, voilà!

For border-radius, you normally have to add all sorts of browser support. With compass, just do this:
@include border-radius(5px);

You can often set up default values. For example, you can add this line to _variables.scss

$default_border_radius : 10px;

Layout

The work is done in _layout.scss file

Note: In your CSS, when you use percentage to specify the width, you should also have a maximum-width attribute

Susy

Susy is a framework for creating responsive grids in Compass. Susy provides an additional set of mixins that let's you easily control your layout from within SASS files. One thing I love about Susy, is that it helps you create layouts without having to add additional markup into your HTML files. This is one of the problems with a framework like Bootstrap. When you code layouts, you end up with all kinds of unnecessary classes in your HTML.

You can also establish global settings, to configure Susy for your specific needs. Create a $susy variable, and add your settings as a map.

//Susy settings---------------------------

$susy: (
    columns: 12, // The number of columns in your grid
    column-width: 4em,
    gutters: 1em,
    gutter-position: inside
);

@include border-box-sizing;

$small: 30em;
$medium: 47em;
$large: 75em;

Documentation: http://susy.oddbird.net/


The basic Susy layout is composed using two simple mixins:

@include container; // establish a layout context
@include span(); // lay out your elements
For example:

body { @include container(80em); }
nav { @include span(25%); }
If you want to lay your elements out on a grid, you can use the span mixin to calculate column widths:

nav { @include span(3 of 12); }
But you don’t have to do things the Susy way. We give you direct access to the math, so you can use it any way you like:

main {
    float: left;
    width: span(4);
    margin-left: span(2) + gutter();
    margin-right: gutter();
}

@include span-columns(4 omega, 12); //omega means that this is the last column on the right

Basically if you make the other span-column be the omega, it switches the columns around.

Transition

Documentation: http://compass-style.org/reference/compass/css3/transition/

So you can just add this line (in _layout.scss) to make the big hero picture slide in instead of abruptly appearing:
@include single-transition(all, 1s, ease-out);

Use this code on your NAV to transform it easily into an horizontal list:

@include at-breakpoint($small){
    @include horizontal-list;
    }
Debugging your SASS

In config.rb, you could change this line:
output_style = :compressed

Into this:
output_style = :expanded

So now, instead of having your final CSS file in just ONE line, it is actually expanded and it also tells you where in your scss files stuff are coming from.









[Fonts]

parent nodes: CSS

Fonts

[camelCaseWordsEnabled: false]

Font pairing Guidelines

1. Match Font Personality with Content
2. Set a hierarchy of meaning
3. Follow the basic pairing rule (pairing serif with sans serif
4. Limit font usage (2 to 3 at most)
    One for headings, one for content and MAYBE another one for special accents like navigation, author name or blog details
Some fonts come in both versions:
- Droid Serif and Sans Serif
- Noto Serif and Sans Serif
- Merriweather Serif and Sans Serif

Suggested combinations:
1) Bevan, Droid and Arimo
2) Oswald, Playfair Display and Open Sans
3) Amatic SC and Roboto Condensed
4) Patua One and Raleway
5) Alpha Slab One, Roboto, Corben

Other sources for fonts:
Google Fonts
Typekit
AdobeEdge Webdonts
Font Shop Webfonts
Fonts.com
Font Squirrel

Google suggests pairing when you click on a font menu (3rd button + pairing tab)

Typecast website also offers live font comparisons

typetester.org
font-combinator.com

12 font considerations

- Typeface
- Type size
- Type weight
- Type style
- Hierarchy
- Line length
- Line height
- Paragraph spacing
- Letterspacing
- Letter case
- Contrast
- Alignment / justification

In print, the preference is to choose a serif font for body text because it's generally considered easier to read. On the web, it doesn't matter as much though it is recommended to mix one with the other (headings vs paragraphs)

When you're choosing font weights, stick with normal font weights for body text, and reserve any light, bold or condensed weights, if you use them at all, for your headings.

Your type style refers to normal and italic fonts which sometimes are called Roman and Oblique. Occasionally, people also include Condensed and Extended font families in this category, but not Bold text. Bold text is treated as a type weight, rather than a style. So, in general, I'd like you to stick with Roman for body text and really reserve Italics, Condensed and Extended fonts styles, for things like headings or for emphasis on smaller blocks of text.

A block of text with too wide or too narrow a measure, or line length, can completely disrupt the reader's rhythm. So, in general, the measure is determined by the font size, but unfortunately, there is no one perfect calculation that all designers use, so instead try an equation that's roughly four times the font size, to get the maximum number of characters per line. For instance, if your type is 16 point, your measure can be about 60 to 65 characters long. While measure is proportional to font size, for improved readability try not to ever go wider than about 70 characters, which is roughly 600 pixels in paragraph widths.

Your line height should be proportionate with your line length. The default as you probably already see in Adobe software and most browsers, is 120 percent of the font's size. So if you increase or decrease your line height, you can actually add interest and focus.

Paragraph spacing refers to the repetitive breaks of space between paragraphs. Most designers create this space for paragraphs and headings by adding top or bottom padding or margins in the CSS. For best results, use one-half the size of the body text line height for your paragraph spacing.

Letterspacing refers to the tracking or added uniform space between all of the letters in a word or phrase. Only adjust the letterspacing for headlines with display type, which are any large fancy fonts used for headings or advertisements or for specialized uses like when creating a logo or logo type. Tracking the letters out within a word or phrase can add a sense of elegance and improve readability, while tightening the letterspacing typically makes the text more difficult to read.

Roughly 90% of all the text we read is comprised of lowercase letters. The coastline or the outline shape of lowercase lettering, is far easier to read than uppercase, which lacks a variable coastline, therefore, reserve your use of all caps and small caps, for display type and for areas of emphasis within your regular text

When we speak of typographic contrast, we normally think, first, in terms of font pairings, and then in terms of color. For best contrast and interest, pair serif with sans serif fonts. As for readability color is extremely important on the web. Light colors on dark backgrounds and dark colors on bright backgrounds are both extremely difficult combinations for readers to look at for an extended period of time. If needed, head over to Webaim.org's free contrast checker, where you can input your text and background colors to find a suitable contrast ratio.

The normal left-aligned ragged-right text is truly easier to read than justified text because of the clean left edge it creates. Justified text can be really great for books, newspapers and magazines, but on the web, it often makes horribly awkward gaps between words that disrupt the reader's rhythm. On the web, reserve justified type as well as type with center and right-alignment for special circumstances like headings, subheadings, buttons, banners, and poetry.









[Foundation]

parent nodes: CSS

Foundation

[camelCaseWordsEnabled: false]

You can download Foundation here: http://foundation.zurb.com/

When working with foundation, you should do it with SASS

When you first download Foundation, in the CSS folder, there are three files:
- foundation.css: Foundation file
- foundation.min.css: Minified foundation.css
- normalize.css: Normalize.css is a fairly standard style sheet that you can go online and download. And it normalizes all of the defaults that come with browsers

Difference between CSS Reset and Normalize.css

1. Normalize.css preserves useful defaults rather than "unstyling" everything. For example, elements like sup or sub "just work" after including normalize.css (and are actually made more robust) whereas they are visually indistinguishable from normal text after including reset.css. So, normalize.css does not impose a visual starting point (homogeny) upon you. This may not be to everyone's taste. The best thing to do is experiment with both and see which gels with your preferences.

2. Normalize.css corrects some common bugs that are out of scope for reset.css. It has a wider scope than reset.css, and also provides bug fixes for common problems like: display settings for HTML5 elements, the lack of font inheritance by form elements, correcting font-size rendering for pre, SVG overflow in IE9, and the button styling bug in iOS.

3. Normalize.css doesn't clutter your dev tools. A common irritation when using reset.css is the large inheritance chain that is displayed in browser CSS debugging tools. This is not such an issue with normalize.css because of the targeted stylings.

4. Normalize.css is more modular. The project is broken down into relatively independent sections, making it easy for you to potentially remove sections (like the form normalizations) if you know they will never be needed by your website.

5. Normalize.css has better documentation. The normalize.css code is documented inline as well as more comprehensively in the GitHub Wiki. This means you can find out what each line of code is doing, why it was included, what the differences are between browsers, and more easily run your own tests. The project aims to help educate people on how browsers render elements by default, and make it easier for them to be involved in submitting improvements.

Then you have the js folder which contains:

- foundation.min.js: all the js files that are in the foundation folder, minified
- foundation folder: all the js files individually, not minified
- vendor: other js files from other vendors
    - modernizr: useful for cross-browser compatibility, also used for mobile device detection scripts
You can either run the js files individually or you can link to the minified version

This is the barebone of a Foundation html file:

<!doctype html>
<html class="no-js" lang="en">
    <head>
      <meta charset="utf-8" />

      <!-- This line identifies that this will be a responsive web design -->
      <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0" />
      <title>Foundation | Welcome</title>

      <!-- You can also change this line to: -->
      <link rel="stylesheet" href="css/foundation.css" />

      <!-- Modernizr can impact the look of the webpage, that's why it is in the head and not at the end of the body -->
      <script src="js/vendor/modernizr.js"></script>
    </head>
    <body>

      <script src="js/vendor/jquery.js"></script>
      <script src="js/foundation.min.js"></script>

      <!--This telling Foundation to monitor any calls to javascript -->
      <script>
      $(document).foundation();
      </script>
    </body>
</html>


The grid

http://foundation.zurb.com/docs/components/grid.html

Foundation ships with a 12-grid system

The first thing to do is to create a div with a class of row:
<div class="row">
</div>

Every row has 12 columns, so you can create as many instances as you want. Next you create your columns:

This is the small grid:
<div class="row">
    <div class="small-3 columns">
    </div>
</div>

We don't have to use only divs. We can also use aside, section, header, footer, nav, etc.

When the screen gets small, the columns will stack on top of each other in a single column. The point at which the stacking occurs happens at a wider point with the large grid and a narrower point with a medium grid.

So to have a different look on a phone, a table and a computer, simply combine the large, medium and small classes within a single div. For example:
<div class="small-9 medium-8 large-2 columns">

Combining all three grids is a little bit overkill. Typically, you'll probably combine the small grid plus either the medium or the large grid.

Offset

Offset is used to introduce more space between columns. Offset is applied on the LEFT of the colum. Example:
<div class="small-9 small-offset-1"> (again you can have an offset in small, medium or large). Make sure your column + offset still equals 12

Offset can even be used on single rows of 12 columns. Example:
<div class="large-10 large-offset-2"> (but it looks kind of stupid to have a large space on the left, oh well, maybe there are some use to it..

Centering

The key here, is to remember that the centering is going to refer to the containing element to which the class is applied. Example:
<div class="large-6 large-centered columns"> Doing that will center the colum on the page but the text itself is not going to be centered

Note:
The order in which the classes are placed don't matter

Block grid

Example: <ul class="medium-block-grid-3">
Which means: Put three pieces of content per row

Ordering

Sometimes on the big screen, you have something in the left column that you actually want to have appear SECOND on the small screen

Foundation offers this way you can change the source order within a row, via push and pull classes. The push classes will push the content from left to right, a given number of cells. The pull classes, pull the content from right to left, a given number of cells.

First step is to rearrange your code so that the SMALL appears properly (so put the code in the right order that you want it to appear on the phone)

<div class="large-3 large-push-9 columns">
    ...
</div>
<div class="large-9 columns large-pull-3">
    ...
</div>

Look and feel

To float images to the left or right, you add a class of "right" or "left"
<img src="img/sfroom.jpg" class="right">

To remove the bullets from a list:
<ul class="no-bullet">
    <li>40 Modern Rooms</li>
    <li>4 Executive Suites</li>
    <li>24-Hour Dining Room</li>
    <li>Business Center</li>
    <li>Fitness Center</li>
    <li>Massage Center</li>
</ul>

All sorts of options here: http://foundation.zurb.com/docs/utility-classes.html

To align text: <div class="large-9 columns text-center">
medium-text-center: will center for medium and large, NOT small
medium-only-text-center: will only center for medium

Buttons: <a href="#" class="button">

3 colours in Foundation:
- Primary: Blue (default you don't have to specify anything)
- Secondary: Gray
- Alert: Red
- Success: Green

<a href="#" class="button success">

Sizes:
- Tiny
- Small
- Medium (default, you don't have to specify anything)
- Large

<a href="#" class="button large">

Panels: http://foundation.zurb.com/docs/components/panels.html

<p class="panel">Founded in 1952 by Arthur Landon, an English businessman who travelled the world in search of the perfect balance of comfort, personality, and convenience.</p>

Thumbnails: http://foundation.zurb.com/docs/components/thumbnails.html
<ul class="small-block-grid-2 large-block-grid-4">
    <li><a href="#" class="th"><img src="img/sfmarket.jpg" alt="Farmer's market. "></a></li>
    <li><a href="#" class="th"><img src="img/sfrocks.jpg" alt="Hot rock massage. "></a></li>
    <li><a href="#" class="th"><img src="img/sfbike.jpg" alt="Biking in San Francisco. "></a></li>
    <li><a href="#" class="th"><img src="img/sfcafe.jpg" alt="Coffee at a cafe. "></a></li>
</ul>

Note that it is possible to round all the corners on your website by changing something in the Foundation SASS file

Custom styles

It is not recommended to add your custom styles to the end of the Foundation stylesheet because when you update Foundation, your styles will be lost.

So I created a custom CSS file called app.css

Visibility classes: http://foundation.zurb.com/docs/components/visibility.html

Visibility classes are really handy things. You can show or hide elements of your web size based on your screen size and orientation, or whether the device's touch enabled. But even if an item is not visible, it is STILL loaded to the page. If you want to make some images or content visible at one screen size but not another, there's a better way to do this with Foundation. That's with the Interchange JavaScript component.

Note: Foundation is based in ems (as opposed to Bootstrap which is based in pixels)

Navigation

Side nav: http://foundation.zurb.com/docs/components/sidenav.html

Make sure to read it as it has important information about accessibility

Nav bar: http://foundation.zurb.com/docs/components/topbar.html

The code starts like this:

<nav>
    <ul>
      <li><a href="#">Home</a></li>
      <li><a href="#">Accommodations</a></li>
      <li><a href="#">Reservations</a></li>
      <li><a href="#">Meetings & Events</a></li>
      <li><a href="#">Contact</a></li>
    </ul>
</nav>

And ends up like this:

<nav class="top-bar" data-topbar>
    <ul class="title-area">
      <li class="name"></li> <!-- This line is important, don't get rid of it even though it's empty!-->
      <!-- Remove the class "menu-icon" to get rid of menu icon. Take out "Menu" to just have icon alone -->
      <li class="toggle-topbar menu-icon"><a href="#"><span>Menu</span></a></li> <!--Without the span, the hamburger wasn't showing up for me -->
    </ul>

    <section class="top-bar-section">
      <ul class="right"> <!--If you remove the class of right, the menu will start on the left -->
        <li class="active"><a href="#">Home</a></li>
        <li><a href="#">Accommodations</a></li>
        <li><a href="#">Reservations</a></li>
        <li><a href="#">Meetings & Events</a></li>
        <li><a href="#">Contact</a></li>
      </ul>
    </section>
</nav>


Note: Every time you see something that starts with data-, that's a trigger for Javascript

For dropdowns, go like this:
<li class="has-dropdown"><a href="#">Accommodations</a>
<ul class="dropdown">
    <li><a href="#">King with Sofa Bed</a></li>
    <li><a href="#">Two Queen Beds</a></li>
    <li><a href="#">Pet-Friendly Suite</a></li>
</ul>
</li>

Off canvas menu: http://foundation.zurb.com/docs/components/offcanvas.html

The code starts like this:
<nav>
    <ul>
      <li><a href="#">Home</a></li>
      <li><a href="#">Accommodations</a>
      <ul>
        <li><a href="#">King with Sofa Bed</a></li>
        <li><a href="#">Two Queen Beds</a></li>
        <li><a href="#">Pet-Friendly Suite</a></li>
      </ul>
      </li>
      <li><a href="#">Reservations</a></li>
      <li><a href="#">Meetings & Events</a></li>
      <li><a href="#">Contact</a></li>
    </ul>
</nav>

Becomes this:
<div class="off-canvas-wrap hide-for-medium-up" data-offcanvas>
    <div class="inner-wrap">
      <nav class="tab-bar">
        <section class="left-small">
          <a class="left-off-canvas-toggle menu-icon"><span></span></a>
        </section>
      </nav>
      <aside class="left-off-canvas-menu">
        <ul class="off-canvas-list">
          <li><a href="#">Home</a></li>
          <li><a href="#">Accommodations</a>
          <ul>
            <li><a href="#">King with Sofa Bed</a></li>
            <li><a href="#">Two Queen Beds</a></li>
            <li><a href="#">Pet-Friendly Suite</a></li>
          </ul>
          </li>
          <li><a href="#">Reservations</a></li>
          <li><a href="#">Meetings & Events</a></li>
          <li><a href="#">Contact</a></li>
        </ul>
      </aside>
      <a class="exit-off-canvas">
[... The rest of your HTML code]
    </div><!--Inner wrap, must go after ALL content-->
</div> <!--Off canvas-->

In nav.html, I actually have a topbar for medium and large and a off-canvas for phones

Javascript

Clearing: http://foundation.zurb.com/docs/components/clearing.html

Three examples:

<h2>Photo Gallery #1</h2>
<p>All images are there</p>
<ul class="clearing-thumbs" data-clearing>
    <li><a href="img/clearing/sfbike-large.jpg" class="th"><img src="img/clearing/sfbike-thumb.jpg"></a></li>
    <li><a href="img/clearing/sfbook-large.jpg" class="th"><img src="img/clearing/sfbook-thumb.jpg"></a></li>
    <li><a href="img/clearing/sfcafe-large.jpg" class="th"><img src="img/clearing/sfcafe-thumb.jpg"></a></li>
    <li><a href="img/clearing/sfdog-large.jpg" class="th"><img src="img/clearing/sfdog-thumb.jpg"></a></li>
    <li><a href="img/clearing/sfmarket-large.jpg" class="th"><img src="img/clearing/sfmarket-thumb.jpg"></a></li>
    <li><a href="img/clearing/sfrocks-large.jpg" class="th"><img src="img/clearing/sfrocks-thumb.jpg"></a></li>
</ul>

<h2>Photo Gallery #2</h2>
<p>One featured image but you can still see all the other ones by clicking on it</p>
<ul class="clearing-thumbs clearing-feature" data-clearing>
    <li><a href="img/clearing/sfbike-large.jpg" class="th"><img src="img/clearing/sfbike-thumb.jpg"></a></li>
    <li><a href="img/clearing/sfbook-large.jpg" class="th"><img src="img/clearing/sfbook-thumb.jpg"></li>
    <li class="clearing-featured-img"><a href="img/clearing/sfcafe-large.jpg" class="th"><img src="img/clearing/sfcafe-thumb.jpg"></a></li>
    <li><a href="img/clearing/sfdog-large.jpg" class="th"><img src="img/clearing/sfdog-thumb.jpg"></a></li>
    <li><a href="img/clearing/sfmarket-large.jpg" class="th"><img src="img/clearing/sfmarket-thumb.jpg"></a></li>
    <li><a href="img/clearing/sfrocks-large.jpg" class="th"><img src="img/clearing/sfrocks-thumb.jpg"></a></li>
</ul>

<h2>Photo Gallery #3</h2>
<p>With captions and better grid</p>
<ul class="clearing-thumbs small-block-grid-2 medium-block-grid-3 large-block-grid-4" data-clearing>
    <li><a href="img/clearing/sfbike-large.jpg" class="th"><img src="img/clearing/sfbike-thumb.jpg" data-caption="Biking in San Francisco"></a></li>
    <li><a href="img/clearing/sfbook-large.jpg" class="th"><img src="img/clearing/sfbook-thumb.jpg" data-caption="Browsing for books"></a></li>
    <li><a href="img/clearing/sfcafe-large.jpg" class="th"><img src="img/clearing/sfcafe-thumb.jpg" data-caption="Enjoying coffee at a café"></a></li>
    <li><a href="img/clearing/sfdog-large.jpg" class="th"><img src="img/clearing/sfdog-thumb.jpg"></a></li>
    <li><a href="img/clearing/sfmarket-large.jpg" class="th"><img src="img/clearing/sfmarket-thumb.jpg"></a></li>
    <li><a href="img/clearing/sfrocks-large.jpg" class="th"><img src="img/clearing/sfrocks-thumb.jpg"></a></li>
</ul>

Equalizer: http://foundation.zurb.com/docs/components/equalizer.html

Makes columns same height (for example, a sidebar and the main content arriving at the same location at the bottom)

1. Add this line to the top: <script src="js/vendor/modernizr.js"></script>
2. Add data-equalizer to the row: <div class="row" data-equalizer>
3. Add data-equalizer-watch to all the sections you want to equalize:
    <article class="medium-9 medium-push-3 columns" data-equalizer-watch>
    <aside class="medium-3 medium-pull-9 columns panel" data-equalizer-watch>
Carousel with Slick (http://kenwheeler.github.io/slick/)
1. Add link to CSS in head: <link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="//cdn.jsdelivr.net/jquery.slick/1.4.0/slick.css"/>
2. Add slick.js before your closing tag, after jQuery (requires jQuery 1.7 +):
<script type="text/javascript" src="slick/slick.min.js"></script>
3. Set up your HTML markup:
<div class="your-class">
    <div>your content</div>
    <div>your content</div>
    <div>your content</div>
</div>


Responsive Lightbox: see the file lightbox.html

Modal Window:

1. Add data-reveal to all your a items
2. Add one of these per image. This is to be placed right after footer over script, way at the bottom:

<!-- Modal Windows -->
<div id="sfdog" class="reveal-modal" data-reveal>
    <img src="img/clearing/sfdog-large.jpg">
    <p>A man and his dog in the San Francisco Park</p>
    <a class="close-reveal-modal">×</a> <!-- &#215 is the code for the X to close the window-->
</div>

Carousel:
1. Download owl carousel http://owlgraphic.com/owlcarousel/
2. Add these two lines to your head:

<!-- Owl Carousel Assets -->
<link href="css/owl.carousel.css" rel="stylesheet">
<link href="css/owl.theme.css" rel="stylesheet">

3. The carousel itself (somewhere in your body)

<h2>Carousel</h2>

<div id="owl-demo" class="owl-carousel">
    <div class="item"><img src="img/banners/1.jpg" alt="Owl Image"></div>
    <div class="item"><img src="img/banners/2.jpg" alt="Owl Image"></div>
    <div class="item"><img src="img/banners/3.jpg" alt="Owl Image"></div>
    <div class="item"><img src="img/banners/4.jpg" alt="Owl Image"></div>
    <div class="item"><img src="img/banners/5.jpg" alt="Owl Image"></div>
    <div class="item"><img src="img/banners/6.jpg" alt="Owl Image"></div>
</div>

<div class="customNavigation">
    <a class="button small prev">Previous</a>
    <a class="button small next">Next</a>
    <a class="button small play">Autoplay</a>
    <a class="button small stop">Stop</a>
</div>

4. Add this at the bottom of the body with the rest of your script stuff:

<script src="js/carousel.js"</script>
<script src="js/owl.carousel.js"></script>

5. Carousel.js is actually something I wrote myself(?) and here is the content:

$(document).ready(function() {
    var owl = $("#owl-demo");
      $("#owl-demo").owlCarousel({
        singleItem:true,
        autoPlay: 3000,
        responsive: true
      });

      // Custom Navigation Events
      $(".next").click(function(){
        owl.trigger('owl.next');
      })
      $(".prev").click(function(){
        owl.trigger('owl.prev');
      })
      $(".play").click(function(){
        owl.trigger('owl.play',3000); //owl.play event accept autoPlay speed as second parameter
      })
      $(".stop").click(function(){
        owl.trigger('owl.stop');
      })
});

See the owl carousel website if you want to have your carousel have a different behaviour

Make image responsive

It's important to replace big images by smaller version for the mobile websites, otherwise people will use up lots of their download for a tiny little image.

Solution 1:
You could use some kind of server side solution. If you happen to be coding with something like PHP, for example, you could have the browser send the client's screen size to the server, and then PHP would pick the right sized image to show up for that particular screen size.

Solution 2:
Javascript based solution by Foundation. The only size downloaded will be the necessary size. Also supports retina images.

Starting point:
<div class="row">
    <div class="medium-12 columns">
      <img src="img/sfnight.jpg" alt="San Francisco." class="bottomspace">
    </div>
</div>

Ending point:
<div class="row">
    <div class="medium-12 columns">
      <img data-interchange="
      [img/interchange/small.jpg, (default)],
      [img/interchange/small.jpg, (small)],
      [img/interchange/retina.jpg], (retina)],
      [img/interchange/medium.jpg, (medium)],
      [img/interchange/large.jpg, (large)]" class="bottomspace"> <!--class of bottomspace is not necessary, it's just needed for this particular project-->
      <!--Adding noscript allow people who have deactivated javascript to still have an image -->
      <noscript><img src="img/sfnight.jpg" alt="San Francisco." class="bottomspace"></noscript>
    </div>
</div>

So, it looks like owl carousel and interchange are in conflict!

Tooltips

http://foundation.zurb.com/docs/components/tooltips.html

Download a custom version of Foundation

Don't change anything on the right-hand side (Grid, colours etc.) You can make those changes using SASS

Make sure you take good notes of which components you download, for when you update to the new Foundation.









[Styling links]

parent nodes: CSS

Styling links

Hyperlink states in CSS

- link - Normal, unvisited
- visited - has been clicked on
- hover (not available on mobile)
- active - as its being clicked

In order to make sure your CSS works, you must put them in that same exact order:

a:link {color: pink;}
a:visited {color: orange;}
a:over {color: green;}
a:active {color: yellow;}

Link style best practice

- Add a little graph when the link is going to an external site (similar to Wikipedia)
- Increase the padding area around your link by 3 to 10 pixel, making the clickable area bigger (easier for people)
- use style, weight, size and color for emphasis
- For visited links, go slightly darker than normal links.









[Drupal]

parent nodes: WebDesign

Drupal

[camelCaseWordsEnabled: false]

==Install Drupal locally using DAMP==

1. Download DAMP from acquia: https://www.acquia.com/downloads (Acquia Dev Desktop 2)
apache web server port: 8083
mysql database port: 33067

2. Go to https://www.drupal.org/project/drupal to download core Drupal (right now you have acquia Drupal)

3. Uncompress Drupal and rename the folder to the name of your site (I'll call mine drupalclaudie)

4. In Acquia Dev Desktop, click on the little + at the bottom of the window and select Import Local Site

5. Browse to your desktop and select drupalclaudie folder

6. Leave create a new database selected and call database drupalclaudie

7. Click OK

8. Access the website and you will be asked to continue Drupal's install

9. Select standard profile and click Save and Continue

10. Configure your site

All done, bravo!

Note: If installing on WAMP, you will have to duplicate a file called settings.php. DAMP takes care of that for you.
Also, Drupal requires 40 Mb of memory but WAMP typically gives it only 2, so there may be a setting somewhere you have to change

==Modules to turn on automatically==

- Aggregator
- Blog

In Drupal 6, it used to be "upload", now: https://www.drupal.org/node/1026432

==Develop Themes==

Note: If you manually download modules, you have to place them in sites > all > modules. If this does not exist, create it.

1. Download the Devel module and the Theme Developer module
2. Enable them but make sure you disable them if ever your website becomes public facing

There is a module called condition style sheet which allows you to render your site differently based on the browser used

In your theme.info file, you would then type something like this:
stylesheets[all][] = not-ie.css
; Set the conditional stylesheets that are processed by IE.
conditional-stylesheets[if IE][all][] = for-ie.css

More details about what to put in theme.info file: https://www.drupal.org/node/171205

[Affiliate Marketing]

parent nodes: General

Affiliate Marketing

[camelCaseWordsEnabled: false]

What is affiliate marketing? Performance-based marketing

Merchant (advertiser)
Affiliate (publisher)

According to stats:
39.9% - less than $5,000
11.8% - $5,000 to $9,999
13.1% - $10,000 to $24,999
9,2% - $50,000 to $99,999

It takes time and substantial effort to start earning good money

Click-through Rate (CTR): Dependant on how targeted your traffic is and the type of linking you'll be using (banners, text links, video, product links, reviews...)

Conversion Rate (CR): Percentage of traffic that converts to desired action

Average Order Value (AOV): Average affiliate-referred ticket, calculated as a sum total of all affiliate generated orders referred over a given period of time, and then divided by the number of orders

Payout: Commission or flat amount per sale/lead.

Reversal Rate (RR): Percentage of affiliate-referred transactions that get reversed by the merchant

Earnings per click (EPC): The metric that tells you what other affiliates are already making on this program

It is NOT possible to build a 100% secure passive income stream through affiliate marketing.

Startup costs: from $150 a year (website domain + hosting)
Time investment: 1-2 hours a day to a full work day

How affiliates can make money

Cost per sale (CPS) / Pay per sale (PPS): Affiliates get a percentage of the sale (80% of affiliate programs work this way)

Cost per lead (CPL) / Pay per lead (PPL): Affiliate receive compensation for referred leads (ex. forms submitted, subscriptions, free trials, etc.)

Cost per click (CPC) : Ceasing model (mainly due to large volume of fraud)

Pay per call: Advertisers pay affiliate for "hot leads" who call in

Types of affiliates

1. Content Publisher:
    Rely on content-saturated websites. Self-authored or user-generated content. Monetize sites with affiliate links, banners, widgets, text links, product links, etc. (example: http://digital-photography-school.com/popular-digital-cameras-and-gear/)
2. Coupon Affiliate:
    Rely on human psychology of trying to find a product at a discounted price. (example: couponcabin.com)
3. Data Feed Affiliates:
    Work with merchants' product feed (example: thefind.com)
4. Display Ads:
    Promote advertisers using display advertising. Includes retargeting.
5. E-mail affiliates:
    Market through e-mail. Includes remarketing.
6. Loyalty and Incentives:
    Offer incentives for desired actions. Cash back, points, virtual currency
7. Mobile or Pay per call:
    Uses mobile marketing and pay-per-call marketing. Bridge the gap between online and offline. May intertwine with location-based marketing.
8. Search engine marketing:
    Employe SEM to drive conversions. SEO, PPC or both.
9. Social Media:
    Leverages existing social media networks. Creates social network.
10. Video affiliates
    Focus on video creatives. Yield 29% higher dwell rate and 45% higher conversion rate.
Clicks are tracked by the platform
Conversion is tracked by a string of code on the merchant's confirmation page or thank you page

Prior to building website

1. Select your niche
    - Follow your passion
    - Monetize hot trends
    - Become key player / influencer
2. Identify Target Demographic (gender, age, income, children, religion, ethnicity, geographic data...)

3. Decide on type of Website
    The key is to provide your friends/followers with high-quality, problem-solving, or entertaining content that they need/want
4. Choose Promotional Methods

5. Select a platform

Note: a dedicated disclosure policy page, visible from every page of the website, should suffice, but you must have one

To generate a disclosure policy: http://disclosurepolicy.org/

Factors for selecting affiliate program

1. Website (ease of use, professionalism)
2. Reputation
3. Competitiveness
4. Market saturation
5. Payouts
6. Commission recurrence
7. Terms of service
8. Cookie life
9. Conversion rate
10. Earnings per click (this is the average of how much affiliates of this merchant earn on every 100 clicks they refer)
11. Reversal rate (rarely disclosed upfront)
12. Tracking/Reporting platform
13. Management/Approachability
14. Creatives
15. Tools

Enemies of money
Broken links
Leaks: Phone number, Live chat, links to related stores/sites/other merchants/other affiliates
Common banner mistakes: Poor graphics, unreadable fonts, Phone number/URL typed out, excessive animation, missing call-to-action, poor contrast, no line around the edge

Monetizing blogs

1. Reviews
2. Rankings
3. Contextual monetization (automate by tools like Skimlinks, Viglinks, Kehalim...)
4. Shop section
5. Coupons and deals section

Embed banners, widgets and video into your content
Google AdSense is not conflicting but complementary
Affiliate disclosure - A must have!

Wordpress plugins to consider:
- Affiliate link encoder from AvantLink
- Amazon AutoLinks
- Commission Junction Product Search
- ClickBank widgets
- eBay feeds for Wordpress
- LinkShare RSS DealFeed
- LinkShare AdMix
- Skimlinks Affiliate Marketing Tools
- VigLink
- Data feed plugisn from PopShops, SellFire, DataFeedR, etc.

How influencers earn revenue:
- 61% - Banner
- 51% - Text ad
- 41% - Affiliate program
- 24% - Producing brand sponsored content
- 19% - Producing brand sponsored reviews
- 19% - Posting brand content
- 17% - Ecommerce
- 7% - Collecting subscription fees

Affiliate data feed: A file (CSV, XML, XLS and others) that lists all merchants products information such as Product ID, name, description, price, image URL, stock availability, product URL, category, keywords, etc. May also include services, deals, etc.

How to import data feed:
- With the help of a software (WebMerge)
- Online-based solutions: network/platform specific
    - Affiliate Window's Create-A-Feed
    - AvantLink's DataFeed Manager
    - LinkShare's LinkLocator Direct
    - Paid on Results' Content Units
    - ShareASale's Make-a-Page
    - Webgain's iSense Ad Creator
- Supported by 3rd party
    - PopShops
    - GoldenCAN
    - DatafeedR
    - Easy Content Units
    - DataFeed File
    - Datafeed Studio
    - FusePump
    - SellFire
    - FeedShare
- Affiliate's own programming / API

How to integrate coupons:
    - AvantLink - Dynamic Coupon Feed
    - CJ by Conversant - Coupon-Only Offers RSS feed
    - ImpactRadius - PromoAds (API)
    - LinkShare - LinkLocator (API)
    - LinkConnector - Coupon/Promotion feed
    - ShareASale - Deals Database Feed
Monday e-mails have the highest revenue per e-mail
Videos seem to be an excellent way of advertising

10 resources:
- ABestWeb forums
- Affiliate blogger pro
- Affiliate Marketers Bootcamp
- Affiliate summit videos (youtube)
- Affilorama
- GeekCast.fm podcasts
- PerformanceIN forums (for Europe)
- "Thoughts for Affiliates" on AM Navigator Blog









[Content Checklist]

parent nodes: General

Content Checklist

[camelCaseWordsEnabled: false]

Source: http://www.uxmatters.com/mt/archives/2009/04/toward-content-quality.php

Usefulness & Relevance:
    Does the content meet user needs, goals, and interests?
    Does the content meet business goals?
    For how long will the content be useful? When should it expire? Has its usefulness already expired?
    Is the content timely and relevant?
Clarity & Accuracy:
    Is the content understandable to customers?
    Is the content organized logically & coherently?
    Is the content correct?
    Does the content contain factual errors, typos, or grammatical errors?
    Do images, video, and audio meet technical standards, so they are clear?
Influence & Engagement:
    Does the content use the most appropriate techniques to influence or engage customers?
    Does the content execute those techniques effectively?
    Does the content use too many or too few techniques for the context?
Completeness:
    Does the content include all of the information customers need or might want about a topic?
    Does the content include too much or too little information about a topic for the context?
Voice & Style:
    Does the content consistently reflect the editorial or brand voice?
    Does its tone adjust appropriately to the context—for example, sales versus customer service?
    Does the content convey the appropriate editorial and brand qualities?
    Does the content seem to have a style? If so, does the content adhere to it consistently?
    Does the content read, look, or sound as though it’s professionally crafted?
Usability & Findability:
    Is the content easy to scan or read?
    Is the content in a usable format, including headings, bulleted lists, tables, white space, or similar techniques, as appropriate to the content?
    Does the content have the appropriate metadata?
    Does the content follow search engine optimization (SEO) guidelines—such as using keywords—
without sacrificing quality in other areas?
    Can customers find the content when searching using relevant keywords?










[E-mail]

parent nodes: General

E-mail

Use this website to encode your e-mail in Unicode so that crawlers and spams cannot get your e-mail address:
http://www.ohlone.edu/org/webcenter/emailencoder.html









[Git]

parent nodes: General | WebDesign

Git

[camelCaseWordsEnabled: false]

Vocabulary
Directory: A folder used for storing multiple files.
Repository: A directory where Git has been initialized to start version controlling your files.
staged: Files are ready to be committed.
unstaged: Files with changes that have not been prepared to be commited.
untracked: Files aren't tracked by Git yet. This usually indicates a newly created file.
deleted: File has been deleted and is waiting to be removed from Git.
Staging Area: A place where we can group files together before we "commit" them to Git.
Commit: A "commit" is a snapshot of our repository. This way if we ever need to look back at the changes we've made (or if someone else does), we will see a nice timeline of all changes.


Commands
git init: To initialize a directory
git status: to see what the current state of the project is
git add [filename]: Tell git to start tracking this file
git commit -m "Add cute octocat story": commit command with a message describing what we've changed
git log: Shows all our changes
git remote add origin https://github.com/try-git/try_git.git: To push our local repo to the GitHub server we'll need to add a remote repository. This command takes a remote name and a repository URL
git push -u origin master: The push command tells Git where to put our commits when we're ready. The name of our remote is origin and the default local branch name is master. The -u tells Git to remember the parameters, so that next time we can simply run git push and Git will know what to do.
git pull origin master: check for changes on our GitHub repository and pull down any new changes
git diff HEAD: diff of our most recent commit, which we can refer to using the HEAD pointer.
git diff --staged: see the changes you just staged
git reset octofamily/octodog.txt: You can unstage files by using the git reset command
git checkout -- octocat.txt: Files can be changed back to how they were at the last commit by using the command: git checkout -- .
git branch clean_up: When developers are working on a feature or bug they'll often create a copy (aka. branch) of their code they can make separate commits to.
git checkout clean_up: You can switch branches using the git checkout command.
git rm '*.txt': removes all the .txt which will not only remove the actual files from disk, but will also stage the removal of the files for us.
git merge clean_up: merge your changes from the clean_up branch into the master branch
git branch -d : delete a branch

add all:
You can also type git add -A . where the dot stands for the current directory, so everything in and beneath it is added. The -A ensures even file deletions are included.
git reset:
You can use git reset to remove a file or files from the staging area.

More useful logs:
Use git log --summary to see more information for each commit. You can see where new files were added for the first time or where files were deleted. It's a good overview of what's going on in the project.

git remote: Git doesn't care what you name your remotes, but it's typical to name your main one origin.
It's also a good idea for your main repository to be on a remote server like GitHub

Cool Stuff:
When you start to get the hang of git you can do some really cool things with hooks when you push.
For example, you can upload directly to a webserver whenever you push to your master remote instead of having to upload your site with an ftp client. Check out Customizing Git - Git Hooks for more information. (http://git-scm.com/book/en/v2/Customizing-Git-Git-Hooks)

git stash:
Sometimes when you go to pull you may have changes you don't want to commit just yet. One option you have, other than commiting, is to stash the changes.
Use the command 'git stash' to stash your changes, and 'git stash apply' to re-apply your changes after your pull.

HEAD
The HEAD is a pointer that holds your position within all your different commits. By default HEAD points to your most recent commit, so it can be used as a quick way to reference that commit without having to look up the SHA.

Commit Etiquette:
You want to try to keep related changes together in separate commits. Using 'git diff' gives you a good overview of changes you have made and lets you add files or directories one at a time and commit them separately.

The '--'
So you may be wondering, why do I have to use this '--' thing? git checkout seems to work fine without it. It's simply promising the command line that there are no more options after the '--'. This way if you happen to have a branch named octocat.txt, it will still revert the file, instead of switching to the branch of the same name.

Branching
Branches are what naturally happens when you want to work on multiple features at the same time. You wouldn't want to end up with a master branch which has Feature A half done and Feature B half done.
Rather you'd separate the code base into two "snapshots" (branches) and work on and commit to them separately. As soon as one was ready, you might merge this branch back into the master branch and push it to the remote server.

All at Once
You can use:
git checkout -b new_branch
to checkout and create a branch at the same time. This is the same thing as doing:
git branch new_branch
git checkout new_branch

Remove all the things!
Removing one file is great and all, but what if you want to remove an entire folder? You can use the recursive option on git rm:
git rm -r folder_of_cats
This will recursively remove all folders and files from the given directory.

The '-a' option
If you happen to delete a file without using 'git rm' you'll find that you still have to 'git rm' the deleted files from the working tree. You can save this step by using the '-a' option on 'git commit', which auto removes deleted files with the commit.
git commit -am "Delete stuff"

Pull Requests
If you're hosting your repo on GitHub, you can do something called a pull request.
A pull request allows the boss of the project to look through your changes and make comments before deciding to merge in the change. It's a really great feature that is used all the time for remote workers and open-source projects.

Force delete
What if you have been working on a feature branch and you decide you really don't want this feature anymore? You might decide to delete the branch since you're scrapping the idea. You'll notice that git branch -d bad_feature doesn't work. This is because -d won't let you delete something that hasn't been merged.
You can either add the --force (-f) option or use -D which combines -d -f together into one command.

The .git directory
You'll notice a .git directory. It's usually hidden but we're showing it to you for convenience.

If you click it you'll notice it has all sorts of directories and files inside it. You'll rarely ever need to do anything inside here but it's the guts of Git, where all the magic happens.

Learning more about Git
We only scratched the surface of Git in this course. There is so much more you can do with it. Check out the Git documentation for a full list of functions. http://git-scm.com/docs

The Pro Git book, by Scott Chacon, is an excellent resource to teach you the inner workings of Git.
http://git-scm.com/book/en/v2

help.github and GitHub Training are also great for anything related to Git in general and using Git with GitHub. https://help.github.com/









[Google App Engine]

parent nodes: General

Google App Engine

[camelCaseWordsEnabled: false]

Google App Engine:
- Platform as a service (PaaS)
    -> Generally a Platform as a Service provides the networks, servers, storage, and other services needed to host applications.
- Supports:
    - Web App
    - Mobile App
    - Games
- Offers complete server-side management
- Automatically scales to an unlimited number of users
- Auto-scaling
    - Instances added as needed
    - Databases shared on demand
    - Bandwidth expanded when necessary
- Great performance
- Tight security with fully sandboxed apps
- Extremely reliable

Supported languages:
- Java
- Python
- Go ("Experimental" - limited functionality)
- PHP (Preview)

To work with App Engine, you'll need to choose one of the language options, and install its SDK.
Documentation (including tutorials): https://cloud.google.com/appengine/docs
SDKs: https://cloud.google.com/appengine/downloads

App enging costs:
- No start-up costs
- No charge limit:
    - 10 Applications per developer account
    - 1 GB storage per application
    - 5 million page views per month per application
Other Google Cloud Platform services
- Compute Engine:
    - For large scale computing needs
    - Same infrastructure as Google Search, Gmail, Ads
    - VMs on demand (you can specify 1, 2, 4 or 8 core instances. Up to 3.75 GB memory per core)
- Cloud Storage:
    - Global regional hosting
    - Fast access
    - Guaranteed up-time of 99.95%
    - Backup and restore option
    - Storage unlimited
- BigQuery:
    - Analyze massive amount of data extremely quickly
    - Access via simple UI or REST (Representational State Transfer) interface
    - Data storage scales to 100s of TB
    - Accessible via client API libraries (Java, .NET, Python, Go, Ruby, PHP, Javascript, etc.)
    - SQL-like syntax (NoSQL)
- Cloud SQL:
    - Relational database
    - MySQL
    - Host in US or EU
    - 100 GB storage, 16 GB RAM per instance
- Cloud Datastore:
    - Non-relational database
    - NoSQL
    - Free up to 50 000 read/write, 200 indexes
    - 1 GB data / month
- Google Prediction API for trend forecasting
- Google Translate API

Quotas

- Safety Quotas
    - Daily (replenished at midnight, Pacific time)
    - Per-minute
- Billable quotas

https://cloud.google.com/appengine/docs/quotas

Project Name: App Engine Lynda 001
ID: crack-cogency-797
URL: crack-cogency-797.appspot.com

In the console (https://console.developers.google.com) under APIs & Auth > API, you will find a list of all the Google Services you can have access to along with the limits.

Turn on URL shortener API.

GIT

You can connect Google Cloud with GIT under Source Code > Developer Tools (I think)

Creating apps to run PHP on Google App Engine

Step 1: Install the SDK
Step 2: Create new folder somewhere
Step 3: Create main.php (this is your php code)
Step 4: Create app.yaml (this is your configuration file)

application: firstapp
version: 1
runtime: php
api_version: 1

handlers:
- url: /.*
    script: main.php
Step 5: In Google App Engine Launcher, click file > Add existing application
Step 6: Browse to the folder where your main.php and app.yaml files are located and click OK
Step 7: Leave default values for port stuff
Step 8: Click Add
Step 9: Select the app, click Run
Step 10: Once the icon becomes green, go to localhost:8080/ in Google Chrome and admire your beautiful app!

To handle images and css files

Here is your app.yaml configuration to handle images and css:

application: static-files-demo
version: 1
runtime: php
api_version: 1

handlers:
- url: /styles
    static_dir: styles
- url: /images
    static_dir: images
- url: /.*
    script: main.php
To accept only some file types for images, change to this:

- url: /images/(.*\.(gif|png|jpg))
    static_files: images/\1
Connecting to a MySQL database

See the app called dbapp under Dropbox\New career\Web Designer\App Engine\aeapps\dbapp

Deploy to app engine

Step 1: Register your app in Google Cloud: https://appengine.google.com Click on Create new application and fill the information.
Step 2: Go in your app.yaml file and ensure that your app ID both on Google and on app.yaml are identical
Step 3: All files will need to be transfered to Google. Anything that looks like this (with static_dir) will be automatically transfered
- url: /styles
    static_dir: styles
But if you used a regular expression such as this, then you will have to add an upload command to app.yaml:
- url: /images/(.*\.(gif|png|jpg))
    static_files: images/\1
Basically just add this line under static_file: upload: images/(.*\.(gif|png|jpg))
It is an exact copy of the first line, minus the first /

Step 4: Go to Google App Engine Launcher, select the app you want to deploy to Google and click Deploy

Step 5: Sign in to your account

==App engine and Python==

Step 1: create main.py
Step 2: create app.yaml

application: firstapp
version: 1
runtime: python
api_version: 1
threadsafe: true

handlers:
- url: /.*
    script: main.application
Note that script is main.application NOT main.py

==Incorporating HTML in Python code==

Step 1: Modify app.yaml to add libraries

application: firstapp
version: 1
runtime: python27
api_version: 1
threadsafe: true

libraries:
- name: jinja2
    version: latest
handlers:
- url: /.*
    script: main.application
Step 2: Ok I didn't quite get it but change the code in main.py to this:

import webapp2

import os
import jinja2

jinja_environment = jinja2.Environment(autoescape=True,
    loader=jinja2.FileSystemLoader(os.path.join(os.path.dirname(_file_))))
class MainPage(webapp2.RequestHandler):
    def get(self):
    template_values = {
      'welcome':'Welcome to Roux Academy'
    }

    template = jinja_environment.get_template('index.htm')
      self.response.write(template.render(template_values))
application = webapp2.WSGIApplication([
    ('/',MainPage),
    ], debug=True)

The full solution is here: Dropbox\New career\Web Designer\App Engine\pyapps\test-py-001
(actually it doesn't really work so why don't you just ignore :)

==Cloud SQL==

- Fully managed relational database service
- Uses MySQL database
- Data replicated across multiple data centres
- You can import existing databases
- You can export to mysqldump format
- Allows you to create multiple db instances
- 100 GB storage per instance
- 16 GB RAM per instance
- Billing must be enabled

Restrictions:
- User-defined functions not supported
- MySQL replication not supported
- MySQL not supported:
    - LOAD DATA INFILE
    - SELECT ... INTO OUTFILE/DUMPFILE
    - INSTALL/UNINSTALL PLUGIN
    - CREATE FUNCTION
    - LOAD_FILE()
Import steps:
1. Create project
2. Enable billing
3. Store SQL file in cloud storage
4. Establish instance (storage > cloud SQL)
    a. Click create new instance
    b. Click on the instance ID
    c. Click import (/)
    d. Go to operations tab to make sure your import was done
5. Import data

In PHP, 3 connections are supported:
- PDO
- mysql_connect
- mysqli

You will connect via a socket

In the examples below,
- App ID = hello-php
- Database instance ID = my-cloudsql-instance

PDO:
$db = new PDO('mysql:unix_socket=/cloudsql/hello-php:my-cloudsql-instance;charset=utf8', '', '');

mysql_connect:
$conn = my_sqlconnect(":/cloudsql/hello-php:my-cloudsql-instance", "", "");

mysqli:
$sql = new mysqli(null, "", "", "", null, "/cloudsql/hello-php:my-cloudsql-instance"); //may be wrong, not sure

==Custom domain==

1. Go in admin console of one of your projects on which you have enabled billing
2. Click on Billing & Settings
3. Click on App Engine Settings at the bottom
4. Click on Custom Domains









[Google Maps API]

parent nodes: General

Google Maps API

[camelCaseWordsEnabled: false]

Google Maps API: http://storelocator.googlecode.com/git/index.html
Reference: http://storelocator.googlecode.com/git/reference.html

Step 1:
Create empty divs called map-canvas and panel. They remain empty, they will be filled by Javascript

Step 2:
Includes:

<script type="text/javascript" src="_scripts/jquery-1.8.2.min.js"></script> <!-- Javascript -->
<script type="text/javascript" src="http://maps.googleapis.com/maps/api/js?sensor=false"></script> <!-- Google API -->
<script type="text/javascript" src="_scripts/store-locator.compiled.js"></script> <!-- Store locator downloaded from Git (URL above) -->

Note: An excel exported CSV will not load into the store locator application properly because it needs to have the double-quote around all the values (which Excel will not do)

See Store locator under jQuery in Bluehost

[Grunt]

parent nodes: General

Grunt

[camelCaseWordsEnabled: false]

Step 1. Create a package.json file in your main directory

grunt-contrib-watch: https://github.com/gruntjs/grunt-contrib-watch
grunt-contrib-less: https://github.com/gruntjs/grunt-contrib-less
grunt-contrib-uglify: https://github.com/gruntjs/grunt-contrib-uglify
grunt-contrib-concat: https://github.com/gruntjs/grunt-contrib-concat
grunt-contrib-cssmin: ??
matchdep: https://github.com/tkellen/node-matchdep

Example of a package.json file for a bootstrap project:
{
    "name" : "lean-claudie",
    "version" : "0.0.1",
    "dependencies" : {
      "grunt" : "~0.4.5",
      "grunt-contrib-watch" : "~0.6.1",
      "grunt-contrib-less" : "~1.0.0",
      "grunt-contrib-uglify" : "~0.7.0",
      "grunt-contrib-concat" : "~0.5.0",
      "grunt-contrib-cssmin" : "~0.11.0",
      "matchdep" : "~0.3.0"
    }
}

Step 2. In command line, go to your directory and type npm install. This will run package.json and install the proper dependencies for your project

Step 3. Create a gruntfile.js file

Example of a gruntfile.js for a bootstrap project:
module.exports = function(grunt){
    grunt.loadNpmTasks('grunt-contrib-uglify');
    grunt.loadNpmTasks('grunt-contrib-watch');
    grunt.loadNpmTasks('grunt-contrib-less');
    grunt.loadNpmTasks('grunt-contrib-concat');
    grunt.loadNpmTasks('grunt-contrib-cssmin');

    grunt.initConfig({
      less: {
        lessbootstrap: {
          options: {
            paths: ["_/css"]
          },
          files: {
            "_/css/bootstrap.css": "_/components/less/bootstrap.less"
          }
        },
        lessother: {
          options: {
            paths: ["_/css"]
          },
          files: {
            "_/css/mystyles.css": "_/components/less/_mystyles.less"
          }
        }
      },
      concat: {
        dist: {
          src: ['_/components/js/jquery.js', '_/components/js/affix.js', '_/components/js/transition.js', '_/components/js/tooltip.js', '_/components/js/alert.js', '_/components/js/button.js', '_/components/js/carousel.js', '_/components/js/collapse.js', '_/components/js/dropdown.js', '_/components/js/modal.js', '_/components/js/popover.js', '_/components/js/scrollspy.js', '_/components/js/tab.js'],
          dest: '_/js/bootstrap.js',
        }
      },
      cssmin: {
        target: {
          files: {
            '_/css/final.css': ['_/css/bootstrap.css', '_/css/mystyles.css']
          }
        }
      },
      uglify: {
        uglifybootstrap: {
          files: {
            '_/js/bootstrap.js': ['_/js/bootstrap.js']
          }//files
        },
        uglifyother: {
          files: {
            '_/js/myscript.js': ['_/components/js/_myscript.js']
          }//files
        }
      }, //uglify
      watch: {
        less: {
          files: ['_/components/less/_mystyles.less'],
          tasks: ['less:lessother', 'cssmin']
        }, //less
        uglify: {
          files: ['_/components/js/_myscript.js'],
          tasks: ['uglify:uglifyother']
        }, //uglify
      } //watch
    })//initConfig
    grunt.registerTask('default','watch');
} //exports


That's it! Now you can type grunt in your command line and wait! :)









[HTML and CSS Tutorial - Shay Howe]

parent nodes: General

HTML and CSS Tutorial - Shay Howe

[camelCaseWordsEnabled: false]

Tutorial located here: http://learn.shayhowe.com

Here is your basic HTML page with the strict minimum:

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
    <meta charset="utf-8">
    <title>Styles Conference</title>
</head>
<body>
</body>
</html>

Then you should add your CSS link along with CSS resets

Summary of steps:

1. Create a folder called assets and inside that "assets" folder, another folder called "stylesheets"
2. Create a file called main.css and place it under stylesheet
3. In main.css, copy Eric Meyer's CSS reset: http://meyerweb.com/eric/tools/css/reset/
4. Add the link from index.html to main.css in the head, just after the title
    <link rel="stylesheet" href="assets/stylesheets/main.css">
OR

1. Download Boilerplate template (http://html5boilerplate.com/)

5. Now start outlining the structure of the page (header, footer, aside, nav, etc.) Make sure you create the nav as an unordered list
6. Create files for the other pages of our website
7. Apply some CSS to place elements on the page where they should be
8.Add the clearfix code to fix the floating issues in the page structure
9. Style body (font family)
10. Style h1 to h5, strong, cite, em
11. Style links (a, a:hover)
12. Style the header
13. Style the nav
14. Style the footer
15. Add images and other media (audio, video, iframes...)

Divisions, or <div>s, and <span>s are HTML elements that act as containers solely for styling purposes

Block vs. Inline Elements

Most elements are either block- or inline-level elements. What’s the difference?

Block-level elements begin on a new line, stacking one on top of the other, and occupy any available width. Block-level elements may be nested inside one another and may wrap inline-level elements. We’ll most commonly see block-level elements used for larger pieces of content, such as paragraphs.

Inline-level elements do not begin on a new line. They fall into the normal flow of a document, lining up one after the other, and only maintain the width of their content. Inline-level elements may be nested inside one another; however, they cannot wrap block-level elements. We’ll usually see inline-level elements with smaller pieces of content, such as a few words.

A <div> is a block-level element that is commonly used to identify large groupings of content, and which helps to build a web page’s layout and design. A <span>, on the other hand, is an inline-level element commonly used to identify smaller groupings of text within a block-level element.

Each heading level (h1 to h6) should be used where it is semantically valued, and should not be used to make text bold or big—there are other, better ways to do that.

Bold Text with Strong

To make text bold and place a strong importance on it, we’ll use the <strong> inline-level element. There are two elements that will bold text for us: the <strong> and <b> elements. It is important to understand the semantic difference between the two.

The <strong> element is semantically used to give strong importance to text, and is thus the most popular option for bolding text. The <b> element, on the other hand, semantically means to stylistically offset text, which isn’t always the best choice for text deserving prominent attention. We have to gauge the significance of the text we wish to set as bold and to choose an element accordingly.

Italicize Text with Emphasis

To italicize text, thereby placing emphasis on it, we’ll use the <em> inline-level element. As with the elements for bold text, there are two different elements that will italicize text, each with a slightly different semantic meaning.

The <em> element is used semantically to place a stressed emphasis on text; it is thus the most popular option for italicizing text. The other option, the <i> element, is used semantically to convey text in an alternative voice or tone, almost as if it were placed in quotation marks. Again, we will need to gauge the significance of the text we want to italicize and choose an element accordingly.

Building Structure

For the longest time the structure of a web page was built using divisions. The problem was that divisions provide no semantic value, and it was fairly difficult to determine the intention of these divisions. Fortunately HTML5 introduced new structurally based elements, including the <header>, <nav>, <article>, <section>, <aside>, and <footer> elements.

All of these new elements are intended to give meaning to the organization of our pages and improve our structural semantics. They are all block-level elements and do not have any implied position or style. Additionally, all of these elements may be used multiple times per page, so long as each use reflects the proper semantic meaning.


|---------------------------------------|
|..................Header...............|
|.......................................|
|---------------------------------------|
|...........................|...........|
|..........Section..........|...........|
|...|-------------------|...|...Aside...|
|...|....Article........|...|...........|
|...|...................|...|...........|
|...|-------------------|...|...........|
|...........................|...........|
|...........................|...........|
|---------------------------------------|
|..................Footer...............|
|.......................................|
|---------------------------------------|


Navigation

The <nav> element identifies a section of major navigational links on a page. The <nav> element should be reserved for primary navigation sections only, such as global navigation, a table of contents, previous/next links, or other noteworthy groups of navigational links.

Most commonly, links included within the <nav> element will link to other pages within the same website or to parts of the same web page. Miscellaneous one-off links should not be wrapped within the <nav> element; they should use the anchor element, <a>, and the anchor element alone.

Article

The <article> element is used to identify a section of independent, self-contained content that may be independently distributed or reused. We’ll often use the <article> element to mark up blog posts, newspaper articles, user-submitted content, and the like.

When deciding whether to use the <article> element, we must determine if the content within the element could be replicated elsewhere without any confusion. If the content within the <article> element were removed from the context of the page and placed, for example, within an email or printed work, that content should still make sense.

Section

The <section> element is used to identify a thematic grouping of content, which generally, but not always, includes a heading. The grouping of content within the <section> element may be generic in nature, but it’s useful to identify all of the content as related.

The <section> element is commonly used to break up and provide hierarchy to a page.

Deciding Between <article>, <section>, or <div> Elements

At times it becomes fairly difficult to decide which element—<article>, <section>, or <div>—is the best element for the job based on its semantic meaning. The trick here, as with every semantic decision, is to look at the content.

Both the <article> and <section> elements contribute to a document’s structure and help to outline a document. If the content is being grouped solely for styling purposes and doesn’t provide value to the outline of a document, use the <div> element.

If the content adds to the document outline and it can be independently redistributed or syndicated, use the <article> element.

If the content adds to the document outline and represents a thematic group of content, use the <section> element.

Aside

The <aside> element holds content, such as sidebars, inserts, or brief explanations, that is tangentially related to the content surrounding it. When used within an <article> element, for example, the <aside> element may identify content related to the author of the article.

We may instinctively think of an <aside> element as an element that appears off to the left or right side of a page. We have to remember, though, that all of the structural elements, including the <aside> element, are block-level elements and as such will appear on a new line, occupying the full available width of the page or of the element they are nested within, also known as their parent element.

Footer

The <footer> element identifies the closing or end of a page, article, section, or other segment of a page. Generally the <footer> element is found at the bottom of its parent. Content within the <footer> element should be relative information and should not diverge from the document or section it is included within.

Anchors

By nature the anchor element, <a>, is an inline element, and, according to web standards, inline-level elements may not wrap block-level elements. With the introduction of HTML5, however, anchor elements specifically have permission to wrap either block-, inline-, or any other level elements. This is a break from the standard convention, but it’s permissible in order to enable entire blocks of content on a page to become links.

E-mail

To create an email link, the href attribute value needs to start with mailto: followed by the email address to which the email should be sent. To create an email link to shay@awesome.com, for example, the href attribute value would be mailto:shay@awesome.com.

Additionally, subject, body text, and other information for the email may be populated. To add a subject line, we’ll include the subject= parameter after the email address. The first parameter following the email address must begin with a question mark, ?, to bind it to the hyperlink path. Multiple words within a subject line require that spaces be encoded using %20.

Adding body text works in the same way as adding the subject, this time using the body= parameter in the href attribute value. Because we are binding one parameter to another we need to use the ampersand, &, to separate the two. As with the subject, spaces must be encoded using %20, and line breaks must be encoded using %0A.

Altogether, a link to shay@awesome.com with the subject of “Reaching Out” and body text of “How are you” would require an href attribute value of mailto:shay@awesome.com?subject=Reaching%20Out&body=How%20are%20you.

Here’s the full breakdown:

<a href="mailto:shay@awesome.com?subject=Reaching%20Out&body=How%20are%20you">Email Me</a>

Opening links in new window: <a href="http://shayhowe.com/" target="_blank">Shay Howe</a>

Back to top link

<body id="top">
    ...
    <a href="#top">Back to top</a>
    ...
</body>

Calculating CSS Specificity

Every selector in CSS has a specificity weight. A selector’s specificity weight, along with its placement in the cascade, identifies how its styles will be rendered.

The type selector has the lowest specificity weight and holds a point value of 0-0-1.
The class selector has a medium specificity weight and holds a point value of 0-1-0.
Lastly, the ID selector has a high specificity weight and holds a point value of 1-0-0.

Combining Selectors

When selectors are combined they should be read from right to left. The selector farthest to the right, directly before the opening curly bracket, is known as the key selector. The key selector identifies exactly which element the styles will be applied to. Any selector to the left of the key selector will serve as a prequalifier.

The first combined selector above, .hotdog p, includes two selectors: a class and a type selector. These two selectors are separated by a single space. The key selector is a type selector targeting paragraph elements. And because this type selector is prequalified with a class selector of hotdog, the full combined selector will only select paragraph elements that reside within an element with a class attribute value of hotdog.

One way to keep the specificity weights of our selectors low is to be as modular as possible, sharing similar styles from element to element. And one way to be as modular as possible is to layer on different styles by using multiple classes.

Let’s take a look at buttons, for example. Say we want all of our buttons to have a font size of 16 pixels, but we want the background color of our buttons to vary depending on where the buttons are used. We can create a few classes and layer them on an element as necessary to apply the desired styles.

HTML

<a class="btn btn-danger">...</a>
<a class="btn btn-success">...</a>

CSS

.btn {
    font-size: 16px;
}
.btn-danger {
    background: red;
}
.btn-success {
    background: green;
}

Here you can see two anchor elements, both with multiple class attribute values. The first class, btn, is used to apply a font size of 16 pixels to each of the elements. Then, the first anchor element uses an additional class of btn-danger to apply a red background color while the second anchor element uses an additional class of btn-success to apply a green background color. Our styles here are clean and modular.

Colors

All color values within CSS are defined on an sRGB (or standard red, green, and blue) color space.
