This session will provide an overview of common architectures and technologies used in the industry to host performing Drupal sites and more importantly, why they are used. This includes:

Single server and multi-tiered architecture
Server roles in a multi-tiered architecture and their resource requirements
Databases: MySQL, PostgreSQL, SQLite
Webservers: Apache, Nginx
PHP: FPM, CGI, LibModPHP
Cache Proxies: Varnish, Nginx, Squid, Akamai, Fastly
Cache Stores: Memcache, Redis
Knowing what's right for your application is more than knowing the architecture and the technology to use. Performance testing and monitoring tools are just as important as the infrastructure. We'll look at some free and paid tools to help you measure the ability of your application including:

Testing with JMeter
Testing with Blazemeter
Profiling with XHProf
Monitoring with Cacti
Monitoring and profiling with New Relic
Dependency Injection, Symfony Dependency Injection Container









[List of Pages]

parent nodes: General

List of Pages

[camelCaseWordsEnabled: false]

Pages typically found on a website

- About us
- Awards/Professional affiliations
- Company information (what we do and brief history)
- Client lists
- Customer quotes or testimonials
- Job postings
- Contact us
- Contact details
- FAQs (frequently asked questions)
- Feedback form
- Maps of and directions to office locations
- Resellers / distributors
- Content
- Advice
- Competition
- Events
- News
- Weather
- Legally required / recommended
- Copyright statement (e.g. © RAC 2003. All rights reserved.)
- Privacy policy
- Terms and conditions
- Member / user login
- Personalised member area
- Press centre
- Contact details for PR dep’t
- Management/Key personnel
- Press releases - Product
- Catalogue
- Description of individual product
- Large image of each product
- Shopping basket / online sales
- Software downloads
- Video of product in use
- Customer survey
- FAQs (frequently asked questions)
- Sample / brochure request form
- Search
- Site map
- Useful links (related links to external sites)

Only include content that is useful, valued and read by the audience.









[MongoDB]

parent nodes: General

Mongo DB

[camelCaseWordsEnabled: false]

MongoDB is a document database. This means that we store data as documents, which are similar to JavaScript objects. Here below are a few sample JS objects:
    var a = {age: 25};
    var n = {name: 'Ed', languages: ['c', 'ruby', 'js']};
    var student = {name: 'Jim', scores: [75, 99, 87.2]};
Here's how you save a document to MongoDB:
    db.scores.save({a: 99});
This says, "save the document '{a: 99}' to the 'scores' collection.".
To confirm that it's been saved properly:
db.scores.find();

Let's find all documents where a == 2:
    db.scores.find({a: 2});
Or we could find all documents where a > 15:
    db.scores.find({a: {'$gt': 15}})
$gt` is one of many special query operators. Here are few others:
    {a: {$lt: 5}} // Less Than
    {a: {$gte: 10}} // Greater than or equal to
    {a: {$ne: 'b'}} // Not Equal To
    {a: {$in: ['a', 'b', 'c']}} // Exists in array
Update

db.users.insert({name: 'Johnny', languages: ['ruby', 'c']});
db.users.update({name: 'Johnny'}, {name: 'Cash', languages: ['English']});
db.users.find()

db.users.insert({name: 'Sue', languages: ['scala', 'lisp']});

Update Sue's languages without overwriting them:
    db.users.update({name: 'Sue'}, { $addToSet: {languages: 'ruby'}});
Or we can add a new field to Cash
    db.users.update({name: 'Cash'}, {'$set': {'age': 50} });
ou can also push and pull items from arrays:
    db.users.update({name: 'Sue'}, {'$push': {'languages': 'ruby'} });
    db.users.update({name: 'Sue'}, {'$pull': {'languages': 'scala'} });
Delete

To delete matching documents only, add a query selector to the remove method:
    db.users.remove({name: 'Sue'});
To delete everything from a collection:
    db.scores.remove({});










[Open Cart]

parent nodes: General

Open Cart

Migrating opencart: http://isenselabs.com/posts/step-by-step-opencart-migration-to-a-new-server









[Regular Expressions]

parent nodes: General

Regular Expressions

[camelCaseWordsEnabled: false]

d : used in place of any digit from 0 to 9
D : represents any non-digit character
. : match any single character (in order to specifically match a period, you need to escape the dot by using a slash . accordingly.)
w : used in place of any alphanumeric
W : any non-alphanumeric
s : any white space
S : any non-whitespace character
[abc] : will only match a single a, b, or c letter and nothing else.
[^abc] : will instead match any single character except for the letters a, b, or c.
[0-6] : will match any digit character from zero to six, and nothing else.
[^n-p] : will match any character except for letters n to p.
a{3} : will match the a character exactly three times. Some implementations, also allow you to specify a range for this value. For example, "a{1,3}" will match the a character no more than 3 times, but no less than once. In Javascript, you can even leave out the second count and just specify a minimum value, for example "a{1,}" will match 1 or more a's.
d* : matches any number of digits
d+ : matches one digit or more
? : denotes optionality. Allows you to match either zero or one of the preceding character or group. For example, the pattern ab?c will match either the strings "abc" or "ac" because the b is considered optional.
^ : matches the beginning of the string
$ : matches the end of the string
() : capture a part of the pattern. Example: (w+).pdf$ will capture file_a from file_a.pdf
| : logical OR, aka. the pipe. Denotes different possible sets of characters. I love (cats|dogs)
b : matches the boundary between a word and a non-word character

Patterns are case sensitive and a-z differs from A-Z in terms of the characters it matches (lower vs upper case).

The most common forms of whitespace you will use with regular expressions is defined as the space _, the tab t, the new line n and the carriage return r (useful in Windows environments), and these special characters match each of their respective whitespaces. In addition, a whitespace special character s will match any of the specific whitespaces above and is extremely useful when dealing with imperfect input text.

One concept that we will not explore in great detail in these lessons is referencing, mostly because it varies depending on the implementation. However, many systems allow you to reference your captured groups by using 0 (usually the full matched text), 1 (group 1), 2 (group 2), etc. This is useful for example when you are in a text editor and doing a search and replace using regular expressions to swap two numbers, you can search for "(d+)-(d+)" and replace it with "2-1" put the second captured number first, and the first captured number second.

Regular Expression Sandbox:
http://www.regexr.com/

More about capture:
(d+)x(d+)

Text capture
1280x720 1280, 720
1920x1600 1920, 1600
1024x768 1024, 768

Sending an e-mail

[SEO]

parent nodes: General

SEO

[camelCaseWordsEnabled: false]

Local SEO

- Create a high quality Google My Business Profile
- Have a really relevant on-page content
- List your business name, address and phone number across the web (in the same format)
- Collect great links
- Get reviews

Figure out your business category:
https://moz.com/local/categories
http://blumenthals.com/google-lbc-categories/

SEO Tool to investigate: http://opensiteexplorer.com

Keywords: http://schema.org/
Google's structured data markup helper: https://www.google.com/webmasters/markup-helper/u/0/
Google's Make the Web Faster: https://developers.google.com/speed/?hl=en
Google's Breadcrumbs: https://developers.google.com/structured-data/breadcrumbs?hl=en
Google's Webmaster Tools: https://www.google.com/webmasters/tools/home?hl=en
Google My Business: https://www.google.com/business/

Example of a sitemap for humans: http://www.lynda.com/sitemap
Example of a sitemap for Google: http://www.lynda.com/sitemap.xml

Another tool that you can download to generate a sitemap? http://www.screamingfrog.co.uk/

Possible directories:
- YP (Yellow Pages)
- Yelp
- Superpages.com
- Citysearch
- Yahoo Local
- Manta
- Better Business Bureau
- Angie's list
- Merchant Circle
- HomeAdvisor
- Facebook

Find your business locally: https://moz.com/local











[Tools and Shortcuts]

parent nodes: General

Tools and Shortcuts

Free Bootstrap Templates:
http://w3layouts.com/
https://bootswatch.com/

Make an image have transparent background (remove image background)

http://lunapic.com/editor/?action=load
Just upload/enter URL of the file
Edit menu/Transparent (last one)
Click on the area you want to make transparent (the background)
Change the treshold to high if necessary (and apply)









[User Requirements Questionnaire]

parent nodes: General

User Requirements Questionnaire

[camelCaseWordsEnabled: false]

1. What is your business’s name?

2. Please briefly describe your business, what services you offer, how and where you operate and who your customers are.

3. Do you already own a website that you wish to update or do you want to build a brand new website?

4. What actions do you want visitors to take on the site? (e.g. make a purchase, contact you, hire you, other)

5. Do you have a logo and/or established image and branding guidelines e.g. fonts, colour schemes etc?

6. Please list your top competitors

7. Please briefly explain why you want a website and how it will benefit your business.

8. Do you have a deadline for getting the new website live?

9. If you were looking for your business in a search engine (e.g. Google) what words/phrases would you search for?

10. Do you have a domain name in mind or already registered? (e.g. http://www.mywebsite.com)

11. Do you already have an idea of what you want your website to look like - can you provide images/examples?

12. What different web pages do you want to have on your site? (see List of pages attachment)

13. Are you able to provide all the content (text and images etc.) for the different pages of your site or would you like me to provide the content?

14. Are you able to provide us with high quality images to be used on your website or would you like me to provide the images?

15. Do you want to include any links/feeds from social networking sites?

16. Do you want to include share/like buttons for the popular social networking pages on each page or on specific pages of your site?

17. Please detail anything that you specifically do not want to have on your website.

18. How often will your site be updated and do you need to be able to make frequent updates yourself (training will be provided)? Do you prefer that I do all the updates?

19. Please list any email addresses you want me to setup with your website and indicate which one(s) to publish on the website and use for any contact forms etc.

20. Do you need your website to be bilingual?









[Web App hosted by Google]

parent nodes: General

Web App hosted by Google

[camelCaseWordsEnabled: false]

Application on Google Developer: https://avid-system-783.appspot.com/
app-id: avid-system-783

Problem of various devices sizes is solved by Cloud Endpoints

Tools needed:
- Java jdk 1.7
- Apache Maven
- Eclipse EE

Open an existing Maven projects

1. In Eclipse, go to file > Import > Maven > Existing Maven Project
2. Select the whole folder where the project is located
3. Click Finish

To run the project locally

1. Right click the project name > Run as > Run Configuration
2. Select Maven Build and click on New Configuration
3. Base Directory: ${project_loc}
4. Goals: appengine:devserver
5. Make sure Maven external is selected in Maven Runtime
6. Run!
7. It'll take a while but once everything is compiled and running, you can now access your webapp at localhost:8080 from Chrome

To run from the server

First you must ensure that your app-ID is filled properly in src > main > WEB-INF > appengine-web.xml (app-id can be found in https://console.developers.google.com/project

1. Right click the project name > Run as > Run Configuration
2. Select Maven Build and click on New Configuration
3. Base Directory: ${project_loc}
4. Goals: appengine:update
5. Make sure Maven external is selected in Maven Runtime
6. Run!
7. It'll take a while but once everything is compiled and running, you can now access your webapp at http://Project ID.appspot.com from Chrome


In web.xml, you see these lines of code:
    <security-constraint>
      <web-resource-collection>
        <web-resource-name>all</web-resource-name>
        <url-pattern>/*</url-pattern>
      </web-resource-collection>
      <user-data-constraint>
        <transport-guarantee>CONFIDENTIAL</transport-guarantee>
      </user-data-constraint>
      </security-constraint>
Which means that https will be used.

Purpose of the various files:
- web.xml: Web App Config
- pom.xml: Maven dependencies
- appengine-web.xml: AppEngine Config

When you see a file that starts with @Api([...] that meanst this file is using Endpoints
By default, a function inside a file that starts with @Api is exposed through endpoints

Endpoints cant return string ojects, they have to return objects with fields.

To view the api explorer: http://localhost:8080/_ah/api/explorer
Datastore admin: https://appengine.google.com
Application on Google Developer: https://avid-system-783.appspot.com/
app-id: avid-system-783

From there you can actually run any functions found in your web app just by clicking on it

Creating maven project from archetype

1. Go to command line
2. Navigate to a place where you want your project to reside
3. Type "mvn archetype:generate" (without the double-quotes)
4. The list will be huge so you can actually filter (for example, type endpoints)
5. Choose archetype: 2
    Choose a number: 3
    groupID: com.google.training
    artifacId: training
    version Id: [null] (meaning, don't type anything!)
    com.google.training: [null] (meaning, don't type anything!)
    Y: Y
6. Go to Eclipse to import the project

First time you run a project, you might have to go in Windows > Preference > Java > Installed JRE and just deselect and reselect and click OK. That's what you should do if you get the error: No compiler is provided in this environment. Perhaps you are running on a JRE rather than a JDK?

Endpoints are usually located in files in a folder called spi.


- You can restrict the input that goes into the API by passing the object as an argument in the API function
- An API can take a user object as an argument. If the object is not null, that means the user is signed in, otherwise he isn't.

Example: public saveProfile(final User user, ProfileForm profileForm) throws UnauthorizedException {...}

Data store

What is data store?
- Database running in the Google cloud (built on "Big Table")
- Key-value, column-oriented (NOT RDBMS)
- Create Google-scale applications
- Highly available and reliable

Datastore modelling
- Kind
- Entity
- Property

Kind is similar to the concept of classes in OO programming, or a table in RDBMS
Entities are similar to the concept of "object" on OO programming, or a row in RDBMS
Properties are similar to fields/objects/attributes, or colum in RDBMS

One kind has one or more entities and each entity has one or more properties. The above are not DIRECT analogies though.

Property types:
- integer
- float
- string
- date
- binary data
- ...
https://cloud.google.com/appengine/docs/java/datastore/entities#Java_Properties_and_value_types

Creating an entity

1. add these in the imports:
import com.googlecode.objectify.annotation.Entity;
import com.googlecode.objectify.annotation.Id;

2. add @Entity at the top of the document but after the import

3. each entity must have one and only one Id (@Id). An Id can be of the type: Long, long or String.

4. Optional: @Index: Indexing properties to speed up the search

5. Optional: @Parent: Ancestor relationship

Example:
import com.googlecode.objectify.annotation.Entity;
import com.googlecode.objectify.annotation.Id;

@Entity
public class Profile {
    @Id String userId;
    String displayName;
    String mainEmail;
    TeeShirtSize teeShirtSize;
...}

Datastore keys

Can be generated two different ways:
- Autogenerated by the datastore
    Ex: Key <Conference> key = factory().allocateId(Conference.class);
    Or, if there is a parent: Key <Conference> key = factory().allocateId(parentKey, Conference.class);
- Specified

Saving Data with objectify

ObjectifyService.ofy().save().entity(entity).now();
it is standard to simplify it like this: ofy().save().entity(entity).now(); //rename the 2nd entity

Read data from datastore

ofy.load();
You can query by key or by criteria.

Entity entity = ofy().load().key(key).now();

Example:
String userId = user.getUserId();
Key key = Key.create(Profile.class, userId);
Profile profile = (Profile) ofy().load().key(key).now();

Web UI and Backend API don't have to be in the same application, they could be in two completely separate applications. You could also have several Web UI using the same Backend API. In our case, the backend and the Web UI are in the same application. However, the appengine doesn't care that they are together. You still have to authorize the UI to access the backend.

So you need to set your client ID either in the API or in the constants, depending how the project is set up. Your client ID can be found in Google Developer Console > API & Auth > Credentials.

You also have to identify yourself in app.js (src > main > webapp > js > app.js). This file runs the authentication process when a user logs in. Here you need to fill in the CLIENT_ID again like previous step.

Now we need to add the javascript origin in the Google Developer Console. Go to App & Auth > Credentials. (kind of done already when I created the client ID)

When you use Objectify to define an Entity class, you need to register the Entity class. You do this in a Static method in OfyService. If there is an error message, you might have to mouse over your entity and click "Import".

Relationships

Ancestor: In Datastore, it is possible to specify that an entity has an ancestor.
- Assigned at creation
- Can never be changed
In our example, Created By will be an ancestor of a conference in our example.

Has a:
In our example, we will use this relationship to store the users who are attending the conferences. Each profile will contain a property that contains the conference that they are attending. This relationship can change.

Types of Queries

Showing all conferences = Query by KIND
Showing all conferences created by you = Query by kind filter by ANCESTOR
Showing all conferences you will attend = Query by kind filter by PROPERTY

Get entity by key:
Entity entity = ofy().load().key(key).now();

Get entities of a given kind:
Query query = ofy().load().type(Kind.class);
Query query = ofy().load().type(Kind.class).order("name");
Query query = ofy().load().type(Kind.class).order("name").list();

Get entity of a given kind having a specific ancestor:
Query query = ofy().load().type(Kind.class).ancestor(key);

Query and filter by property:
Query query = ofy().load().type(Kind.class).filter("property and operator", "value");
Query query = ofy().load().type(Conference.class).filter("city =", "London");

To add a filter after the query was created:
Query query = ofy().load().type(Conference.class).order("name");
query = query.filter("city =", "London");

Objectify will assume = as the operator if none is given

Performance of the query only depends on the size of the result set, not on the amount of data stored.

Query restrictions

An inequality filter can be applied to AT MOST one property (but you can have several filters on that same property)
    start_date > June 15 &&
    max_attendees < 100 -> This is NOT a valid query
A property with an inequality filter must be sorted first
    max_attendees < 1000
    sort by Name -> This is NOT a valid query
The best way to avoid the restrictions is to THINK AND PLAN

Indexes

RDBMS Indexes are not the same as Datastore indexes

Datastore indexes are actually REQUIRED to perform a query on data. So if you want to query on certain data, there HAS TO BE an index on that data.

Index value:
Kind / Property / Value
Conference / City / London

Single property indexes such as the one above is also called "Built-in index"

Composite index:
Retrieve all conferences
Filter by City and Topics
Sort by name

This is composite because city, topics and name cannot be combined to generate the result. For this to work, a single table combining different values must be created.

2 ways to build composite indexes:
1. Add index to index file
2. Run application locally (if it encounters a query locally that requires composite index, it will build it automatically and when you deploy to appengine, the new index will now be available)

To look at the index file in Eclipse:
Target > conference 1.0 > WEB-INF > appengine-generated > datastore-index-auto.xml

So instead of deploying to dev all the time before deploying to prod, you could also build your own datastore-index.xml file. Here's what the auto-generated file looks like:

<!-- Indices written at Sun, 7 Dec 2014 10:24:39 CET -->

<datastore-indexes>
    <!-- Used 1 time in query history -->
    <datastore-index kind="Conference" ancestor="false" source="auto">
      <property name="city" direction="asc"/>
      <property name="month" direction="asc"/>
      <property name="topics" direction="asc"/>
      <property name="name" direction="asc"/>
    </datastore-index>
</datastore-indexes>

If you create datastore-index.xml, both datastore-index.xml and datastore-index-auto.xml gets sent to the Google server.

Indexes take up a lot of space so it's better to index ONLY the columns on which you will query.

To index single properties at a time, add @index in front of it.
To index everything inside a class, use @index in front of the class and then @unindex to remove the index from specific properties
You can also add conditional indexing (ex: only index this if the value is greater than 100)
Documentation on partial indexes: https://code.google.com/p/objectify-appengine/wiki/Queries#Partial\_Indexes

Datastore Commit Process

1. Eventual Consistency
2. Strong Consistency

Eventual consistency means that when you ask to enter data in the datastore, the OK is given back to you BEFORE the data is actually fully loaded. So if you send a query to retrieve the data right after you received the ok, the data might not be returned to you right away.

Strong consistency means that the query will notice that some data is still being written, so it will wait for the write operation to be done, and then return the data.

So which is better? It depends on the application. Strong consistency is more accurate but slower. Eventual consistency scales better.

For example:
Blog Comments could be "Eventual Consistency"
ATM Money Withdrawal should be "Stong consistency"

Datastore supports both

Enforcing Strong Consistency is done when you have an Ancestor relationship and you filter by Ancestor. All children will be queries using Strong Consistency.

Transactions

Transactions are used when several transactions must be done together. For example:
- Registering to a conference
- Decreasting the number of seats available

You wrap those two operations in a transaction to ensure that either nothing gets executed if there is a problem or both get executed.

Code for a transaction:

<T> result = ofy().transact(new Work<t>(){
    public <T> run(){
      //do stuff
      return <T>;
    }
});

if you don't wnat the transaction to return anything, you would use new void Work instead of new Work.

Snapshot isolation
- Read returns values at the beginning of the transaction
- Updates will not be reflected while in transaction

Optimistic Concurrency:
- Commit is only successful if the values updated by the transaction have not changed since the beginning of the transaction
- One transaction can modify at most 5 ancestor groups
- A transaction must complete within 60 seconds

Memcache

Memcache is a Memory Cache which sits next to your appengine instances. Any data you store in Memcache can be immediately retrieved without having to make a call to the Datastore. So when you store data in the store, you can also store it in Memcache at the same time. Both datastore and Memcache are shared across any number of instance of your application.

Add @Cache to your entity to automatically use Memcache to store your entity data. Objectify will try its best to use Memcache.

Memcache is only used if you are trying to get an entity by Key, save it or delete it. Query result are NOT cached. Property value are cached. Objectify has its own session cache.

Using the memcache service:
MemcacheService memcacheService = MemcacheServiceFactory.getMemcacheService();

Put something in memcache:
memcacheService.put(key, value);

Get value out of memcache:
<Type> value = memcacheService.get(key);

Servlets

When you use Servlets in a webapp, you need to configure them in web.xml

To trigger the servlet, go to the servlet URL: avid-system-783.appspot.com/crons/set_announcement

Task queues

Tasks queues are meant to take big jobs offline and split them in smaller tasks. They are not executed in the user request thread, so you can immediately return a response to the user.

Push Queues

The execution of Push Queues are managed by appengine itself. That means that appengine has threads that scan the queue and pick up tasks. These thread than call the URL that you have specified when you've entered the task in the queue. The maximum duration of a task is 10 minutes. There are several configuration options for each queues. Configurations are defined in the "Queue configuration file" when you do development.

Configuration items:
- Name
- Maximum Rate
- Enforced Rate
- Bucket Size
- Maximum Concurrent
- Oldest Task
- Tasks in Queue
- Run in Last Minute
- Running

Also lots of parameters around Errors Management

How to create a task and assign it to a queue:
1. Get Queue by name
2. Create task (task name, URL, other params)
3. Add task to queue

Very important to protect the URL

In our example, we will use the queue to send a confirmation e-mail.

Adding tasks to a queue:
1. Define work to be done (in a servlet or endpoint function)
2. Configure queue.xml (if you use the default queue, you actually don't have to do any configuration)

<queue-entry>
    <queue>
      <name>emailqueue</name>
      <rate>l-s</rate>
    </queue>
</queue-entry>

There could be more parameters

3. Write code to add task to queue

Queue queue = QueueFactory.getDefaultQueue();
or
Queue queue = QueueFactory.getQueue("queueName");

queue.add(TaskOptions.Builder.withUrl("url_for_task").param("param1").param("param2"));
or
queue.add(transaction, TaskOptions.Builder.withUrl("url_for_task").param("param1").param("param2"));
ofy.getTransaction()

4. If you use all the default options, a task is going to stay stuck in the queue until it succeeds, so it's important to test your queues to make sure that no task get stuck in there that is never going to finish.

Pull queues

Humans actually pull tasks from the queues to work on them (for example, approving comments before they get posted on the site.) Tasks can be "leased" for a certain time. If it is not completed by the time the lease is over, it is automatically returned to the queue.

Caracteristics:
- No URL
- Tasks are leased
- Explicit delete (worker must delete the task when completed)
- Automatic return if task is not completed
- REST interface
- No default queue (you must create it)

Cron jobs

- Schedule tasks regularly
- Perfect to perform background tasks not directly initiated by user activity (ex. backups)
- Easy to configure:
    - URL
    - Schedule
- 10 minutes limit for dynamic instances, if you want more, you would need resident instances

Cron jobs are configured in cron.xml. Example:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<cronentries>
    <cron>
      <url>/crons/set_announcement</url>
      <description>Repopulate the announcement every 1 hour</description>
      <schedule>every 1 hours</schedule> => Must follow a certain format otherwise it won't work
    </cron>
</cronentries>

Scheduling cron tasks https://developers.google.com/appengine/docs/java/config/cron#Java\_appengine\_web\_xml\_About\_cron\_xml
Schedule format: https://developers.google.com/appengine/docs/java/config/cron#Java\_appengine\_web\_xml\_The\_schedule\_format

If you want to cancel your job, it is not enough to delete cron.xml and reupload your app, you actually have to set up a new cron.xml with no cron entries:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<cronentries>
</cronentries>
</cronentries>

Modules

- Code partitioning
- Scalability Control
- Version control and online upgrades

Applications can have several modules, and modules include:
- Code
- Instance class
- Scalability

Each module can then have several versions of your code.

This allow you to do version upgrades without bringing down your application

And finally each version can have several instances.

Two types of scaling:
- Manual
    - Instances always up and running
    - No 10 minutes limit on background tasks and cron jobs
    - Must configure the number of instances
- Automatic
    - Can specify min/max idle instances (instances have a startup time)
    - Can specify min/max pending latency (so how long appengine waits for an instance to become free before it just starts a brand new instance)
Instance classes:
- Speed of CPU
- Amount of memory

Appstats

Function to allow you to get extensive information about how API functions are called by your app.

- Profile application
- Inspect API Calls
    - Minimize latency by caching data
    - Reduce / bundle calls
    - Reduce costs
- Enable tracing through configuration
- Access profiling information using URL

Documentation: https://developers.google.com/appengine/docs/java/tools/appstats

To use AppStats with Maven, you have to add additional dependence to your pom.xml file. This is in addition to the steps described in AppStats documentation, as this is Maven specific step.

After following the AppStats install guide found in the link above, add the following code in pom.xml under <dependencies>:
    <dependency>
      <groupId>com.google.appengine</groupId>
      <artifactId>appengine-api-labs</artifactId>
      <version>${appengine.target.version}</version>
    </dependency>
Edge caching

1. Set cache-control header in http response (only if the response will be the same every time)
2. Define as much content as possible as being static (in configuration files)

Even by doing these two options, you cannot guarantee that edge caching will be used, but if it is, the response to the user will be MUCH faster.

To create a mobile app

You need to generate the client library for your Endpoints API so that you can include the library in your mobile application.

You'll need to know:

The package name of the classes in your mobile app
The SHA1 fingerprint of your mobile app
Getting the SHA1 fingerprint of your mobile app

When you build an Android App in debug mode, the SDK automatically creates a debug key and signs the application. You can also generate a new key.

To generate a new key, you'll need to specify the keystore name and keystore alias.

Generating a new key

keytool -genkey -v -keystore keystore-name.keystore -alias keystore-alias -keyalg RSA -keysize 2048 -validity 1000
Enter a password and remember it!
Answer the questions (such as what is your first and last name)
Say yes for the the last question.
It's OK for the password for the keystore alias to be the same as the keystore password.
To create the client Id for the Android app, you'll need the SHA1 fingerprint.

Getting the SHA1 fingerprint

keytool -exportcert -alias keystore-alias -keystore keystore-name.keystore -list -v
Enter password.
Copy and save the SHA1 value, (don't include "SHA1:") for example: 04:E7:79:66:CD...C7:41
Creating the Client ID

Create your mobile client ID in the Developers Console.

Go to APIS & Auth > Credentials. Click Create New Client Id.
Choose Installed application.
Select Android.
Enter the package name of the classes in your Android app.
Copy in the SHA1 fingerprint.
You can leave DEEP LINKING disabled.
Click Create Client ID.
Add the new Android Client ID to the clientIDs list in the @Api annotation in the Java class containing the endpoint functions.
Generate the Client Library for the Endpoints API

You need to generate the client library that contains your Endpoints API so you can include it in your mobile app.

For Android Apps:

In a terminal window, cd to the library containing the pom.xml for your application.
mvn appengine:endpoints_get_client_lib
cd to the target directory.
cd to endpoints-client-libs
cd conference
mvn install
cd to the target folder
Add the client library jar appname-v1-1.n.n-rc-SNAPSHOT.jar to the project for your mobile application.
If you change your backend API, you'll need to update the client library.

Changes to the Conference Central code

In general, when you create an application that uses Endpoints, the code to define the endpoints is the same regardless of whether the endpoints are used by a web app or an Android app. However, when the Android app injects the user into an endpoints API call, the User object does not include the userId. In our Conference Central app we have used the userId to uniquely identify the logged-in user, and obviously this won't work for Android users. So we have defined a class AppEngineUser that compensates for the lack of the userId in Android Users.

You will need to:

Add the AppEngineUser class to your Conference Central Java project .

(To be clear, add it to the app that defines the endpoints, not the Android app).

You can find the AppEngineUser class in the Lesson 6 folder.

Add the definition of private static String getUserId(User user) to ConferenceApi.

You can find it in the file extra code for ConferenceApi.txt in the Lesson 6 folder.

In ConferenceApi, change each occurrence of: user.getUserId(); to getUserId(user)

Problems

1. If there are problems that don't make sense, try to delete the Target directory and compile again.

2. We now have test data, you may want to go in run configuration to check "skip test"

3. If you delete the "target" folder, right click on your project and do Maven > Update Project before you run it (you might have to do that a few times?)

4. Under target > surefire-reports, you will have a report of the errors

5. 500 error, run your app first on dev and THEN move it to Google. It will not work until the index is finished preparing (check status in google dev console > Storage > Cloud Datastore > Indexes)

6. List must be imported as java.util (not java.awt)









[Website Checklist]

parent nodes: General

Website Checklist

[camelCaseWordsEnabled: false]

FAVICON

TITLES AND META DATA (Make sure it changes on every page and relates to that page’s content.)

<title>10 Things To Consider When Choosing The Perfect CMS | How-To | Smashing Magazine</title>
<meta name="description" content="By Paul Boag Choosing a content management system can be tricky. Without a clearly defined set of requirements, you will be seduced by fancy functionality that you will never use. What then should you look" />

CROSS-BROWSER CHECKS

PROOFREAD

LINKS

FUNCTIONALITY CHECK

GRACEFUL DEGRADATION

Your website should work with JavaScript and/or Flash turned off. Users often have JavaScript turned off for security, so you should be prepared for this. You can easily turn off JavaScript in Firefox. Test your forms to make sure they still perform server-side validation checks, and test any cool AJAX stuff you have going on.

VALIDATION

You should aim for a 100% valid website. That said, it isn’t the end of the world if your website doesn’t validate, but it’s important to know the reasons why it doesn’t so that you can fix any nasty errors. Common gotchas include no “alt” tags, no closing tags and using “&” instead of “&” for ampersands.
http://validator.w3.org/

RSS LINK

If your website has a blog or newsreel, you should have an RSS feed that users can subscribe to. Users should be able to easily find your RSS feed: the common convention is to put a small RSS icon in the browser’s address bar.
Put this code between your <head> tags.
<link rel="alternate" type="application/rss+xml" title="Site or RSS title" href="link-to-feed" />

ANALYTICS

SITEMAP

Adding a sitemap.xml file to your root directory allows the major search engines to easily index your website. The file points crawlers to all the pages on your website. XML-Sitemaps automatically creates a sitemap.xml file for you. After creating the file, upload it to your root directory so that its location is www.mydomain.com/sitemap.xml.

If you use WordPress, install the Google XML Sitemaps plug-in, which automatically updates the sitemap when you write new posts. Also, add your website and sitemap to Google Webmaster Tools. This tells Google that you have a sitemap, and the service provides useful statistics on how and when your website was last indexed.

DEFENSIVE DESIGN

The most commonly overlooked defensive design element is the 404 page. If a user requests a page that doesn’t exist, your 404 page is displayed. This may happen for a variety of reasons, including another website linking to a page that doesn’t exist. Get your users back on track by providing a useful 404 page that directs them to the home page or suggests other pages they may be interested in.

Another defensive design technique is checking your forms for validation. Try submitting unusual information in your form fields (e.g. lots of characters, letters in number fields, etc.) and make sure that if there is an error, the user is provided with enough feedback to be able to fix it.

OPTIMIZE
Optimize speed, images, minify js and css...
Consider using: http://requirejs.org/

BACK UP
If your website runs off a database, you need a back-up strategy. Or else, the day will come when you regret not having one. If you use WordPress, install WordPress Database Backup, which you can set up to automatically email you backups. Configure backup schedule, and test recovery from backup.

PRINT STYLE SHEET
If a user wants to print a page from your website, chances are she or he wants only the main content and not the navigation or extra design elements. That’s why it is a good idea to create a print-specific style sheet. Also, certain CSS elements, such as floats, don’t come out well when printed.

To point to a special CSS style sheet that computers automatically use when users print a page, simply include the following code between your <head> tags.

<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="print.css" media="print" />

COLOUR CONTRAST
Use http://www.vischeck.com/ to simulate colorblind vision

SEARCH

Test the Search functionality



Extra
Configure Google Webmaster Console and Yahoo! Site Explorer
FeedBurner?
Use robots.txt where necessary?
Set-up email/SMS monitoring/alerts (e.g. for errors, server warnings); consider internal and external monitoring services
Check correct database indexing


‘Click here for the latest company news’ becomes ‘Latest company news’
‘Buy now’ becomes ‘Buy 4 socket extension cable now’
‘More info’ becomes ‘More info on our product range’

Do not have a set of navigational links that is any larger than 8 items

Avoid placing important navigation at the top. While scanning pages, which is the way the huge majority of web users use the Internet, they blank out anything they don’t recognise, know they don’t want or that looks like advertising – which they have come to expect in the top part of the page

Place legals (copyright notice, privacy policy, terms and conditions) at the bottom of all web pages where they are typically found, but you should also draw them to users’ attention by including links within content where it is timely for them to be read

Home should be the first link. Any site/company logo and image in the top left corner should also be a link to home to follow web convention

Don’t make the mistake of deciding on the top level navigation before you have created a site map for the whole site

Include a search and site map if your site has many pages. Note that some users have learned searching gets them to the info they seek quicker than browsing and look for a search box, rather than at navigation, as soon as they come to a new website

Unless you have a very small, simple site, plan to include a ‘You are here’ navigation before the page title (i.e. show the user where they are in the site). Also show what step they’re on of how many, in stepped interactions such as making a purchase

Minimise the amount of links on the page, keep it under 20

Decide how you would like to lead users through the site and identify a key link – calls to action work well as buttons aligned to the right of the main content

Are links labeled with anchor text that provides a clear indication of where they lead without over using exact match anchor text?

Is there a clear statement of PURPOSE of the site? Purpose must be clear within a few seconds.

Do you have clear call to action on each page?

Is text broken into small, readable chunks and highlighted using headings, sub-headings, and emphasis features where appropriate to assist in skimming?

Are private directories password protected via .htaccess?

Is customer data stored online? If so, is this database appropriately safeguarded against external access?

Privacy Policy up (especially if you collect data, email, names, and web analytics tracking cookies)?









[Writing for the Web]

parent nodes: General

Writing for the Web

[camelCaseWordsEnabled: false]

3 things to keep in mind when writing for the web

1 - Make it easy to find
    Unique, useful content
    Keywords that users are familiar with
    Keywords in both body and title
    Identify and write for audience
2 - Make it easy to scan
    Organize content to meet users needs
    Think through questions users will ask
    Chronological organization
    General first, then exception, conditions and other special info
    Limit levels to 3-4
    Address separate audiences separately
    Chunky content (short sections with breaks)
3 - Make it easy to understand
    Familiar words instead of jargon
    Short, simple sentences
    Active voice, write in the second person
    Avoid idioms like "belt-tightening"
    Avoid acronyms or abbreviations, unless all your readers know and use them
    Skip fluff, wastes user's time
    Use contractions, keep do not when it's important to make a point
    Address one person, not a group. You're only speaking to one person at a time.
    Use tables
    Use illustrations and graphics
Traps
    Don't post content online without "translating" it for the web
    You're not writing the next Globe & Mail best seller
    Don't use all caps or underlined text
    Don't use cross reference
Info, cheatsheets and exercises: 4syllables.com.au/resources

Simple English Wikipedia can help to simplify









[Google Analytics]

parent nodes: WebDesign

Google Analytics

[camelCaseWordsEnabled: false]

When creating account

Benchmarking is, you're going to contribute your data to this anonymous benchmark, such that you can see those benchmarks back yourself and how you compare to those.

Analytics

Not only how visitors are reaching your site, but how to evaluate the VALUE of each of those visitors.
Exactly how your visitors are interacting with, and using your site's content.
Track all of your marketing with Google Analytics
Identify areas of your site that perform well and those that don't

Modern business intelligence and digital analytics tools give us the ability to collect a staggering amount of data. We want to take that raw data, organize it into something that we can use, something actionable and something that has importance to us and meaning to us as people. What we really care about, is the performance of the content and how the visitors are interacting with the site. Which marketing channels are driving business? Which devices are my users using?

Web Analytics is the study of online behaviour in order to improve it - Wikipedia

Analytic software is like an x-ray machine. In this case, the patient is your website and the x-ray machine is Google Analytics. The tool, will identify and display exactly what's going on under the skin of your website, much like this x-ray will detect and display the broken bones. However, it won't end your pain and it won't ultimately fix your problem. For that you're going to need someone who can actually read and interpret the x-ray, and perform the analysis necessary to actually take action and improve the situation. Analytics alone is NOT ENOUGH.

Assess situation
Prioritize problems
Find solutions

Constantly analyzing, adjusting, improving and optimizing.

Web Analytics is a process and set it and forget it has no place here. We first perform the measurement, we apply analysis and we learn from what we see. And then we take action. Our site is constantly changing, our marketing is changing, the tools themselves are changing, and the devices in which we access that online content, are rapidly and continually changing. We need to make sure our Analytics process doesn't become stale, but rather evolves and keeps up with those changes, in order to ensure our site is always performing at its best.

Goals

Goals are what will allow us to evaluate quality traffic from poor performing traffic.

Goals are a fundamental concept of any analytics package, and without goals, you have nothing more than a fancy hit counter. In other words, in order for us to say that site A is sending you much more valuable traffic than site B, we need some criteria to base that on, and that's where goals come in.

There's high performing traffic, low performing traffic, and everything in between. In order to analyze which sources and types of traffic are valuable, we need to track what those visitors are doing when they're on the site, what content works, how they're using the site, and ultimately figure out how to segment them and understand why they're doing what they're doing. Finally, we're going to measure how many folks and which segments of those people reach that final step and convert. Whether it's putting money in your bank account, or filling that lead-gen form, we get to tell our analytics package exactly what we consider a successful visit by setting a goal.

One very important point about goals is not to overlook intermediate goals, sometimes known as micro conversions. We're often so focused on that last step, such as a shopping cart checkout, that we forget about all the factors in between that contribute to the sale and get them to take that next step

1. Attract traffic
    - Paid ads
    - Organic searches
    - Email marketing
    - Offline marketing
2. Track Action
    - Add item to shopping cart
    - Fill out a form
    - Download coupons
    - Find a phone number
3. Measure conversion
    - Completing a sale
    - Completing a form
You can set up a maximum of 20 goals per view. If you need more goals, you can always create another view. Goals have their own section in Google Analytics under Conversions.

Configuring Goals

One important configuration is that we can actually assign a monetary value to a goal. This allows us to get revenue, without having to have a full blown e-commerce setup. And the idea here is that if you know a particular goal's estimated to be worth a certain amount to you, and each time a visitor reaches that goal, Google Analytics is actually going to attribute that revenue to that visitor and all the segments with it. So, the landing page, the source, the medium, all the things associated with that visitor.

Why do you have a website?
- E-commerce
- Support
- Call us
- Mailing list
- Information
- Affiliates / Ads
- Human Resources
- Lead Generation

1. Go to the website
2. Do the full steps of a succesful visit
3. Copy every single URL along the way
4. Go into Google Analytics > Admin > View > Goals > New goal
5. Fill all the information, now make sure that you don't copy the full URL but only the URI: /calendar/
    Feel free to use regular expression if need be: /calendar/|/fr/calendrier/
6. Fill the funnel if that makes sense (different steps leading to the end result). Make sure you do not put the goal destination as a funnel step.

If you do conduct transactions online, one of the most important goals you'll want to measure, is the goal of collecting money, and there's a whole set of reports dedicated to just that topic. To get the info from these reports, you do need to integrate Google Analytics with your shopping cart, so your shopping cart, or check out software, will send all the data with the results of those transactions, back to Google servers

Goal Reports

Reverse goal path report:
This report shows us some a unique navigation path that was used to complete the goal. This is an interesting report because it compares what our predicted path might be. Something we would set up in a funnel, where we predict what it's going to be with what the user actually did. So, unlike funnels, that start with the beginning pages, and work towards the end conversion, this actually starts with the goal and works backwards to see where the most common paths are.

Averages

Misinformation is often worse than no information. Averages can lie. Even if the underlying data is 100% accurate. For example, if your feet are frozen and your head is on fire, on average, you're doing fine.

Most often, the real insights lie when we can segment out groups of visitors and understand their behaviour. Then we can see who's really driving the success.

Segmentation

Segmentation is the first step in true analysis. And we have tons and tons of ways to segment visitors in Google Analytics

Type of segmentation:
1. Geographic locations
2. Traffic sources
3. Site actions
4. Offline traffic sources
5. Intent (keywords typed in search engine can give insight)
6. Landing page
7. Browser

And thus the ability to segment by landing page can be quite revealing. In fact, simply splitting the site into two groups, those who reached our goals versus those who didn't. Just as examining successes or failures in any aspect of life is useful, examining successful and unsuccessful visitors to our website can give us insight into how we can optimize and improve. If you're split testing your ads, you’ll want to understand how the segments that saw one ad performed versus another.

Now beyond just mobile versus desktop, we can also get detail reports that tell us about things like, connection speed, screen resolution, and other segmentation information that will help us design sites, that are optimal for our user base.

Trends and context

Take this example:

Source Goal convertion
Google.com 28.90%
Answers.com 94.1%

Answers.com looks much better but if we add more data:

Source Goal convertion Number of visits
Google.com 28.90% 80 427
Answers.com 94.1% 17

Now google.com is much better.

Always analyze your Analytics in context of external factors. Example: conversion is better on a sunny day then during hurricane.

Accidental competition: Other companies or organizations that share the same name or keywords online (example: Hilton hostel in Paris vs. Paris Hilton)

Let's say you have a trend in your business where Mondays have better conversion than other days of the week. If you then compare an e-mail campaign that runs on a Monday vs an e-mail campaign that runs on a Sunday, the Monday campaign has a better chance of success and we may then conclude the wrong thing, just because we didn't take the trends into account. Most trends are more than just days of the week, but seasonal as well.

Understanding trends will allow us to compare apples to apples by controlling for those external factors, and keeping our data in context

How does Google Analytics work

Now the way Google Analytics works is based on the current generation of web analytics tools and has a very important difference from the older log file based systems in that it cuts out the web server logs, almost entirely from that process. When the web server returns the page back to your browser, it has some embedded JavaScript which is actually the code that runs Google Analytics. That Google Analytics code snippet collects information from your browser, and sends it directly to Google's powerful data centers. Now in addition to that JavaScript that runs in that standard web browser, we can also have that data sent back by mobile apps, and now even non-computer devices like coffee makers and virtually anything that can put the data in the right format.

The data is sent back to Google by what's known as the Measurement Framework. All that data is collected from those devices and visitors and ultimately stored in large databases. When you and I go log into Google Analytics, we open up the reporting database that's connected to those databases. When you think about it, your browser sends all the data to Google. And it actually has almost nothing to do with your web server that hosts your site, other than the fact that your site has that JavaScript snippet included as part of the page that it serves up. Depending on how much traffic you have, and the type of Google Analytics account you have, there can be a wide variance in how long it takes from the time a visitor sees the web page, until the data from that visit shows up in our reports.

Views

You can create up to 25 views. At least each Web property should have 3 different views:
- Main view where you do the majority of your analysis
- Test view where you can test new filters, make mistakes, etc.
- Raw, unfiltered view

The data is stored in the property, not in the views

Other possible views:
- Internal traffic.
- AdWords traffic.
- Specific people who work in the organization.
- Specific tests that we are running

To create views: Admin > Drop-down under view, create a new view

Interface

The standard reporting tab includes all the built-in reports for this particular view.

Left menu:
1. Dashboards
2. Shortcuts
3. Intelligence Events
4. Real Time: shows what's happening on your site right now.
5. Audience: includes reports about Demographics, Behavior, Technology, Geography and Mobile.
6. Acquisition: includes reports broken down by medium and other campaign data, reports that are dedicated to search engine optimization and advertising, which will show multiple reports specific to AdWords. And if you've linked AdWords and Google Analytics accounts together, you'll get even more data there.
7. Behaviour: gives you details about the performance of your content, the engagement with your content and the site's search reports. If you configure Google Analytics to work with an internal site search box that you have on your website, you'll see that data here.
8. Conversion: houses information about Goals you've set up, e-commerce, if you've enabled that for your profile, and multi-channel funnel reports to give you greater insights into how users find your sites over time, even over multiple visits.

In the mid pane you have a graph which you can add a second metric on (next to vs.) You can change the time period on the right. For some reports, you can add individual rows by selecting them and clicking "plot rows".

To compare two date ranges, go to the very top where you have your date range, click on it and select "Compare to". Sometimes it makes much more sense to change the date range slightly so that you are comparing a Monday with a Monday... When comparing one month vs another, make sure you compare the same amount of days especially if comparing amounts (total number of visitors, total revenue, etc.) Also keep in mind # of holidays in a month.

To add an annotation to the graph, click on the arrow under the graph. You can tell that there is a note by the icon on the date itself. You must have the permission of Collaborate or above on the entire view to be able to modify or add shared notes, but you can always add your own private ones.

Audience Reports

The reports under the Audience tab give us the most sought after information about the number and type of visitors as well as some basic information about the nature of their visit.

One of the most illuminating segments to consider about our visitors, is simply where they're from, geographically speaking when they visit our site

Audience > Geo reports

We can also move to E-commerce tab and we can see metrics that are related to commerce themselves, if they're enabled in this particular profile. You can get this information from Audience > Geo > Location. If looking at the US, you will notice that your map looks very similar in colours to a map from the sensus of population density. So this map report doesn't tell you much if you look at it as "number of sessions". More populous states will obviously have more sessions. But this map report can become more interesting if you look at it using other metrics such as "average amount of time people spend on the site" (avg. session duration), or e-commerce conversation rate.

You must realize that the geographic location report is not 100% accurate (due to network, VPN, etc.)

The language report is also very enlightening. If you see a language code you don't recognize, you can look it up here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_ISO_639-1_codes This language code comes from the browser. The language report isn't one you're going to access daily, but it can be very useful when you're trying to answer specific questions.

Audience > Behavior Reports

Thinking of your website users as "dates" is a good analogy. If you treat returning visitors every time as if it was their first time, or if you treat first-time visitors as if they've known you for years, things are likely not going to work very well. So it makes sense to analyze Analytics data in segments of "first visit" vs "returning visitor" and compare how the site is performing for both groups.

Google Analytics track first visit vs. returning visitors through cookies. Which means that if the same person uses a different browser, they will be tracked as a new visitor. If you delete your cookies in the browser, you will also be tracked as a new visitor. Same thing for incognito browsing or private browsing windows. Same as well for visitors who visit from work and then from home.

You can find this new vs. returning information in the report under Audience > Behaviour > New vs. returning. For this report, the graph only shows you the total for both new vs. returning so here it makes sense to go in the data table, select both new and returning and click the button "Plot Rows" to see totals, new AND returning in the graph. It also makes sense to turn on the pie chart.

New Vs. Returning is not 100% accurate, and looking at returning visitors as one big group isn't entirely accurate either. To further segment the returning visitors, you can look at the report Audience > Behaviour > Frequency and Recency report, which gives us an idea of how many times users are coming back to the site. If you see big numbers at the bottom of the charts where it counts people that have done 100+ visits, this may be because of the employees of the organization that visit the site on a daily basis. You can also look at the section "Days since last session" in the same report, but keep in mind that over 30 days, it is more likely that users have gotten rid of their cookies, changed computers, etc.

The next report in this section is the Engagement report. And the session duration metric is a highly illuminating report, because it exposes just how misleading these averages can be, and it's pretty well known within user experience circles that most people spend less than ten seconds on a given page, which is backed up by this data. For example, in the Overview report, you may have seen that the average session is 1 minute 23 seconds whereas the vast majority of users only spend 10 seconds on the site. Don't rely too much on averages! And that means that this Engagement report can be very revealing of the true situation of a website.

A new visit starts any time you either open a new web browser, or let 30 minutes lapse, since the last page you saw on that site. So if you go have lunch, come back to your browser to the same website you were on earlier, that will be counted as a second visit to the site.

Audience > Technology Reports

Browser & OS Report: Contains a few individual reports in different tabs about browsers, Operating Systems, screen resolution, screen colors, flash version and Java support. Using this report on the browser tab, you can go to the goal section to find out if one of the browser has suspiciously low activities to find out if your website is working on all browsers.

I haven't seen a client yet interested in the colour report.

Audience > Mobile Reports

Mobile devices are becoming increasingly important in the web analytics world. In Google Analytics, we have two reports to help us analyze mobile web traffic. The first of these is the mobile overview report. This report allows us to quickly isolate different types of mobile traffic, and evaluate that traffic against things like total sessions, bounce rate, revenue generated, and so on. Now if we use the Plot Rows functionality, we can see how each type of mobile, so phone and tablet, stacks up against desktop.

Devices report: Here we can evaluate mobile traffic by the device that's used

We can even get a picture of each device. So if you can't remember if the Nexus 4 was a smart phone or a tablet, you can just click this little camera icon here to launch a picture of the device and you can see if it was or wasn't. We can also look at the devices rolled up to the brand of the phone manufactures, Apple and Samsung and Nokia, et cetera. We can also look at things like the different service providers. So here we're going to see whether it's Verizon, Comcast, Sprint, Nextel. We can even look at things like whether or not the device has a touchscreen, we click here in the mobile input selector, it's going to tell us if it's a, stylus based phone like the Palm Pre was, or even a click wheel phone like the Blackberries.

Audience > User Flow

Earlier, I said that the acquisition report was my go to report for new clients, because it gives me such an efficient backgrounder. But this interactive report might just take the crown as my favorite to use. Here's a report, that combines the content navigation, entrance and exits reports, and funnels, all in one, and at the same time, it leverages all of our campaign data, and custom segmentation. In this report, the pages of your site are represented by the green boxes over on the right, known as nodes. Visitors and paths and the trends that they take through the site, are represented by these individual lines, which we can actually highlight by clicking on one of them. Starting pages are actually the landing pages. From there, we can see how many visitors moved on, from their landing page, to another page on the site, which page, and we can see how many of them left the site entirely and dropped off, after visiting a particular page.

The number of visitors that left the website, after reviewing the page, are represented by the red bar on the right-hand side. This is a visual representation of the percentage of visitors that abandon the site, and don't move on any further. Now, above the red bar, for the visitors that didn't drop off, we can see through the lines where they moved on to. And we can click on any one of these lines, to highlight the traffic through that particular path, and see all the people who came to this point, where they originally came from, and then where they went as they moved on, including, where did they eventually drop off. Now, if we're to go back on the first column here and click on any one of the dimension nodes, we can also highlight the traffic through that particular country.

If we only have interest in a particular country, we can click the second option "view only this segment". At that point, it's going to clear away all the other ones and just show us the segment that we're currently interested in.

Now another good tip, is that on any individual nodes, I can click on it, and I can select Group Details. From here, we're going to see a table with different metrics about the pages that are included here. The top page is, is thereby default, but we can also change this drop-down to see things like the traffic breakdown, which is going to show that, the various counties that came through this page. And even things like the outgoing traffic, which shows where they went, after they came through this page.

One any of the pages, you can click on the node and click "Explore traffic through here". Click on the plus on either side to understand where people came from prior to go to that page and where they went after. You can use the zoom to see some parts better.

When you "Explore traffic through here", there is an edit button on the main page and you can change the expression used if you wish. Then, by clicking the node again and clicking group detail, you can see all the pages that are now included in that node.

Acquisition tab reports

If I could pick only one tab to do all my work, it would be the Acquisition tab. Whenever I examine a client's account for the first time, these reports are the first place I go

Overview: Google Analytics is going to split up all of our traffic into a few default buckets that we can see here in the overview report, where we've got a nice graphical overview that's going to give you a pretty valuable bird's eye view of the sources of traffic that drive your site

Channels Report: Now, anyone who's serious about the website, should be able to immediately answer questions such as what is your best performing source of traffic? What is your worse? Which channel or medium sends you the most traffic? Which channel gets you the best bang for your buck? And even questions like, how is your offline marketing comparing to your online sources? All of those are easy, once you get the hang of making this report work for you.

Acquisition > Channels

My favourite report and this is the first one I'm going to go to if I get a new client because it provides so much information about the current state of the site and how they generate, engage, and convert their traffic in one convenient report. So we have all the traffic segmented into these rows, known as Dimensions on the Left. They represent the way the visitor came to the site. On the other side, the columns are known as Metrics

New users: tell us about the traffic we are acquiring during the acquisition section.
Duration of the visit: average session duration, this is going to speak about the behaviour once they're on the site.
Goal completions: tell us whether or not they converted.

This tabular format presents a lot of data, but for us humans it's not particularly easy to remember, compare, interpret information when it's just a bunch of numbers in a big table. So you can view this data in pie chart, graph etc. by clicking on the buttons next to the search field. The icon comparison is going to be comparing the current numbers with the site average. Each of these bars are relative to the site average, so if the bar is on the right-hand side, it's performing worse than average, on the left hand side, better than average (for bouce rate for example). So you can compare the quality of your traffic, for example two sources of traffic may bring the same amount of people but one of them might have a good bounce rate while the other not so much.

This quantity and quality combination is just such a critical point that I want to emphasize. In these two columns we have the two critical things we need to know. We need to know how it's performing overall, but we also need the number of visits to know what it is in the context of the volume. After all, somebody has a great bounce rate, but it only brings one or two visits. It isn't necessarily something that's important to me as a site owner

A good bounce rate can be correlated directly to our revenue and other performance indicators. A lower bounce rate is good.

You can also look at this report by pivoting, last icon. Pivot by city for example.

Acquisition > All Traffic

The All Traffic report is very similar to the Channels report in that its goal is to tell you the good, the bad, and the ugly about how traffic gets to your site. Except in the case, instead of grouping it into larger channels, it's more focused on identifying actual, specific sources of traffic. This ability to pinpoint sources of high-quality traffic and separate that from poor-performing traffic sources, is critical to our success.

In general, the all traffic report provides some of the most fundamental information a web analytics package can offer in a simple, easy to adjust, report. Now, these are going to show which sources, which mediums and which campaigns are performing on your site, and perhaps this is important which ones are not.

Acquisition > All referrals

The referring sites is simply a fancy way to describe sites that link to you, or in other words sites that refer traffic to you. Google Analytics has the ability to detect an incoming visit from a link and then it records that link down as the referring site. From then on, anything that is done during that visit including a goal or a transaction, will be credited or attributed back to that referring source.

To find out on which page the referrals are sending the traffic, you can add a secondary dimension of "landing page". Click on a link (like Youtube.com for example) to see the exact referring path. Then if you want to see the exact page, just click on the little icon next to the name in the data table. With this report, you can determine not only who is sending that traffic, but just as importantly, who sends that quality traffic that's going to convert on my particular goals.

Acquisition > Social reports

1. Overview
The Overview starts giving us the overall impact of social to our bottom line. We see these concentric circles aimed to show the part that social plays in the customer journey. The dark blue ones here are where social was the source that led directly to the site visit where their conversion happened. Call that the last click interaction. The light blue above it are the amounts where social contributed somewhere in the funnel, but was not the most recent activity. The other circle is the overall site conversions. And this gives us a sense of how much social does or doesn't contribute to our overall success of the site

2. Network Referrals
We see both the sessions that were referred from a social site against all of our site traffic down here in orange. This allows us to see if there are correlations between the two and some overall patterns. On scrolling down, we see a table of social sites and the metrics that are associated with each including sessions, page views and the standard engagement metrics of time on site and pages per session.

3. Data Hub Activity.
This is going to show us activity on social sites that may never have even hit our site. Twitter and Facebook do not provide any data here

4. Landing Pages
Brings us a list of our top landing pages from social channels

5. Trackbacks
Gives us an idea of when people are linking back to our site in social posts and how many people are following those links.

6. Conversions
Specific report to note how many of those social network referrals are converting on our site and to what degree. An interesting part of this report is to go up here to the top and select Assisted versus Last Interaction Analysis. What this is going to show us is similar to those circles that we saw in the Overview report, as it attempts to show us a time where social referrers were the last thing that happened right before the converting session, versus when they may have sent the user to the site earlier, maybe few days ago, maybe few weeks ago.

7. Plugins

8. Users Flow.
This is going to be a user flow that simply defaults the same user flow we saw earlier in the course to a dimension of social networks. So we can see which social networks led to which starting pages, what their interactions were, what their drop offs were, we can follow their path through the site, and everything that we learned how to do in the user flow one except starting with the dimension of social.

Acquisition > Keywords > Organic

Some poeple say that Organic keyword reports aren't that useful now that Google stopped allowing you to see the search phrases. Instead, you see : "not provided". But, we can still see the amount of traffic coming through that is coming from the organic source.

If you want to have an idea of the keywords people used, you can head over to Acquisition > Search Engine Optimization > Queries. However, you will have to link your Google Analytics account with your Google Webmaster Tools first.

Behavior > Behavior Flow

Make sure you fist select Automatically Grouped Pages. On the left, you will have all your Landing Pages. Landing pages are the only chances we have to make a first impression, and understanding how users enter and exit the site can tell us a lot about performance and user behaviours. Behavior Flow is a great place to start visually understanding that behavior, so we can start to optimize it. I highly encourage you just to dive into these reports, check out some different dimensions, and see what you can find about your site.

Behaviour > Site Content > All pages

From here you can see which content is causing the users to bounce or which one is particularly sticky. For example you could go in comparison and select bounce rate. To fix the bounce rate, you can analyze what keyword people have been using and compare that with the content of your page.

You can also use this report to find pages that share the same title but different URL by clicking on the tab Page Title. Then if you click on one of the page titles, it will drill down on it and show you a list of all the URLs that share this page title. It is usually good practice to have different titles for all the different pages of your website.

Behavior > Site Content > Content drill-down

Depending on your site's architecture, the content drill-down report provides a unique and very efficient reporting tool to analyze your site's content. This can be useful because some pages should be grouped together, for example each of your blog pages may not compete against the "career" section of the site but it would make sense to put all the blog pages into one group. If your site is divided into sub-directories, it's actually going to be very easy to achieve.

Behaviour > Site content > Landing pages

For example you could analyze by city how many session ended up on the Training landing page so that you know in which city to host a conference.

Landing page analysis is really important because optimizing our landing pages is one of the easiest and most effective things we can do to improve site conversions.

Behaviour > Site Search

It is common to see less than 10% of traffic to use the search functionality of your website. It is also common to see that 50% of the people who have purchased used the site search.

Under site search, you have a page report. You can look at where the user was before searching. So if a user was on "Google Analytics Premium" and the user started searching about "Google Analytics Premium", you can tell that the page failed them... These search reports are well worth your time to explore.

Configuring your site search:
1. Make a search on your website (example: Claudie)
2. Look in the URL and see what term is used to identify the keyword searched for (in LOG, it is "s") http://www.lesbianoutdoorgroup.ca/?s=test
3. Go to Google Analytics > Admin > View settings
4. Turn Site Search Setting ON
5. Fill the keyword used (LOG is s)
6. Makes sense to check the box to strip out the search parameters. Site search category is like Amazon where you can search for books or music etc.

Intelligence report

Now, there are two different ways I use this tool. The first I'll call Forensic and the second we'll call Insights.

In Forensic mode what I'm really looking for, are things I see in various reports that are jumping out at me, but I can't necessarily explain it. Having a look at Daily Events where Google Analytics store particular events can help. Basically Google is going through every single report every day and logging the anomalies.

In Insight mode, I'm expecting Google to surface for me things that I would otherwise miss. In other words, one of the great things about these intelligence reports, is that it lets us look for that needle in a haystack, except I don't even necessarily know the needle exists, Google is going to figure that out too. So it would be a matter of just going through each list of alerts and discover interesting insights.

You can create custom alerts by going to Intelligence Events > Overview > Custom Alerts > Manage Customized Alerts > New Alert

A good way of getting alerted if Google Analytics is broken (after an update to your website for example) is to set up an alert when pageview decreases by 60% (comparing same day in previous week). Or you can also set up an alert if the organic traffic suddenly drops, which would mean that you don't appear as much in search engine search results anymore.

Various tabs in the report view

The first tab is "Summary", the default view.

The idea is to pull in metrics that represents each phase of the customer journey:
1. Acquire customers
2. Measure their behaviour on the site through what are commonly known as engagement metrics
3. Measure the outcomes which are represented in the conversion section.

The second tab is Site Usage

Gives us some information about how people are actually using the information on our site through these engagement metrics. We have sessions, pages per session, average session duration, percentage of new sessions, and bounce rate. This information is going to be broken down on the left by source and media. We can see for each of these different sources how these metrics are doing.

The next time is goal (when you have some that are set)

The tab is E-commerce: This is going to give us the dollars and cents, exactly how much each of these visits are worth. How much money are these traffic sources bringing in.

You can create a brand new view of this report by clicking on "Customization" and then select the exact columns you want to see.

Real-life example. Consider these two campaigns, and let's figure out which one is better:

Cost ROI Revenue Per visit value
$8,999.93 273.93% $14,793.82 $1.41
$1,499.90 1058.45% $7,750.54 $3.22

Although the numbers are widely different, when you do Revenue minus cost, they are essentially almost the same: $5,793.89 vs. $6,070.64

Consider now this example:

Visit Clicks Cost
10,473 10,486 $8,999.93
5,910 5,080 $774.33

If you only look at number of visits, you'd consider the first campaign to be more successful, which is absolutely not the case. ($5,793.89 vs $37,941.96)

It is hard to pick the right metric to concentrate on. If you look at each metric, you could go back and forth on which campaign was better.

Filters

There are 3 types of filters:
- View filters (formerly known as profile filters): Set up under admin > View > Filter
