- Quick inline filters: Filters are the top of the data table in the reports
- Advanced filters

--Inline filters--

For example, if you are in the geo > Language report and want to report on spanish speakers, you can click on "ES", but certain browser report spanish differently (ES, ES-SP, etc.) So using the search box, you can type ES and it will give you all the lines that contain ES. The top row will then give you the total for all spanish users.

--Advanced filters--

For example if you want to compare iPad users vs iPhone, you could click on the Advanced link next to the search box, and fill the following information:
- Include
- Mobile Device Info
- Matching RegExp
- iPhone|iPad

(if you create two rows with equal instead of MatchingRegExp, it will not work because you cannot change the AND in between in to an OR.)

In the advance filter, you can also filter on elements that are not even on the report.

A large part of what we're doing in metrics is evaluating quality. And we often do this with rates, bounce rates, conversion rates, e-commerce conversion rates and so on. The problem is that sorting by rate, means that we're dominated by outliers (for example just one session, the person bought something, so that means 100% conversion rate). You can see this in action in the Behaviour > Site Content > All pages report. To fix this problem, you could go in advanced filters and remove pageviews of under 5 for example, but there is another way.

Sort type > instead of Default, pick "weighted"

Now you will see bounce rate rated by pageviews. However, you may not like the Algorithm that Google is using to generate the new bounce rate values.

There is another option in that "sort", called Absolute Change. It will be grayed out unless you do a comparison by date (see above on how to do that)

Segmentation

Examples, segmenting by:
- Country
- Region
- Search Engine
- Keyword
- etc.

Let's use Acquisition > Channels report: Here you can see which search engine was used to access your site by clicking Organic Search and changing the primary Dimension to be "source". Note that by doing that, you are segmenting a segment.

Let's go to Audience > Geo > Location. From this you can click on a country on the map or a country name on the list to drill down to the various regions.

You can segment by drilling down on elements. For example, being in the Audience > Technology > Browser and OS report, you can click on Flash Version and in the data table, click on not set. So now you are segmenting your report to see just the people that don't have Flash (proof in the breadcrumb at the top). Now from there, you could then click on "other" in the tabs area to set the primary dimension to something different, such as operating system, and find out what OS these non-Flash users are using.

User management

User management is done under Admin > User Management (which exists under Account, Property and View).

You can use it to grant access or restrict access.

Different possible permissions:
- Manage Users
- Edit
- Collaborate
- Read & Analyze

It is recommended to use corporate e-mail accounts that you then link to a google account to access Analytics (security reasons, because anybody can open an account called John_smith_123@gmail.com even though their name is not John Smith.

E-mailing report

1. Configure your report
2. Scroll back to the top and click "e-mail"

If you already have a report that is being e-mailed on a certain frequency, when you click e-mail for another report, you will see an option in the bottom right corner to "add to an existing e-mail"

Social Media

If you have a Facebook Like or a Twitter Tweet button on your site, you want to track how many times those buttons were pressed on the various content pages of your site such as a particular blog post. These are known as social plugins for your site. Note that Google +1 buttons are automatically tracked by Google Analytics without you having to do anything further. But outside of Google+, the social data from these elements on your site will have to be sent in by embedding special tracking code in the page to detect the interaction with these buttons. And that's outside the scope of this course, but I do want you to be aware that it exists

Campaigns

If you have add on various websites, instead of giving them your plain link "acme.com/redbox.html", you can add more information in the link like this:
acme.com/redbox.html?utm_campaign=redboxes&utm_media=display&utm_source=boxafficionadosmagazine.com&utm_content=banner-red

Each parameters correspond to these values below:
Campain: redboxes
Medium: display
Source: boxafficionadosmagazine.com
Version: banner-red

You can use the URL builder if you need help: https://support.google.com/analytics/answer/1033867?hl=en

You can test your URL by accessing it and checking the Traffic Source report under Real-Time to make sure that the information is being read by Google Analytics properly

Another example to track e-mail campaigns:
Campaign: maturityassessment
Medium: email
Source: newsletterlist
Content: (various links inside the e-mail can be tagged to various content. So takesurvey vs headline link)

Another medium is "social"

If trying to track offline campaign, use different URLs (short) that will redirect (301 redirect) to the long version

You can use these utm_source and utm_medium in the URL to exactly identify one session in your Google Analytics data if you want to test out something for example.

Anatomy of a URL

http://www.domain.com/myContent/myPage.html

http:// Protocol
www.mydomain.com: hostname
myContent/myPage.html: URI

The URI is what's going to populate all the Google Analytics content reports.

Dashboard

To create a new dashboard, click on Dashboard > New. Then you need to add widgets. If you want to link to a particular report, you can type the URL or you can just start typing the name.

From any report, you can add to dashboard using a button at the very top of the report.

Notes

If you are expecting to see data that you don't see, make sure that the date range includes today.

If you don't know what a specific metric mean, click on the question mark next to it.

Page value: How it works, is that when a transaction happens or a goal is achieved, the revenue or the goal value, is divided up amongst all the unique page views that were part of that visit prior to that transaction. So, if a page is repeatedly part of that set, it'll gain more and more value over time

Google Analytics Tips

How is it possible to have more page views than sessions? Because the session is only counted once on the landing page. Here is how things are calculated in Google Analytics:

User Alice visits the following page: Home - About us - Home
User Bob visits the following pages: Privacy - About us

Pages Pageviews Sessions Unique PV Entrances Users
Home 2 1 1 1 1
About us 2 0 2 0 2
Privacy 1 1 1 1 1
Total 5 2 4 2 2

- Things get a little weird when you're starting to combine hit-level dimensions and session-level metrics.
- Only the first hit of the session is associated with the Sessions metric
- That doesn't mean the hit isn't associated with the session for filters, just the Sessions metric
- Sessions equal Entrances (usually) ->The difference happens when the session starts on an event

Investigate the Google Analytics Query Explorer tool to get IDs of different things like segments

You can use Google Drive to export your reports to Excel, you can create charts from the data and export those as images and that will give you a link. Accessing the link will always show you the image up to date with the latest data.

Misunderstanding with segments

1. AND condition

Filter on session:
Page = Training page
And
Page = Homepage

This condition will work (surprisingly). Google here will show you sessions where people visited both these pages.

However:
Filter on user:
Page = Training page
And
Page = Homepage

This will NOT work.

But you can do this
Filter on user:
Page = Training page
(and then don't have either AND or OR, just create a new filter)
Page = Home page

This will bring you back all the users that have visited both the training page and the home page at some point (doesn't have to be in the same session).

2. Include vs. Exclude

Condition A: Include Page != ContactTrue (the thank you page after submitting a form)
Condition B: Exclude Page = ContactTrue

Corey: Home page > Blog > Training page > Video > About us
David: Home page > About us > Form Start > Form Submit > ContactTrue > Home page
    Condition A Condition B
Corey Y Y
David Y N

Condition A basically says "Show me all the users who have ever hit a page that was anything other than the ContactTrue page"
Condition B says: "Find the existence of people who visited this page and then exclude those people"

3. Filtering from both user and session

On session:
Country = United States
On user:
Revenue per user >= 100

- First, the USER will be filtered
- THEN the session-based condition will be applied

Therefore, let's say Alice has two sessions:

Session 1: $25, Canada
Session 2: $80, US

Alice passes filter 1 because she has $105 total revenue, but only her session 2 will appear in the report: Total revenue: $80, even though our filter indicated $100. That's because she did have $100 when we were including all the sessions that were later removed due to the session filter.

Another example
Filter on user:
Session duration > 300s

Alice
Session 1: 350s
Session 2: 200s

Bob
Session 1: 400s

Charlie
Session 1: 200s
Session 2: 200s

Alice will make it in (both sessions), Bob will make it in, Charlie is not included

Another example at the "hit" level
Filter on user:
Product Revenue per hit >= 50

Alice
Session 1: $25 $35 Total: $60
Session 2: $10 Total: $10

Bob
Session 1: $10 $75 Total: $85

Charlie:
Session 1: $55 $10 Total: $65
Session 2: $20 Total $20

Alice is out, Bob is in, Charlie is in and the total revenue of the segment is: $85 + $65 + $20 ($170)

4. Sequence segments

Filter include user
Step 1: Session duration >= 300s
Step 2: Transaction per hit > 0

Alice:
Session 1: No transaction, 300s
Session 2: 1 transaction, 200s

Bob: No transaction, 400s

Charlie:
Session 1: 1 transaction, 200s
Session 2: no transaction, 350s

Alice is in but Charlie is out because the steps are not in the proper order.

Custom Definitions

In Admin > Property > Custom Definitions

So it's something to investigate again but you can for example match author_id with actual names and then you can investigate in GA which author has most views and things like that

Time zone tips

1. Once the data is in the system, there's no going back
2. If you need to view the data from different time zone perspective, create different views for each time zone
    -> Note that the London view and the US view may record the same visit on different days because of the time difference
Custom reports

You have to be very careful with the granularity. For example, you can't build a report that tries to match page-level scope and session-level scope.

For example, whether you convert or not in a session is something that applies to that entire session. But how may page views a particular page has is a page level scope. So it makes no sense to create a content report that reports the number of page views and the conversion rate for a page. A page itself can't convert, a user converts in a session based on the goals you set up which may or may not include that page.

Documentation on the various scopes here: https://developers.google.com/analytics/devguides/reporting/core/dimsmets (select web mode)

A quicker way of building a custom report is to start from an existing report, go to the top of the page and click "customise". For example you could customize the language report to drill down into Country (instead of drilling down further into Language).

Google Analytics Universal

One user + multiple device = One user in Universal

If you upgrade, you will have to do retagging for the following:
- Events
- Ecommerce
- Custom Variables
- Virtual Pageviews
- Social Interactions
- User Timings
- Cross-domain tracking
- Subdirectory tracking
- Sampling
- Enhanced Link Attribution

Permanent view Filters vs Segments
    -Filters- -Advanced Segments-
Hit based Visit Based (and now user based too)
Forward looking only Can look retroactively
Can affect IP Address Cannot segment on IPs
Can write data (pre-pend subdomain) Doesn't write data, just build subsets for analysis
For data cleanup For analysis

Permanent filters should be applied to NEW views because it is NOT retroactive and it probably doesn't make sense to look at data where the filter was not applied at first and suddenly started to be applied. Filters are permanent, and they are destructive.

Cohort

A cohort is a group of people who are tied together by some common characteristic. They're generally grouped around a certain defined time period. It's not just looking at time periods such as people who buy on their first visit, or if they bounce. We're actually identifying a group of people and then we're following them as time passes. But we're not updating that definition, we stick with that original group

1. Create a new segment using Date of First visit as your criteria (to identify people who have seen that clever Superbowl ad you just ran)
2. Create the exact same segment but for one week prior

Date range cohort is limited to 31 days. And we also want to remember that these are user segments that we are using here, and so we know those can only go 90 days back

Filtering internal traffic

Recommended to filter out by IP address. Don't look at your computer IP address, just Google "What is my IP address?" and use that. This is your External IP address. IP address is only accessible through view filters.

Filters everyone should have

Note: When you do a custom filter on a view, if you use "include", it doesn't just mean Include, it's also going to EXCLUDE everything else. The filter pattern field is a regular expression field, so if you put your IP address there, you should put a backslash before each dot to escape it.

1. lowercase

This filter will cleanup your data before it even hits your account. Apply to medium, source and campaign name (three different filters)

Advanced segments

You can see up to 4 segments at a given time. You can create your own segment by clicking "new segment". When you segment by user, you have a 90 day look back window (example: total purchase per user).









[HTML]

parent nodes: WebDesign

HTML

[camelCaseWordsEnabled: false]

HTML Statuses
HTML5

Adding a favicon:

<!DOCTYPE html
    PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01//EN"
    "http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/strict.dtd">
<html lang="en-US">
<head profile="http://www.w3.org/2005/10/profile">
<link rel="icon"
    type="image/png"
    href="">
[…]
</head>
[…]
</html>

Button Type Attributes

button: The button is a clickable button
submit: The button is a submit button (submits form-data)
reset: The button is a reset button (resets the form-data to its initial values)









[HTML Statuses]

parent nodes: HTML

HTML Statuses

404 Not Found

500 Internal Server Error

304 Not Modified
Technical Jargon: Indicates that the resource has not been modified since the version specified by the request headers If-Modified-Since or If-None-Match. This means that there is no need to retransmit the resource, since the client still has a cached copy.

401 Unauthorized

410 Gone

301 Moved Permanently

413 Request Entity Too Large

508 Loop Detected

400 Bad Request









[HTML5]

parent nodes: HTML

HTML5

[camelCaseWordsEnabled: false]

Main features

- Video Support
- Audio support
- Canvas element
- Offline storage
- New form elements
- Drag and drop
- Geolocation
- Local storage

For a list of features you can use per browser, go to http://caniuse.com

Example

<video id="myVideo" controls preload="auto">
    <source src="videofile.mp4 type="video/mp4" />
    <source src="videofile.webm type="video/webm" />
    <source src="videofile.ogv type="video/webm" />
    <!-- if video is not supported -->
    <p>Your browser does not support HTML5 video.</p>
</video>

Data tag

Example:
<li class="vacation onsale" data-price='399.99'>

You use the data tag to provide additional data to elements on the page. You can then use jQuery to access that information.

.data(<name>)

You can SET the value by providing a name AND a value: .data(, )









[Ionic]

parent nodes: WebDesign

Ionic

Ionic is a framework

SDK for building native applications using Modern Web Technologies

Basically you can code in HTML, Javascript and CSS and ionic will translate it into each of the mobile's programming languages. So it is a Framework of Frameworks using the following:

- AngularJS
- Cordova: Cordova will package the web code and compile it into native applications for a number of different mobile platforms. Now Cordova can also give you access to native functionality, like the accelerometer or a camera through a series of JavaScript APIs.
- SASS
- Gulp
- NodeJS
- Git
- Bower

- Prebuilt Style Components
- Custom Directives through AngularJS









[AngularJS]

parent nodes: Ionic | Javascript | MVC Frameworks

Angular JS

[camelCaseWordsEnabled: false]

What is Angular JS?
> Javascript Framework for creating single page web applications
> A client-side Javascript Framework for adding interactivity to HTML

Advantages:
- Excellent templating engine
- Handles DOM masterfully
- Easy data manipulation

MVC Architecture
M: Models (data)
V: Views (template)
C: Controllers (link between models and views)

Core features:
- Directives (start with ng-)
- Data binding
- Filters
- Modules
- Routes
- Controllers

Installing Angular JS

Go to http://www.angularjs.org and download the library

Angular JS must be added in the HEAD of your document


Then you must tell Angular which part of your HTML file you want Angular to control. To do that, add ng-app in the tag. More information here: https://docs.angularjs.org/api/ng/directive/ngApp

<html lang="en" ng-app>

Now we will have the most basic Angular app by adding this to our body:

<input type="text" ng-model="name">
    <h2>Welcome {{name}}</h2>
More information about ng-model: https://docs.angularjs.org/api/ng/directive/ngModel

Basically, ng-model is binding the data from the input field into the template {{name}} is acting as a template

Create a new folder called js with a file called controllers.js

controllers.js will contain:
var myApp = angular.module('myApp', []); //[dependancies], this particular project does not have any

Now we need to update our HTML:
<html lang="en" ng-app="myApp">

Now we need to create our controller in controllers.js. This is a piece of JavaScript code that's going to control something on the page.

You can create different controllers and tell them to control different parts of your application.

So we'll do this inside the myApp variable that we just created. We use the controller method. In there we're going to give this controller a name. We'll call it MyController. This is going to have a function. This function is going to be MyController. That function is going to receive a variable called scope. We're also asking that the controller use something called scope. This is like a super variable that you can use to pass things from your JavaScript to your application and template, and vice-versa.


myApp.controller('MyController', function MyController($scope){
    /*We are creating the model manually*/

    $scope.author = {
      'name': 'Claudie Larouche',
      'title': 'President of the world',
      'company': 'Claudie Web Design'
    }
});

Then we update our body in HTML:

<body>
    <div ng-controller = 'MyController'>
    <h1>{{author.name}}</h1>
    <p>{{author.title + ', ' + author.company}}</p>
    </div>
</body>

To loop through elements in an array, use ng-repeat:

<div class="main" ng-controller = "MyController">
    <ul class="artistlist">
      <li class="artist cf" ng-repeat="item in artists">
        <img src="images/{{item.shortname}}_tn.jpg" alt="Photo of {{item.name}}">
        <div class="info">
          <h2>{{item.name}}</h2>
          <h3>{{item.reknown}}</h3>
        </div>
      </li>
    </ul>
</div>

More about ng-repeat: https://docs.angularjs.org/api/ng/directive/ngRepeat

Right now we have an error because of the image tag, we need to use a special image tag specific to Angular with ng-src (more information here: https://docs.angularjs.org/api/ng/directive/ngSrc



Now we have no more error!

Loading data from a JSON file

To load data from a JSON file in Angular, we will use something called a "service"

https://docs.angularjs.org/api/ng/service

We simply need to change our controller:

myApp.controller('MyController', function MyController($scope, $http){
    /*We are creating the model manually*/

    $http.get('js/data.json').success(function(data){
      $scope.artists = data;
    });
});

And that's it! However now our code has stopped working on a local machine, it must now be hosted on Bluehost (although it might work in Firefox, I haven't tested it)

Minification

You must put your scope and html variables into an array if you ever plan on doing minification (otherwise it won't work, god knows why)

myApp.controller('MyController', ['$scope', '$http', function ($scope, $http){
    /*We are creating the model manually*/

    $http.get('js/data.json').success(function(data){
      $scope.artists = data;
    });
}]);

Filters

Example:

{{item.name | uppercase}}



This will make all the names uppercase

More info about filters: https://docs.angularjs.org/api/ng/filter

Another example:


  • Will limit the number of returned elements to 5

    Bind filter to data

    Now we are adding a search box in HTML:
    <div class="search">
      <h1>Artist Directory</h1>
      <label>search: </label>
      <input placeholder="Search for artists" autofocus>
    </div>

    To bind the data with the search, all we have to do is to create a model on the input field:

    <input ng-model="query" placeholder="Search for artists" autofocus>

    Then we add a filter to the li to link it with our model

    <li class="artist cf" ng-repeat="item in artists | filter: query">

    Sorting

    I just added an option box in HTML for the sorting:
    <label class="formgroup">by:
      <select ng-model="artistOrder">
        <option value="name">Name</option>
        <option value="reknown">Reknown</option>
      </select>
    </label>

    Don't forget the ng-model too. And then I add the sort by code in the li:

    <li class="artist cf" ng-repeat="item in artists | filter: query | orderBy: artistOrder">

    And now why not add the sort direction?

    <label class="formgroup">
      <input type="radio" ng-model="direction" name="direction" checked>
      ascending
    </label>
    <label class="formgroup">
      <input type="radio" ng-model="direction" name="direction" value="reverse">
      descending
    </label>



  • To make sure that "Name" is automatically selected in the order by, add artistOrder in your controller:

    myApp.controller('MyController', ['$scope', '$http', function ($scope, $http){
      /*We are creating the model manually*/

      $http.get('js/data.json').success(function(data){
        $scope.artists = data;
        $scope.artistOrder = 'name';
      });
    }]);

    Routeprovider

    More information: https://docs.angularjs.org/api/ngRoute/provider/$routeProvider

    In order to make this work, we will need an additional module: https://code.angularjs.org/1.3.14/

    We need angular-route.min.js, save it in lib > angular

    Add a call to it in your HTML (after angular):
    <script src="lib/angular/angular-route.min.js"></script>

    Now we will create a new folder called "partials"

    create a new file called list.html

    For the rest, maybe you should just look at the final state of the application...

    Animation

    Angular JS has all sorts of animations, see here: https://docs.angularjs.org/guide/animations

    First, we need to download additional modules: angular-animate.min.js

    You must add this module as a dependency on your controllers

    Add animate to something on your page:

    <li ng-animate="'animate'" class="artist cf" ng-repeat="item in artists | filter: query | orderBy: artistOrder:direction">

    add the following to CSS:
    .artist.ng-enter.ng-enter-active,
    .artist.ng-leave{
      opacity: 1;
      height: 80px;
      overflow: hidden;
      }

    .artist.ng-leave.ng-leave-active,
    .artist.ng-enter{
      opacity: 0;
      height: 0;
      overflow: hidden;
      }
    Hiding data by default

    We will use ngshow: https://docs.angularjs.org/api/ng/directive/ngShow

    AngularJS training from codeschool

    If you're using Javascript to create a dynamic website, Angular is a good choice.

    - Angular helps you organize your Javascript
    - Angular helps create fast websites
    - Angular plays well with jQuery
    - Angular is easy to test

    Normal website workflow

    1) Browser send URL request to Server
    2) Server responds with Webpage and Assets (HTML, Javascript)
    3) User clicks on a link. New request to the server
    4) Server respons with Webpage and Assets (HTML, Javascript)

    With Angular:

    1) Browser send URL request to Server
    2) Server responds with Webpage and Assets (HTML, Javascript)
    3) User clicks on a link. New request to the server
    4) Server respons with JSON Data which will then be loaded into the existing page

    In the course, we will be building a front-end app using Angular, which will be talking to a back-end app. But we won't be building the back-end app.

    In Angular, we add behaviour to our HTML through Directives

    Directives

    A Directive is a marker on a HTML tag that tells Angular to run or reference some Javascript code

    index.html
    <!DOCTYPE html>
    <html>
      <body ng-controller="StoreController"> <!-- Add this Directive ... -->
      </body>
    </html>

    app.js
    function StoreController(){ /*same name as ng-controller*/
      alert('Welcome, Greg!');
    }

    BUT, you would never actually write the angular code this way. This is just to understand the relationship between ng-controller and the function names.

    Possible directives:
    - ng-app
    - ng-bind
    - ng-blur
    - ng-change
    - ng-class
    - ng-click
    - ng-copy
    - ng-dblclick
    - ng-disabled
    - ng-focus
    - ng-hide
    - ng-href
    - ng-if
    - ng-include
    - ng-init
    - ng-keydown
    - ng-keypress
    - ng-keyup
    - ng-model
    - ng-mouseenter
    - ng-mouseleave
    - ng-mousemove
    - ng-mouseover
    - ng-paste
    - ng-repeat
    - ng-style
    - ng-switch
    - ng-transclude
    ... (there are over 50 of them)

    Modules

    - Modules are where we write pieces of our Angular application
    - Makes our code more maintainable, testable and readable
    - Where we define dependencies of our app

    var app = angular.module('store', []);

    angular = angularJS
    store = Application name
    [] = dependencies

    This will be in app.js

    Next we add ng-app = "store" in our HTML tag:
    <html ng-app="store">

    Expressions

    https://docs.angularjs.org/guide/expression

    Allow you to insert dynamic values into your HTML

    Numerical Operations:
    <p>
      I am {{4+6}}
    </p>

    String Operations:
    <p>
      {{"Hello " + "you"}}
    </p>

    Controllers

    Help us put data into the page. Controllers are where we define our app's behaviour by defining functions and values.

    A good practice is to wrap our app.js code into a closure, and then we specify the name of the controller, in this case, StoreController:

    (function(){
      var app = angular.module('store', []);

      app.controller('StoreController', function(){
        this.product = gem; //Product is a property of the controller
      });

      var gem = {
        name: 'Dodecahedron',
        price: 2.95,
        description: 'description of the gem',
      }
    })();

    Other directives

    ng-show: <button ng-show="store.product.canPurchase">Add to cart</button>
    The button will appear only if canPurchase is true

    ng-hide:
    <div ng-hide="store.product.soldOut">...</div>
    div will be hidden if soldOut is true

    ng-repeat:
    <div ng-repeat="product in store.products">
      <h1>{{product.name}}
      <h2>${{product.price}}
      <p>{{product.description}}


      <!--button will show only if canPurchase is true-->
      <button ng-show="product.canPurchase">Add to cart
    </div>
    Iterate through every items in store.products and show on the screen

    Filters

    Example: <em class="pull-right">{{product.price | currency}}

    Basically the format is the following: {{data | filter:options}}

    Examples:
    {{'1388123412323' | date: 'MM/dd/yyyy @ h:mma'}} -> 12/27/2013 @ 12:50AM

    {{'octagon gem' | uppercase}} -> OCTAGON GEM (lowercase also exists)

    {{'My Description' | limitTo:8}} ->My Descr (limits the number of characters). Can also be used to limit the number of items shown by ng-repeat

    <li ng-repeat="product in store.products | orderBy:'-price'"> (minus means reverse sort order)

    Different types of filter:

    currency: {{amount|currency:"USD$"}}
    date: {{startDate|date:'short'}}
    filter: repo in repos!filter:searchTerm
    json: {{repo|json}}
    limitTo: repo in repos|limitTo:10
    lowercase/uppercase: {{user.name|uppercase}}
    number: {{stars|number}}
    orderBy: repo in repos|filter:searchTerm|orderBy:'name'

    Tabs

    <section ng-init="tab = 1">
      <ul class="nav nav-pills">
        <!-- if tab===1, class = active -->
        <li ng-class="{active:tab === 1}">
          <a href ng-click="tab = 1">Description</a>
        </li>
        <li ng-class="{active:tab === 2}">
          <a href ng-click="tab = 2">Specifications</a>
        </li>
        <li ng-class="{active:tab === 3}">
          <a href ng-click="tab = 3">Reviews</a>
        </li>
      </ul>
      <div class="panel" ng-show="tab === 1">
        <h4>Description</h4>
        <p>{{product.description}}</p>
      </div>
      <div class="panel" ng-show="tab === 2">
        <h4>Specifications</h4>
        <p>None yet</p>
      </div>
      <div class="panel" ng-show="tab === 3">
        <h4>Reviews</h4>
        <p>None yet</p>
      </div>
    </section>

    This will basically show different divs depending which tab you click. This is known as 2-way data binding (this means that Expressions are re-evaluated when a property changes).

    Use ng-init to set the initial value

    This is apparently starting to get messy and we will move the logic outside of our HTML and into Angular. Basically you need to create a new Controller like this:

    app.controller('PanelController', function(){
      this.tab = 1; //this replaces ng-init

      //this replaces ng-click="tab = 1"
      this.selectTab = function(setTab){
        this.tab = setTab;
      };

      //this replaces ng-class="{active:tab === 1}
      this.isSelected = function(checkTab){
        return this.tab === checkTab;
      };
    });

    And your HTML should now look like this:
    <section ng-init="tab = 1" ng-controller="PanelController as panel">
      <ul class="nav nav-pills">
        <!-- if tab===1, class = active -->
        <li ng-class="{active:panel.isSelected(1)}">
          <a href ng-click="panel.selectTab(1)">Description</a>
        </li>
        <li ng-class="{active:panel.isSelected(2)}">
          <a href ng-click="panel.selectTab(2)">Specifications</a>
        </li>
        <li ng-class="{active:panel.isSelected(3)}">
          <a href ng-click="panel.selectTab(3)">Reviews</a>
        </li>
      </ul>
      <div class="panel" ng-show="panel.isSelected(1)">
        <h4>Description</h4>
        <p>{{product.description}}</p>
      </div>
      <div class="panel" ng-show="panel.isSelected(2)">
        <h4>Specifications</h4>
        <p>None yet</p>
      </div>
      <div class="panel" ng-show="panel.isSelected(3)">
        <h4>Reviews</h4>
        <p>None yet</p>
      </div>
    </section>

    /Forms/

    We can use the directive ng-models to bind for element values to their properties, as such:
    <h4>Reviews</h4>
    <blockquote ng-repeat="review in product.reviews">
      <b>Stars: {{review.star}}</b>
      <p>{{review.body}}</p>
      <cite>by: {{review.author}}</cite>
    </blockquote>
    <form name="reviewForm" ng-controller="ReviewController as reviewCtrl" ng-submit="reviewCtrl.addReview(product)">
      <blockquote>
        <b>Stars: {{reviewCtrl.review.stars}}</b> <!--binding this -->
        <p>{{reviewCtrl.review.body}}</p>
        <cite>by: {{reviewCtrl.review.author}}</cite>
      </blockquote>
      <h4>Submit a review</h4>
        <fieldset class="form-group">
          <!-- with this! -->
          <select ng-model="reviewCtrl.review.stars" ng-options="stars for stars in [5,4,3,2,1]" class="form-control" >
            <option value="">Rate the Product</option>
          </select>
        </fieldset>
        <fieldset class="form-group">
          <textarea ng-model="reviewCtrl.review.body" class="form-control" placeholder="Write a short review of the product..." title="Review"></textarea>
        </fieldset>
        <fieldset class="form-group">
          <input ng-model="reviewCtrl.review.author" type="email" class="form-control" placeholder="you@example.org" title="Email" />
        </fieldset>
        <fieldset class="form-group">
          <input type="submit" class="btn btn-primary pull-right" value="Submit Review" />
        </fieldset>
    </form>

    ng-submit allows us to call a function when the form is submitted.

    Form Validation

    Angular.js has great client side validations that we can use in our directives. The first thing we need to do is turn off HTML default validation with novalidate.

    Then add "required" to a few fields and add a condition so that the button actually submits only if the form is valid:
    <form name="reviewForm" ng-controller="ReviewController as reviewCtrl" ng-submit="reviewForm.$valid && reviewCtrl.addReview(product)" novalidate>

    Angular will add classes to your field depending if they are filled or not, and depending if they are valid or invalid. You can style each class differently to make it clear when a field is not valid. Here are the classes:
    - ng-pristine
    - ng-dirty
    - ng-valid
    - ng-invalid

    Angular can validate e-mails, urls and numbers:
    <input type="e-mail" name="email">
    <input type="url" name="homepage">
    <input type="number" name="quantity"> You can even specify a min and max (min=1 max=10)

    Eliminating duplication

    Let's pretend the following two lines are needed in various places in our code:

    {{product.name}}
    <em class="pull-right">${{product.price}}</em>

    To eliminate this duplication, we can create HTML snippets.

    So we will pull this HTML and put it in product-title.html

    Then in index.html, we will use ng-include:


    <!--we need the single quote because Angular is expecting a variable and we are actually sending a string-->



    We can actually write our own custom directive, as such:
    <product-title></product-title>

    But we will need more code behind the scenes to make this work.

    Why use directives? Because they can tell you a lot of information about your Angular Application. For example:

    <div>
      <book-cover></book-cover>
      <h4><book-rating></book-rating>
    </div>
    <div>
      <h3><book-title></book-title></h3>
      <book-authors></book-authors>
    </div>

    Template-expanding Directives are the simplest:
    - Define a custom tag or attribute that is expanded or replaced
    - Can include Controller logic, if needed

    Directives can also be used for:
    - Expressing complex UI
    - Calling events and registering event handlers
    - Reusing common components


    To create a custom Element directive:

    <product-title></product-title>

    The dash in HTML will translate to camelCase in Javascript

    app.directive('productTitle', function(){
      return {
        //A configuration object defining how your directive will work
        restrict: 'E', //Type of directive (E for Element)
        templateUrl: 'product-title.html'
      };
    });

    To create a custom Attribute directive:

    <h3 product-title></h3>

    app.directive('productTitle', function(){
      return {
        //A configuration object defining how your directive will work
        restrict: 'A', //Type of directive (A for attribute)
        templateUrl: 'product-title.html'
      };
    });

    Element directive vs Attribute directive

    Element directive:
    <product-title></product-title>

    Attribute directive:
    <h3 product-title></h3>

    Use Element directives for UI widgets and Attribute directives for mixin behavious like a tooltip.

    NOTE: Element and Attribute directives don't work locally (must upload file to server)

    Attaching Controllers to directives

    So basically what we did here is the following:
    1) Create a new element directive for product-panel
    2) remove the whole product section from index.html and remove the call to ng-controller
    3) Add the controller functions and alias to our new element directive, as such:
    app.directive('productPanels', function(){
      return {
        //A configuration object defining how your directive will work
        restrict: 'E', //Type of directive (E for Element)
        templateUrl: 'product-panels.html',
        controller: function(){
          this.tab = 1; //this replaces ng-init

          //this replaces ng-click="tab = 1"
          this.selectTab = function(setTab){
            this.tab = setTab;
          };

          //this replaces ng-class="{active:tab === 1}
          this.isSelected = function(checkTab){
            return this.tab === checkTab;
          };
        },
        controllerAs: 'panel' //the alias
      };
    });
    4) Remove the controller from app.js
    5) Add the call to the directive in index.html: <product-panels></product-panels>

    Dependencies

    If our app.js becomes crowded, it's possible to split things into different modules. For example you can create a products.js by copying all three directives related to products into it. If you wrap it in a closure, you can use another variable called app which will be different from the one in app.js:

    products.js:

    (function(){
      //because I included this in a different closure, this is a different app variable than app.js
      var app= angular.module('store-products',[])

      app.directive('productDescription', function(){
        ...
      });

      app.directive('productSpecs', function(){
        ...
      });

      app.directive('productPanels', function(){
        ...
      });
    })();

    We need to include this new product.js in index.html and add store-products as a dependency of the store module in app.js

    It is best to split Modules around functionality:
    - app.js - top-level module attached via ng-app
    - products.js - all the functionaility for products and ONLY products

    Services

    Services give your Controller additional functionality:
    - Fetching JSON data from a web service with $http
    - Logging messagaes to the JavaScript console with $log
    - Filtering and array with $filter

    The $http service is how we make an async request to a server
    - By using $http as a function with an options object:
      $http({method: 'GET', url: '/products.json'});
    - Or using one of the shortcut methods:
      $http.get('/products.json'. {apiKey: 'myApiKey'});
    Both return a Promise object with .success() and .error() //jquery course at codeschool has information about Promises

    If we tell $http to fetch JSON, the result will be automatically decoded into JavaScript objects and arrays

    Controller using a service:
    app.controller('ReviewController', ['$http', function($http){
      ... //service name is same as function argument
    }]);

    If you need more than one:
    app.controller('ReviewController', ['$http', $log, function($http, $log){
      ... //service name is same as function argument
    }]);

    Example of using http:

    (function(){
      var app = angular.module('store', ['store-products']);

      app.controller('StoreController', ['$http', function($http){
      var store = this;
      //we need to initialize products to an empty arry since the page will render before our data returns from our get request below

      store.products = [];

      $http.get('/product.json').success(function(data){
        //cannot use this.products = data because "this" is not the same thing inside this function
        store.products = data;
      });
        });
    })();

    In addition to get() requests, $http can post(), put(), delete(), etc...

    $http.post('/path/resource.json', {param: value});
    $http.delete('/path/resource.json');

    ...or any other http method by using a CONFIG object:

    $http({ method: 'OPTIONS, url: '/path/resource.json'});
    $http({ method: 'PATCH, url: '/path/resource.json'});
    $http({ method: 'TRACE, url: '/path/resource.json'});

    Other available services:
    - $http
    - $interval
    - $window
    - $timeout
    - $log (to use this service, simply do: $log.info("Starting the process");
    - $animate
    - $location
    - $browser
    - $window
    - $anchorScroll
    - etc.

    We typically don't use http service inside a controller, you'll typically create a separate .js file (see jquery > angular > service on Bluehost. The file is github.js)











    [Javascript]

    parent nodes: WebDesign

    Javascript

    [camelCaseWordsEnabled: false]

    AngularJS
    jQuery
    jQuery Plugins
    Node.js
    EmberJS
    MVC Frameworks

    Introduction
    JavaScript only works inside another application, the web browser. Whether that's IE or Safari or Firefox or Chrome or Opera, they all have a JavaScript engine inside them. The operating system runs the web browser, the web browser contains a page, and the page contains the JavaScript. Now another way JavaScript is limited is that it doesn't have access to the file system of the computer that it's running on. There are no keywords in JavaScript to open or save local files because that would be a security risk.

    Javascript is a client-side language as opposed to server side technologies like PHP, ASP.NET, Ruby on Rails...

    You will also find Javascript in Acrobat, Photoshop, Node.js...

    Because JavaScript is on the client-side, you have to think of the possibility of it not being activated on the client's machine, and it will be as if your javascript does not exist at all. It is not as common nowadays as it used to be. We have to make sure our website are still useable even if JavaScript is inactivated.

    JavaScript used to be rendered differently by different browsers, but it is no longer the case much.

    JavaScript and ECMAScript is pretty much the same thing. ECMAScript version 3 was published in 1999 and ECMAScript version 5 in 2009, but version 3 is the one that guarantees full support by all browsers. [The course was done in 2011 so it is probably not true anymore]

    Javascript is interpreted, not compiled

    Javascript is case sensitive
    Javascript is whitespace insensitive
    Javacript comment: // or /**/

    Alert Box
    <script>
      alert("Hello World!");
    </script>

    Examples of things you could do with JavaScript

    - Change color of headline
    - Calculate age
    - Move image
    - Hide menu
    - Alert important messages

    Putting Javascript into different files

    In your HTML file:
    <script src="myscript.js" type="text/javascript"></script>

    You can leave off type="text/javascript", every browser will assume it's javascript

    And in your js file, you would not have the <script> tag

    Where to put your code

    Put the script tags at the very bottom of your <body> tag, unless the script is necessary to render the page.

    Variables

    Creating a variable:
    var year;
    year = 2011;

    or:
    var year = 2011; //technically, the word "var" is not necessary but it is good practice to put it

    So basically if you have just year = 2011, javascript will check if that variable already exists and if it doesn't, it will create it for you.

    Name of variable cannot start with a number
    99problems does not work
    problems99 works

    You are allowed to do this:
    var year, month, day;
    var year= 2011, month = 12, day = 18;

    In javascript, you don't have to specify which type your variable is (bool, float, string, etc.)

    You can use either " or ' to surround text.

    You're allowed to do this:

    var myVariable;
    myVariable = 200;
    myVariable = "Hello";
    myVariable = 'Hello';
    myVariable = true;

    Conditional code

    if(condition) {
      //code
    }
    else{
      //different code
    }

    if( c==99(<){
      //we need a double ==, or triple ===. Never =
    }

    You don't have to put braces if you have a one-line statement inside your if

    Switch

    var candy = prompt("What's your favorite candy?","Type your favorite candy here.");

    switch(candy) {
      case 'licorice':
        console.log("Gross!");
        break;
      case 'gum':
        console.log("I like gum!");
        break;
      case 'beets':
        console.log("...is that even a candy?");
        break;
      // Add your code here!
      default:
        console.log("default");
    }

    Operators

    Arithmetic: + - * /
    Assignment: =
    Equality: == or === (strict equality)
    Different: != or !==
    Comparison: < > =< =>
    Logical "or" and "and": || and &&
    Modulus: %
    Shorthand increment / decrement: i++; or i--; or ++i; or --i;
    Prefix / Postfix: if you alert(++a), this is different from alert(a++)
    Ternary: condition ? true : false

    Operator precedence: * and / are more important than + and -

    Equality example:
    5 == "5" is true
    but
    5 === "5" is not true

    Some javascript experts recommend using === all the time and never use ==

    //Those two statements are identical:
    score = score + 10;
    score += 10;

    Calculate a leap year:
    var year = 2003;
    var remainder = year % 4; //remainder is 3

    Write to the console

    var foo = 10;
    var bar = 20;

    if (foo < bar){
      console.log("foo is less than bar");
      console.debug("foo is less than bar");
      console.info("foo is less than bar");
      console.warn("foo is less than bar");
      console.error("foo is less than bar");
    }

    Loops

    while

    var a = 1;

    while (a < 10){
      console.log(a);
      a++;
    }

    do...while

    var a = 1;

    do {
      console.log(a);
      a++;
    } while (a < 10);

    for loop

    for (var a = 1; a< 10; a++){
      console.log(a);
    }

    break

    The word "break" jumps you out of the loop

    continue

    for (var a = 1; a< 10; a++){
      //do stuff
      //do stuff
      if (condition){
        continue;
      }
      //will be skipped by continue, we're done with this iteration
    }

    Functions

    function myFunction () {
      console.log("We're in the function!");
    }

    //sometime later
    myFunction();

    It doesn't matter where you put your functions, they will work regardless, however it is better practice to declare a function BEFORE calling it.

    Function with parameters

    function myFunction (x) {
      console.log("We're in the function and here is the value of x: " + x);
    }

    //sometime later
    myFunction("salut!");

    Returning values

    function myFunction (x, y) {
      var myVar = x + y;
      return myVar;
    }

    //sometime later
    myVar = myFunction(2,3);
    alert(myVar);

    If you pass an extra parameter by mistake:
    myVar = myFunction(2,3,4) -> this equals 5

    The extra parameter is simply ignored.

    If you don't pass enough, the variables will be "undefined".
    myVar = myFunction(2) -> This does not actually give 2, it gives NaN, but at least my page doesn't break.

    Scope

    var bar = 1000; //This is a global variable

    function simpleFunction(){
      var foo = 500;
      console.log(foo); //500
      console.log(bar); //1000
    }

    simpleFunction();
    console.log(foo); //undefined
    console.log(bar); //1000;


    Arrays

    var tableau = [1,2,3,4,5];

    or

    var tableau = [];

    tableau[0] = 50;
    tableau[1] = 60;
    tableau[2] = "mouse";

    Basically you can put anything in your array, regardless of the type

    These lines mean the same thing:
    var tableau = [];
    var tableau = new Array();
    var tableau = Array();

    We can create the array with a size (var tableau = Array(5);) but you don't have to specify the size, javascript will let you put values wherever you feel like in your array at anytime. Arrays are dynamic.

    console.log(tableau.length()); //will give you the length of the array

    Array methods

    length;
    reverse();
    join(); //join all the values in the array in one single string
    sort();

    Numbers

    Internally, all JavaScript numbers are 64-bit floating point numbers

    5 + 5 = 10
    "5" + "5" = "55"
    5 + "5" = "55"

    To verify if a variable is a number:

    var foo = "55";
    var myNumber = Number(foo);

    if (isNaN(myNumber) ){
      console.log("It's not a number!");
    }

    or

    if (!isNaN(myNumber) ){
      console.log("It IS a number!");
    }

    To convert a variable into a number, just put a + in front of it (var foo = +"55";)

    Using the Math object

    var x = 200.6;
    var y = Math.round(x);

    var a = 1, b = 2, c = 3;
    var biggest = Math.max(a,b,c);
    var smallest = Math.min(a,b,c);

    other functions:
    Math.PI
    Math.random();
    Math.sqrt();
    Math.log();

    Math.floor(Math.random() * 255) -> will give you a random number between 0 and 255
    We do this because random generates a random number between 0 and 1 (0.5, 0.831, etc.)

    Strings

    Escape string:

    var phrase = "this is a simple phrase.";
    phrase.length; //24
    phrase.toUpperCase();
    phrase.toLowerCase();

    phrase.split(" "); //returns an array of words. The "space" represents where the string should be split

    var phrase = "We want a groovy keyword";
    var position = phrase.indexOf("groovy"); //10

    This will return the FIRST occurence of the word (if there are multiple)

    If not found, it will return -1

    You can use lastIndexOf for the last occurence

    var phrase = "Yet another phrase.";
    var segment = phrase.slice(6,11); //"other"

    .substring(start,end)
    .substr(start,length)

    String comparison is case sensitive

    All the uppercase letters are considered less than lowercase

    Javascript reference guide: http://developer.mozilla.org/en/JavaScript/Reference

    Dates

    var today = new Date(); //current date and time if you don't pass parameters
    var y2k = new Date(2000,0,1); //notice that MONTH is zero based

    today.getMonth(); //returns 0 - 11
    today.getFullYear(); //YYYY
    today.getYear(); //deprecated
    today.getDate(); //1-31 day of month
    today.getDay(); //0-6 day of the week (0 = Sunday)
    today.getHours(); //0-23 (zero-based)
    today.getTime(); //milliseconds since 1970/01/01. This is used a lot to compare dates

    We also have the equivalent "set" methods.

    Comparing dates

    var date1 = new Date(2000,0,1);
    var date2 = new Date(2000,0,1);

    if (date1==date2) //This is false, because dates are objects

    instead we should do:

    if(date1.getTime() == date2.getTime()) //This is true

    Typeof

    var anObj = { job: "I'm an object!" };
    var aNumber = 42;
    var aString = "I'm a string!";

    console.log(typeof anObj ); // should print "object"
    console.log( typeof aNumber ); // should print "number"
    console.log( typeof aString); // should print "string"


    Objects

    3 types of object:
    - Host Objects: objects defined by the environment in which your code is run (example a web browser which include console object, window object, etc.)
    - Core Objects: Objects built into the JavaScript language itself (ex: Math, String, Date, etc.)
    - Coder defined: All other objects that are defined by you or coming from a library like jQuery! :)

    Arrays are Objects
    Dates are Objects

    var player = new Object();

    //properties
    player.name = "Fred";
    player.score = 100;
    player.rank = 1;

    or

    //shorthand through name-value pair
    var player1 = {name: "Fred", score: 100, rank: 1};
    var player2 = {name: "Sam", score: 50, rank: 3};

    function playerDetails(){
      //Display information about each player
      console.log(this.name + " has a rank of: " + this.rank);
    }

    player1.logDetails = playerDetails; //This is not a call to a function, we are associating the function with player1
    player2.logDetails = playerDetails;

    player1.logDetails();

    OR

    var phonebookEntry = {};

    phonebookEntry.name = 'Oxnard Montalvo';
    phonebookEntry.number = '(555) 555-5555';
    phonebookEntry.phone = function() {
      console.log('Calling ' + this.name + ' at ' + this.number + '...');
    };

    phonebookEntry.phone();

    OR

    var me = {
      name: "Claudie",
      age: 29
    };

    hasOwnProperty

    var myObj = {
      name: "Claudie"
    };

    console.log( myObj.hasOwnProperty('name') ); // true
    console.log( myObj.hasOwnProperty('nickname') ); // false

    Loop through elements of an object

    var nyc = {
      fullName: "New York City",
      mayor: "Bill de Blasio",
      population: 8000000,
      boroughs: 5
    };

    for (var property in nyc)
    {
      console.log(property); //this will log the property name
      console.log(nyc[property]); //this will log the property value
    }

    DOM

    Knowing the DOM is the single most important skill for a Javascript developer

    DOM: Document Object Model

    Document = The page (the web page)
    Object = Any element on the page (h1, ul, html...) sometimes they contain other objects (ul contains li)
    Model = kind of like the HTML in a tree structure. The model is an agreed upon set of terms

    HTML
      HEAD
        TITLE
      BODY
        H1
        P
        UL
          LI
          LI
          LI
    When you know the DOM, you can use Javascript to access and make changes to ANY element of the page:
    - Get the title text
    - Get the second paragraph
    - Get the third link in the menu and set its CSS to display: none
    - Change the background color of all paragraphs with a class of "important"
    - Get all the <li> elements in the last unordered list
    - Find the image with an id of "logo" and move it 40 pixels to the right
    - Change a link so it performs a javascript function when clicked
    - Create a new unordered list and insert between first and second paragraph
    - ...

    The DOM thinks about elements in terms of "Nodes". Nodes are not only tags, they are block of text, comments in the code, attributes, etc.

    Node types

    node.ELEMENT_NODE
    node.ATTRIBUTE_NODE
    node.TEXT_NODE
    node.CDATA_SECTION_NODE
    node.ENTITY_REFERENCE_NODE
    node.ENTITY_NODE
    node.PROCESSING_INSTRUCTION_NODE
    node.COMMENT_NODE
    node.DOCUMENT_NODE
    node.DOCUMENT_TYPE_NODE
    node.DOCUMENT_FRAGMENT_NODE
    node.NOTATION_NODE

    But we are only interested in the first three

    Accessing DOM elements

    Your main question is: Is it unique? Does it have an ID?

    If so, you can get to it this way:
    var myElement = document.getElementById("someId");

    What we are creating is a "Handle" to that place in the DOM. We can use that variable to read properties of the element. You can call methods of the element. You can even change that element. You can use it to go down to the child nodes. You can use it to go up to the parent node.

    What if you don't have an ID or you want more than one element?

    var myListItems = document.getElementsByTagName("li"); //this will become an array
    var myLinks = document.getElementsByTagName("a"); //if you don't have any, the array will be empty

    Those two functions (getElementById and getElementsByTagName) don't always have to be used on "document", they can be used on any element

    Changing DOM elements

    Working with attributes:
    myElement.getAttribute("align"); //name in quotes
    myElement.setAttribute("align","left"); //if the attribute does not exist, it will be created

    Creating elements

    Step 1: Create the element
    Step 2: Put it where it belons in the DOM
    Step 3: If necessary, create a text node

    var myNewElement = document.createElement("li");
    myElement.appendChild(myNewElement); //we pretend that myElement is actually a <ul> somewhere
    var myText = document.createTextNode("New list item text");
    myNewElement.appendChild(myText);

    You could use this method to populate a trivia for example. So you have a list of trivia questions and you randomly pick one and use javascript to populate that area everytime the page loads.

    Alternative to appendchild:
    parent.insertBefore(newElement, existingElement);

    Events

    Examples of events:
    - Page load
    - Button click
    - Mouse scroll
    - Mouse move
    - Form field click
    - Key press
    - ...

    Event names (examples):
    - onload
    - onclick
    - onmouseover
    - onblur (opposite of onfocus, when you leave a form field for example)
    - onfocus

    There are 3 ways you can react to an event in JavaScript:

    1. Handling Events directly in your HTML ==> Not recommended

    <button onclick="alert('Hello,world');">
      //Code
    </button>

    2. Using the element name.event name method ==> Those are all anonymous functions

    window.onload = function(){
      //code
    };

    nameField.onblur = function(){
      //code
    };

    myElement.onclick = function(){
      //code
    }; //Don't forget the semicolon, it is there because of the myElement.onclick stuff, because this is a statement

    In most cases it would work even without the ;, but it's better to put it

    3. Add event listener

    document.addEventListener('click', myFunction, false);

    You can call it on the document object or any element
    'click' => Event
    'myFunction' => the function
    'false' => this is going to be false most of the time, it's for super advanced event handling stuff

    Benefit: You can have one event with multiple listeners (so you can reuse your function basically). You can also remove eventlisteners and put them back throughout your code

    Disadvantage: There is still a different between the browsers. Does not work prior to IE 9

    //IE 8 and previous
    document.attachEvent('onclick', myFunction);

    Here is a function you can use to handle this:

    function addCrossBrowserEventListener (elementName, eventName, functionName){
      //does the addEventListener function exist?
      if (elementName.addEventListener){
        //yes - use it
        elementName.addEventListener(eventName, functionName, false);
        return true;
      } else {
        //otherwise use attachEvent
        elementName.attachEvent("on" + eventName, functioName);
        return true;
      }
    }

    BUT, it is much better to use jQuery or another similar library!

    Useful piece of code:

    function prepareEventHandlers() {
      var myImage = document.getElementById("mainImage");
      myImage.onclick = function() {
        alert("You clicked the image");
      }
    }

    //The window.onload function tells us when the page is fully loaded
    window.onload = function() {
      // prep anything we need to
      prepareEventHandlers();
    };

    With the code above, if you don't have window.onload function and you have your script tag in your HTML in your head section, it won't work because it's trying to grab the image (var myImage = document.getElementById("mainImage");) which does not exist yet

    You should only write a window.onload function ONCE PER PAGE. If multiple javascrip files are using window.onload, only the last one will win. To go around this problem, do this:

    window.addEventListener(‘load’, function () {
    // Your code or function call here.
    }, false);

    Or another option would be to use jQuery:

    $(document).ready(function(){
      //code
    }

    Focus and Blur

    var emailField = document.getElementById("email");

    emailField.onfocus = function() {
      if ( emailField.value == "your email") {
        emailField.value = "";
      }
    };

    emailField.onblur = function() {
      if ( emailField.value == "") {
        emailField.value = "your email";
      }
    };

    This will basically put "your email" as a helper in the e-mail field and remove it when you focus on it. It puts it back if the field is still empty. Notice the .value for form fields

    Timers

    // settimeout is in milliseconds
    setTimeout(functionName,3000); //This only happens once

    // setInterval is also in milliseconds
    setInterval(changeImage,5000); //This happens every 5000 milliseconds

    // Two methods for timers - setTimeout and SetInterval (single / repeating)

    function simpleMessage() {
      alert("This is just an alert box");
    }

    // settimeout is in milliseconds
    setTimeout(simpleMessage,3000);

    var myImage = document.getElementById("mainImage");

    var imageArray = ["_images/overlook.jpg","_images/winery_sign.jpg","_images/lunch.jpg",
      "_images/bigSur.jpg","_images/flag_photo.jpg","_images/mission_look.jpg"];
    var imageIndex = 0;

    function changeImage() {
      myImage.setAttribute("src",imageArray[imageIndex]);
      imageIndex++;
      if (imageIndex >= imageArray.length) {
        imageIndex = 0;
      }
    }

    // setInterval is also in milliseconds
    setInterval(changeImage,5000);

    To stop the interval:

    // setInterval is also in milliseconds
    var intervalHandle = setInterval(changeImage,5000);

    myImage.onclick = function(){
      clearInterval(intervalHandle);
    }

    Forms

    Getting forms and form elements:

    document.forms.frmContact (will get you the form named frmContact)
    document.forms.frmContact.name (this is the name of the field)

    or you can use document.getElementById

    Text fields

    Have a "value" property

    Events:
    - onfocus
    - onblur
    - onchange
    - onkeypress
    - onkeydown
    - onkeyup

    Checkboxes and radio buttons

    Have a "checked" property, true or false

    Events:
    - onclick
    - onchange

    Select list (dropdown or list box)

    Properties:
    - type (possible choices: select-one or select-multiple)
    - selectedIndex (for a select-one)
    - mySelect.options[x].selected (true or false, for a multi-select)

    Events:
    - onchange

    Form Event: onsubmit

    The function you write on onsubmit can be used to validate the form. You can stop the submission of the form by returning false. Do not rely solely on Javascript to validate a form, you should do form validation on the server too.

    Example:

    // handle the form submit event
    function prepareEventHandlers() {
      document.getElementById("frmContact").onsubmit = function() {
        // prevent a form from submitting if no email.
        if (document.getElementById("email").value == "") {
          document.getElementById("errorMessage").innerHTML = "Please provide at least an email address!";
          // to STOP the form from submitting
          return false;
        } else {
          // reset and allow the form to submit
          document.getElementById("errorMessage").innerHTML = "";
          return true;
        }
      };
    }

    // when the document loads
    window.onload = function() {
      prepareEventHandlers();
    };

    Example to show elements that weren't there before when clicking a checkbox:

    // show and hide sections of a form
    function preparePage() {
      document.getElementById("brochures").onclick = function() {
        if (document.getElementById("brochures").checked) {
          // use CSS style to show it
          document.getElementById("tourSelection").style.display = "block";
        } else {
          // hide the div
          document.getElementById("tourSelection").style.display = "none";
        }
      };
      // now hide it on the initial page load so that people who disabled javascript can still get to that information.
      document.getElementById("tourSelection").style.display = "none";
    }

    window.onload = function() {
      preparePage();
    };

    CSS

    You can style elements through javascript by setting their Style property:

    myElement.style.color = "#ff0000";

    example of CSS and equivalent Javascript:

    #example{
      width: 230px;
      color: #fff;
      font-weight: bold;
      background-color: #193742;
    }

    Now the equivalent Javascript:

    myElement.style.width = "230px";
    myElement.style.color: "#fff";
    myElement.style.fontWeight = "bold";
    myElement.style.backgroundColor = "#193742"

    Some elements become camel case because the - means minus in Javascript.

    Setting properties are always set as strings

    Applying a class to an element: myElement.className (not .class)

    Example:

    // prevent a form from submitting
    function preparePage() {
      document.getElementById("mainContent").onclick = function() {
        if ( document.getElementById("mainContent").className == "example") {
          document.getElementById("mainContent").className = "";
        } else {
          document.getElementById("mainContent").className = "example";
        }
      };
    }

    window.onload = function() {
      preparePage();
    };

    Minification

    A few resources to minify your Javascript:

    JSMin
    YUI Compressor
    Google Closure Compiler (web based version: http://closure-compiler.appspot.com/home)

    Javascript Code Checkers

    JSLint (http://jslint.com/)

    Missing use strict: "use strict"; on all your functions, or change the options at the bottom of the screen
    'document' was used before it was defined: In options, assume browser

    Libraries

    https://developers.google.com/closure/library/
    http://mootools.net/
    http://yuilibrary.com/ => Discontinued
    http://jquery.com/
    http://lokeshdhakar.com/projects/lightbox2/
    http://script.aculo.us/
    http://moofx.mad4milk.net/

    Linking several scripts in one HTML file

    Keep them to a minimum: every script is a call by the browser to the server. Combine them as much as possible

    Using a CDN for linking external libraries:
    - Improved speed / redundancy
    - Improved bandwidth
    - Improved parallel downloads
    - Caching benefits (if same file used by various websites)

    More information:
    https://developers.google.com/speed/libraries/
    https://developers.google.com/speed/libraries/devguide

    Google API key is not necessary, you can simply use the "path". You can use http or https.

    Javascript additions in HTML5

    getElementsByClassName (IE9+, otherwise use jQuery)

    video

    <video id="myVideo" controls preload="auto">
      <source src="videofile.mp4 type="video/mp4" />
      <source src="videofile.webm type="video/webm" />
      <source src="videofile.ogv type="video/webm" />
      <!-- if video is not supported -->
      <p>Your browser does not support HTML5 video.</p>
    </video>

    .play();
    .pause();
    .currentTime = 0;

    myVideo.addEventListener("ended", function(){
      //code
    }, false);

    You can assume that if a browser supports the video tag, it will also support addEventListener

    storage

    //set
    localStorage["username"] = name;

    //get
    var name = localStorage["username"];

    web workers

    We'll be able to load JavaScript and make it run in the background, regardless of what else is going on in your page. Similar to multithreading

    var worker = new Worker("anotherjavascriptfile.js");

    The worker cannot directly affect the DOM. It is used to generate events and send them back

    //get ready to receive messages from the worker
    worker.onmessage = function(e){
      console.log("the worker called me!");
    }

    //send messages to the worker
    worker.postMessage("firstFunction");

    Not supported in IE

    feature detection

    if (document.getElementsByClassName){
      //if that function exist, use it
    }
    else{
      //else, find another way! :)
    }

    Basically, if you want to check if a feature exist, just name it in an if statement.

    Modernizr

    http://www.modernizr.com

    Recommended to put the link to this library in the head of your HTML

    Once this is run, what you will have is a javascript object called Modernizr with 40 boolean properties like this to say whether a particular feature is supported or not:

    video: true
    audio: true
    canvas: false
    ...

    if (Modernizr.video){
      // true - you can use HTML5 video
    }
    else{
      //false - perhaps replace with Flash video?
    }

    The full Modernizr library lets you check for every feature of HTML5 and CSS3. You can also download a custom-built version to only check what you are interested in.

    The advanced options of Modernizr helps you load shims or polyfills to replace thee missing features

    Strict mode

    It's a way to volunteer to have your JavaScript held to higher standards. By turning on strict mode, you must declare variables before using them. To volunteer to strict mode, simply add this line to the beginning of your javascript:

    "use strict";

    You can also use it in the first line of a function if you want to do it function by function

    If you combine JavaScript files into one, some of which use Stric and some of which don't, you can wrap your files into an anonymous function so that only that particular file will use Strict:

    (function(){

    //your javascript file

    }());

    If strict mode is turned on, make sure you test your code in a browser that supports it :)

    Javascript to avoid

    Javascript is very popular and there is a LOT of bad javascript out there

    document.write

    document.write("here is some <em>important</em> content");

    Why you should not use it:
    - document.write does not work in XHTML
    - It does not understand the DOM properly
    - Clunky, inflexible way of doing things
    - Can only use it when the page is initially loaded, otherwise it will destroy the content of the page that was there before it ran

    browser sniffing

    if (navigator.userAgent.indexOf('Netscape')...

    or

    if (navigator.appName=='Microsoft Internet Explorer')...

    etc.

    This is old school stuff, it's a giveaway that this is old javascript code because it's not necessary anymore. Any detection you do should be to detect features not browsers.

    EVAL

    EVAL is a powerful function that can take an expression and execute it as code

    Example:

    var a = "alert('";
    var b = "hello world";
    var c = "');";


    // now, we use eval to combine and execute code dynamically
    eval(a + b + c);

    Why you should not use it:
    - There are almost always better way of doing this as opposed to using EVAL
    - This is ugly and hard to figure out what's going on
    - Innefficient
    - Can lead to security problems

    Pseudo-protocols

    <p>Inside your HTML, you may find:
    <a href="javascript:someFunction()">this</a>
    </p>

    It's a way to make a link or a button directly call a function

    - Mixing HTML with script
    - If Javascript is disabled, this is useless

    <p>A preferable way:
    <a href="nojavascript.html" onclick="someFunction();" return false;>this</a>
    </p>

    Here at least you have a backup plan if there is no javascript. The return false is to cancel the browser following the link. Even though it's better, it's not recommended.

    Regular expressions

    1. Create the regular expression

    var myRE = /hello/;
    or
    var myRE = new RegExp("hello");

    2. Testing the Regular Expression

    For the string to match the RegExp, it would need to contain the string "hello"

    var myString = "Does this sentence have the word hello in it?";
    if (myRE.text(myString)){
      alert("Yes");
    }

    myRE.search(myString) would return the postion of the first match

    /^hello/; //hello must be at the start
    /hello$/; //hello must be at the end
    /hel+o/; //previous character (l) has to appear once or more (helo, hello, hellllllllllllllllo)
    /hel*o/; //previous character (l) has to appear zero or more times (heo, hello, hellllllllo)
    /hel?o/; //previous character (l) has to appear zero or one time (heo, helo)
    /hello|goodbye/; //either or
    /he..o/; //. = any character
    /\wello/; \w must be alphanumeric or underscore
    /\bhello/; \b = word boundary (space or new line)
    /[crnld]ope/; // [...] range of chars, so any of those letters (cope, rope, etc. but not zope)

    More complex patterns

    /^[0-9]{5}(?:-[0-9]{4})?$/ US Zip Code with an optional 4 digit extensions

    5 = how many characters
    question mark to say optional

    AJAX

    AJAX: Asynchronous JavaScript and XML

    Ajax doesn't actually require XML, AJAX is JavaScript

    What it means is that after a web page has opened in the user's browser, we can have JavaScript behind the scenes to communicate back to the server, even pass and retrieve data, and update parts of the page without the entire page itself needing to reload. A simple example, if you've used, for example, Google, and started typing, and found it able to start to fill out the information that it thinks you're looking for and actually update the page as you're typing, this is AJAX going on.

    The ability to zoom in and out on maps is also AJAX

    1. Create the request
    2. Deal with any response

    Unfortunately, there is a different way of writing this in different browsers

    var myReqyest;
    //check if the feature exists
    if (window.XMLHttpRequest){
      myRequest = new XMLHttpRequest();
    } else if (window.ActiveXObject){
      myRequest = new ActiveXObject("Microsoft.XMLHTTP");
    }

    //prepare to accept the response
    myRequest.onreadystatechange = function(){
      console.log("We were called!");
      if (myRequest.readyState === 4) { //this is the important state
        var p = document.createElement("p");
        var t = document.createTextNode(myRequest.responseText);
        p.appendChild(t);
        document.getElementById("mainContent").appendChild(p);
      }
    };

    //configure and send
    myRequest.open('GET', 'simple.txt', true); //simple.txt can be replaced by http://mysite.com/somedata.php
    // any parameters?
    myRequest.send(null);

    You can use jQuery so that you don't have to worry about writing the cross browser check

    Prototypes

    Don't confuse with the popular JavaScript library called Prototype (http://prototypejs.org)

    Prototype is used to create objects that share the same structure (and same functions?)

    1. Create a constructor function to make a new object

    function Player(n, s, r) { //Convention -> First letter capital
      this.name = n;
      this.score = s;
      this.rank = r;
    }

    var fred = new Player("Fred", 1000, 5);
    var bob = new Player("Bob", 50, 1);

    2. Use Prototype to create new functions that all objects will share

    Player.prototype.logInfo = function(){
      console.log("I am: ", this.name);
    }

    Player.prototype.promote = function(){
      this.rank++;
      console.log("My new rank is: ", this.rank);
    }

    //logInfo and promote are names I picked myself

    fred.logInfo();
    fred.promote();

    Inheritance

    // the original Animal class and sayName method
    function Animal(name, numLegs) {
      this.name = name;
      this.numLegs = numLegs;
    }
    Animal.prototype.sayName = function() {
      console.log("Hi my name is " + this.name);
    };

    // define a Penguin class
    function Penguin(name) {
      this.name = name;
      this.numLegs = 2;
    }

    // set its prototype to be a new instance of Animal so that it inherits its functions
    Penguin.prototype = new Animal();

    Private Variables

    function Person(first,last,age) {
      this.firstname = first;
      this.lastname = last;
      this.age = age;
      var bankBalance = 7500;
    }

    // create your Person
    var john = new Person("John","Smith",32)

    // try to print his bankBalance
    console.log(john.bankBalance); //This will not print the bankBalance because it is private (var)



    In order to access the private variables:

    function Person(first,last,age) {
      this.firstname = first;
      this.lastname = last;
      this.age = age;
      var bankBalance = 7500;

      this.getBalance = function() {
        // your code should return the bankBalance
        return bankBalance;
      };
    }

    var john = new Person('John','Smith',30);
    console.log(john.bankBalance);

    // create a new variable myBalance that calls getBalance()
    var myBalance = john.getBalance();
    console.log(myBalance);

    Useful Functions

    encoreURIComponent(document.getElementById("english").value); -> will change "Hello World" into "Hello%20World"

    Other sources of help

    https://dev.opera.com/
    https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/
    http://stackoverflow.com/ (type javascript and sort by votes to find interesting articles)

    Other notes

    Global variables are to be avoided at all cost because it's so easy to overwrite other people's variables. So it's better to do:

    (function(){
      ....all your JS code
    }());

    This is an Immediately invoked function expression (IIFE, pronounce iffy)









    [EmberJS]

    parent nodes: Javascript | MVC Frameworks

    Ember JS

    Example of sites built using Ember:
    - discourse.org
    - squareup.com
    - admanager.yahoo.com

    What is Ember

    - Used to build large web apps
    - Ideal for building small web apps
    - Favours "convention over configuration", also called "abstraction" (Ember has many blocks of best-practice conventional javascript code)
    - Ember is based on MVC
      - Models: Describe the data
      - Views: Display the data
      - Controller: sends data to the view
    NOTE: Ember uses other components, especially a Router (lists all the links in your app) So Ember is sometimes described as MVC + R

    Ember routers

    - Prebuild lots of code internally
    - Some code can be ignored, some need configuration
    - Routers are where "convention over configuration" starts (Once you create a route, Ember builds supporting code for you based on common coding conventions.)

    Ember as an SPA (Single Page Application)

    - All the "pages" are contained inside one file (new data loads without a page refresh)
    - SPAs use lots of HTML, CSS and javascript
    - Ember optimizes all this code very well with caching

    Documentation

    Two sections:
    - Guides: http://guides.emberjs.com/v2.0.0/
    - API: http://emberjs.com/api/

    Core Concepts

    http://guides.emberjs.com/v2.0.0/getting-started/core-concepts/

    - Routing
    - Templates
    - Components
