    - Models
    - Controllers

    This class will not discuss:
    - Ember.Object
    - Ember.View

    Ember Starter Kit

    from command prompt, run the following commands:

    npm install -g ember-cli
    ember new my-app

    This will create a starter Ember app. It comes with two CSS files:
    - normalize.css (reset file)
    - style.css

    It also comes with 4 js files:
    - libs > ember-1.16.1.js (Includes functionality that returns some really helpful information about your app to the browser console)
    - libs > handlebars-1.1.2.js (templating engine that Ember uses to load model data into our app)
    - libs > jquery-1.10.2.js
    - app.js (contains some minimal code needed to start Ember app)

    If you run index.html and go to the console, you will have all sorts of info about the app.

    app.js

    App = Ember.Application.create(); //starts the Ember app in a web browser. Ember code won't run if app is not started with this command. App is the default name but you can give any name as long as it starts with a capital letter

    App.Router.map(function() {
      // put your routes here
    });

    App.IndexRoute = Ember.Route.extend({
      model: function() {
        return ['red', 'yellow', 'blue'];
      }
    });

    Tests folder

    The starter kit comes with a tests folder. The test folder contains a testing framework called Q unit, and you can use it to test your Ember code. Now testing code with a tool like Q unit is important and it's something you should strive to do regularly.

    Routes

    Routes are essentially URLs. All the routes need to be grouped as what's known as a "Router".

    Ember uses naming convention to build code once a route is declared:

    - Route Object (It will tell the route what the specific model data is for the page it's loading.)
    - Controller (sends data to the view)
    - Template (smaller versions of views. Ember assumes that the ID of the template is the same as the route name)
    - URL (#/[name of route])

    It is important to note that Ember has a route already created for us (home page)

    To find out the URL of a route, use the Ember tool in Google Chrome

    How to add a route

    1) Go to app.js
    2) Add the following code:

    App.Router.map(function() {
      this.route("about");
      this.route("collections");
      this.resource("exhibits");
      this.route("notes");
    });

    Default Ember Routes

    - Application Route: Renders the primary application template

    There are two routes below the application template information, the loading route and the error route. You use these when you want your route to perform more complicated actions as they load content onto the page, as well as if this loading process generates an error. Using these routes in a project takes a firm understanding of how routes load content asynchronously, as well as understanding a concept known as javascript promises.

    Templates

    Ember uses the Handlebars templating library for creating templates
    Routes point to templates
    The app template is already on the page

    Templates for other pages load into the app template but they need to be told in which spot. That's gets done with what's called an outlet.

    {{outlet}} is known as Handlebars "helper". It loads other tmeplates into the app template

    You can use the "link to" helper for Ember to create the proper URL to the route you want to display on the screen.

    {{#link-to "routeName" class="some-class"}}Some Links{{/link-to}}

    {{outlet}} is called helper
    {{link-to}} is called block helper

    Component

    - Can contain a complete HTML layout
    - Reusable page elements like HTML tags

    Step 1: Create component definition
      <script type="text/x-handlebars" id="components/single-collection"> <!-- MUSTS be two words separated by a dash -->
        <h2>Collections</h2>
        This is the SAMOCA Collections Page
      </script>
    The component definition creates what's known in Ember as a custom element. And it has the same name as the component you just created. You then place this custom element inside your page template

    Ember components are usually displaying data and must be told exactly what that data is.

    Step 2: Display the component
      <script type="text/x-handlebars" id="collections">
        <section class="pageClass clearfix">
          {{single-collection}}
        </section>
      </script>
    When an ember component generates content and loads it into a template, it's automatically placed inside a div tag, but it's simple to change this as well as customize other parts of the component.

    Models

    - Describe application data
    - Model data is placed inside route objects
    - "Model hook": model data defined inside a route object

    Models are the way you describe application data, and in Ember, models are closely tied to the route. We've learned that when a route is created in Ember, it automatically creates a lot of code behind the scenes. And one of these pieces of code is a route object. It's inside this route object where you tell Ember which model data gets passed to which particular template. And this process of defining a template's model data inside of a route object is commonly referred to as creating the model hook.

    We need to build templates for our component related code before loading in the model data.

    Controllers

    - Controllers send model data to views in MVC
    - Controllers send model data to templates in Ember
    - Models aren't aware of templates
    - This makes code efficient

    Two types of controllers in Ember:
    - ObjectController: sends info about 1 piece of data
    - ArrayController: sends info about all the data
    - Controllers can do more: decorate data, format data...

    Nested Routes

    - Nested Routes are Routes within a route (i.e. sub-routes)
    - Load content in the existing and not go to a new page
    - Best to list that as "Resources" instead of routes

    e.g.
    this.resource("exhibits", function(){
      this.resource("exhibit", { path: "/:exhibit_id"});
    });

    getJson()

    - Finds and returns JSON content
    - Works well with jQuery .then() to return "promises"
    - .then() waits for getJSON to load data before working
    - Server functionality is needed to test getJSON()

    Ember Data

    - Manages a "Store": the place where model data is persisted
    - DS.Model: refers to the model properties
    - DS.LSAdapter: stores the model data, like "cookies"
    - Ember data is in beta









    [jQuery]

    parent nodes: Javascript

    j Query

    [camelCaseWordsEnabled: false]

    Step 1 : Download jquery at jquery.com

    Step 2: Call jQuery using this line: (put this in the HEAD section). The jquery version might be different.

    <script type="text/javascript" src="/js/jquery-1.11.1.js"></script>

    jQuery's feature break down in 8 major categories:
    - Core Functionality: Implements core jQuery functions as well as commonly used utilities.
    - Selection and Traversal: functions for finding content in documents and navigating among the contents of the document. query in the jquery name. Traversing the document object model.
    - Manipulation & CSS: functions for editing and changing documents content and working with CSS data such as positioning info.
    - Events: Simplifies working with the modern DOM events such page, keyboard and mouse events and provides a lot of common event helper functions.
    - Effects: Contains functions for creating some basic animations and effects such as hiding and showing elements and moving objects around etc.
    - AJAX: utilities for working with Ajax, such as loading content from pages without refreshing the page and dealing with JSON (javascript object notation data).
    - User Interface (UI): an official plug-in with commonly used interface widgets, like slider controls, progress bars, dialogs, accordions, etc.
    - Extensibility: Enables the construction of jQuery plug-ins that enhance the functionality of the base library.

    Document ready function:

    IMPORTANT NOTE: try.jquery.com thinks that document should have NO QUOTES....
    This function will load when the DOM is ready, even if the images are not quite done loading. If you pile up several functions on top of each other to do that, they will be called in succession.

    $("document").ready (function(){
      alert("the page just loaded!");
    });

    A shortcut of this "document ready" thing would be to do this:
    $(function(){
      alert("the page just loaded!");
    });

    Example of difference between DOM and jQuery

    1) Get all the elements that are paragraphs
    2) Get all tags with ID of list1
    3) Get all li tags with a class of "a"
    4) Get all tags that have a class of "b" but only if they are inside a ul

    DOM:
    1) document.getElementsByTagName("p");
    2) document.getElementsById("list1");
    3) complicated in DOM, requires loop
    4) complicated in DOM

    jQuery:
    1) $("p");
    2) $("#list1"); (similar to CSS)
    3) $("li.a");
    4) $("ul .b");

    Other jQuery selectors

    selector, selector – Finds all of the specified selectors
    .class1.class2 – Finds all elements with both .class1 and .class2 applied
    parent>child – Finds all child elements that are direct children of elements of type parent
    ancestor descendant – Finds all descendant elements that are contained within elements of type ancestor (like #4 above)
    prev+next – Find all next elements that are next to a prev element
    prev~siblings – Find all sibling elements that come after prev and match the siblings selector
    closest: For each element in the set, get the first element that matches the selector by testing the element itself and traversing up through its ancestors in the DOM tree.

    Find number of children: $("#location1").children().length

    Filters

    Types of filters

    Basic: Provides basic filtering, like getting the first, last, and even- and odd-numbered items in a returned set
    Content: Filters a set of elements based on the content, like whether an element contains a particular string
    Visibility: Filters a set of elements using the visibility setting of each element as a test
    Attribute: Examines a given attribute on an element to determine whether it should be filtered out
    Child: Selects elements based upon their relationship with their parent element
    Form: Provides specialized filters that operate on form elements

    Basic filters

    :first – Selects only the first instance of the selector’s returned set
    :last - Selects only the last instance of the selector’s returnet set
    :even – Selects only the even-numbered elements in the selectpr’s returned set
    :odd – Selects only odd-numbered elements in the selector;s returned set
    :eq(n) – Filters out elements that are not positioned at the given index
    :gt(n) – Includes elements that are past the given index
    :lt(n) – Includes elements that are before the given index
    :header – Selects all header elements(H1, H2, H3, etc)
    :animated – Selects all elements that are currently being animated in some way
    :not(selector) – Includes elements that do not match the given selector

    Index number start from 0.

    Examples:
    $("document").ready(function() {
      $("p:first").css("border","3px solid red");
      $("p:odd").css("border","3px solid red");
      $("p:even").css("border","3px solid red");
      $(".classname:first").css("border","3px solid red");
      $(".classname:even").css("border","3px solid red");
      $("p:gt(1)").css("border","3px solid red"); – index will start from 2 (0 and 1 will not be included)
      $("p:not(p:eq(2))").css("border","3px solid red"); – index 2 will be excluded
    });

    Attribute filters

    [attribute] – Includes elements in the result set it they have the specified attribute
    [attribute=value] – Includes elements in the result set if they have the specified attribute and it has the given value
    [attribute!=value] – Includes elements in the result set only if they have the specified attribute and it doesn’t have the given value
    [attribute^=value] – Includes elements that have the specified attribute and it starts with the specified value
    [attribute$=value] – Includes elements that have the specified attribute and it ends with the specified value
    [attribute*=value] – Includes elements that have the specified attribute and it contains the specified value
    [attrFilter1][attrFilterN] – Includes elements that match all of the specified attribute filters

    Example:
    $("document").ready(function() {
      $("p[class]").css("border","3px solid red");
      $("p[id=idname]").css("border","3px solid red");
      $("p[id^=list-item]").css("border","3px solid red"); - Ex: <p id="list-item1″ lang="en-us"></p>
      $("p[id^=list-item][lang*=en-]").css("border","3px solid red"); – Ex: <p id="list-item1″ lang="en-us"></p>
    });

    Content and visibility filters

    :contains(text) – Filters the selection to only include elements that contain the text string
    :empty – Filters the selection to only include empty elements
    :has(selector) – Matches elements that contain at least one element that has the specified selector
    :parent – Matches all elements that are parents(i.e. they contain at least one other element, including text)
    :visible – Filters the selection to only include visible elements
    :hidden – Filters the selection to only include hidden elements

    Child filters

    :nth-child(index)
    :nth-child(even)
    :nth-child(odd)
    :nth-child(equation)
    - Matches elements at index, or even or odd increments, or who match an euation of the form Xn-M (for example 2n or 3n+1)

    :first-child- Matches elements who are the first child of their parent
    :last-child- Matches elements who are the last child of their parent
    :only-child- Matches elements who are the only child of their parent

    Examples:
    $("document").ready(function() {
      $("p:contains(3)").css("border","3px solid red"); – Ex: <p class="test"> This is paragraph 3</p> – contains number 3
      $(":contains(3)").css("border","3px solid red"); – all the elements which contains number 3 : body, div, ul, li and others.
      $("li:contains(3), p:contains(3)").css("border","3px solid red"); – Ex: <p> This is paragraph 3</p> – contains number 3
      $("p:parent(3)").css("border","3px solid red"); – Ex: <p> This is paragraph 3</p> – All p contains content.
      $("ul:has(li[class=a])").css("border","3px solid red"); – Ex:<ul><li class="a">Item 1</li></ul> – only select ul if has inside class a
      $("ul li:nth-child(3)").css("border","3px solid red"); – Only the third li will be highlighted
      $("ul li:last-child").css("border","3px solid red"); – Only the last li will be highlighted
      $("ul li:nth-child(2n)").css("border","3px solid red"); – n start counting from 1
    });

    Form selectors

    :input – Finds all input, select, textarea and button elements
    :text- Finds all text elements
    :password – Finds all password elements
    :radio – Finds all radio button elements
    :checkbox – Finds all checkbox elements
    :submit – Finds all submit elements
    :reset – Finds all reset elements
    :image – Finds all image elements
    :button – Finds all button elements
    :file – Finds all file upload elements
    :enabled – Matches all form elements that are enabled
    :disabled – Matches all form elements that are disabled
    :checked – Matches all form elements that are checked (radiobuttons and checkboxes)
    :selected – Matchels all elements that are selected

    Examples:
    $("document".ready(function() {
      $("form:input").before("INPUT:"); – add "INPUT" before all input elements (checkbox, textarea, button, upload field, etc.)
      $("form:text").before("INPUT:"); – add "INPUT" before all text elements: Ex. <input id="text1″ type="text" />
      $("form:text:disabled").css("display" "none"); – Ex. <input id="text1″ type="text" disabled="disabled" />
      $("form:text:enabled").before("ENABLED:"); – Ex. <input id="text1″ type="text" />
      $("form:checked").before("CHECKED:"); – Ex. <input id="checkbox1″ type="checkbox" /><label>Checkbox 1</label> <input id="radio1″ type="radio" /><label>Radio 1</label>
      $("form:checkbox:checked").before("CHECKED:"); – Ex. <input id="checkbox1″ type="checkbox" /><label>Checkbox 1</label>
    });

    Traversing filters

    size(), lenght – The number of elements in the jQuery result set
    get() – Returns an array of all matched DOM elements. Useful if you need to operate on the DOM elements themselves instead of using built-in jQuery functions
    get(index) – Access a single matched DOM element at a specified index in the matched set
    find(expression) – Searches for descendent elements that match the specified expression
    each(fn) – Execute a function within the context of every matched element

    Examples:
    $("document").ready(function() {
      // alert("There are "+$("p").size() +"<p> elements"); – There are "number" <p> elements
      // alert("There are "+$("p").length +"<p> elements"); – There are "number" <p> elements
      // var elems= $(‘li’).get(); alert("there are "+ elems.lenght + "<li> tags" ) – get all the li tags from the page and show the number using DOM
      // alert ($(‘li’).get(0)); – find the index – get the first li tag- Results: [object HTMLElement]
      // $("ul").find("li.b").css("border" "3px solid red"); – find the elements with b class and add a border to them
      /* var leftmargin – 0;
      var border =3;
      $("p").each(function () {
        $(this).css("border", border + "px solid red");
        $(this).css("margin-left", leftmargin);
        border += 2;
        leftmargin += 10;
      }
    }); */ – The border will gonna get bigger for each <p>, also for left margin.

    Chaining

    $(selector) .fn1().fn2().fn3(); – ".fn1().fn2().fn3();" – Statement chain

    The reason why this makes jQuery so powerful is that it allows you to perform multiple operations on one result set without having to get that result set over and over again, like you might have to do in other scripting conventions.

    Example:
    $("document").ready(function(){
      $("a[href$=.pdf]").after("HTML code"); – Find the <a href=""> elements which ends with .pdf and add a content(text, img etc) after the <a>
    });

    Manipulating HTML Content

    To create new HTML content, you simply pass a string containing the new HTML to the jQuery function.

    Example:
    var newHeader = $("<h1>My New header</h1>");

    Example using variables:
    var myStr = "<h1>My new Header</h1>"
    var newHeader = $(myStr);

    In addition to this method, you can use jQuery's html() and text() methods to get and set content on elements.

    :html() – Returns the HTML content of the first matched element
    :html(newcontent) – Sets the HTML content of every matched element
    :text() – Returns the text content of the first matched element
    :text(newtext) – Sets the text content for all matched elements

    Examples:
    alert($("#list1″).html()); – display all the HTML elements which contains #list1 (list1 is a UL)

    $("#list1″).html("<li>This is a new list item</li>"); Now everything in the UL list1 is removed and replaced by "This is a new list item"

    var newItem = $("<p>This is a new paragraph</p>");
    $("#para2″).html(newItem.html()); */ – it will replace <p id="para2″></p> with the new content

    Manipulating Attributes

    attr(name) – Accesses property on the first matched element. This method makes it easy to retrieve a property value from the first matched element. If the element does not have an attribute with such a name, undefined is returned
    attr(properties) – Sets a series of attributes on all matched elements using an object notation syntax. This is the best used for setting large numbers of properties at once. Ex: $("img").attr({src: "/images/hat.gif", title: "jQuery", alt: "jQuery Logo"});
    attr(key, value) – Sets a single property to a value on all matched elements
    attr(key, fn) – Sets a single property to a computed value, on all matched elements. Instead of supplying a string value, a function is provided that computes the value of the attribute
    removeAttr(name) – Removes the named attribute from all matched elements.

    Examples:
    $("a").attr("target", "_blank" ); – open all <a> tags in a new tab
    $("a").removeAttr("href"); – will turn off the link
    $("img").attr({src:"images/spring.jpg", alt:"spring"}); – will change the image and add a different alt tag

    Checking a checkbox: $('#location1 input').attr('checked', 'true')
    Selecting a specific option in a select box: $('#location1 select').val('target2');

    Read this for difference between attr and prop: https://api.jquery.com/prop/

    Inserting content

    append(content) – Appends content to the inside of every matched element
    appendTo(selector) – Appends all of the matched elements to another, specified, set of elements
    prepend(content) – Prepends content to the inside of every matched element
    prependTo(selector) – Prepends all the matched elements to another, specified, set of elements
    after(content) – Insert content after each of the matched elements
    before(content) – Inserts content before each of the matched elements
    insertAfter(selector) – Insert all of the matched elements after another, specified, set of elements
    insertBefore(selector) – Insert all the matched elements before another, specified set of elements

    Examples:
    $("p").append("with some content appended"); – add a text after the text from paragraph
    $("p").prepend("Hello! "); – add a text before the text from a paragraph
    $("p:last").appendTo("p:first"); - add the last paragraph under the first paragraph
    $("p:last").prependTo("p:first"); - add the last paragraph to be the first paragraph

    Wrapping, replacing and removing content

    wrap(html) – Wraps each matched element with the specified HTML content
    wrap(element) – Wraps each matched element with the specified element
    wrapAll(html) – Wraps all the elements in the matched set with the specified HTML content
    wrapAll(element) – Wraps all the elements in the matched set into a single wrapper element
    weapInner(html) – Wraps the inner child contents of matched elements(including text nodes)with an HTML structure
    wrapInner(element) – Wraps the inner child contents of each matched element(including text nodes)with a DOM structure
    replaceWith(content) – Replace all matched elements with the specified HTML or DOM elements
    replaceAll(selector) -Replaces the elements matched by the specified selector with the matched elements
    empty() – Remove all child nodes from the set of matched elements
    remove() – Removes all matched elements from the DOM
    clone() – clone matched DOM elements and selects the clones
    clone(bool) – Clone matched DOM elements, and all their event handlers, and select the clones

    Examples:
    $("p").wrap("<div style=’color:red’/> "); – p without class will be added in a div with red color
    $("p").wrapAll("<div style=’border: 2px solid red’ />"); – All <p> will be added in a div with 2px border
    $("ul").empty();

    Working with CSS

    css(name) – Returns the value for the named CSS property for the first matched element
    css(properties) – Sets the css properties of every matched element using an object-notation syntax:
    var cssObj – {
    ‘background-color’ : ‘$DDD’,
    ‘font-weight’ : ‘normal’,
    ‘color’ : ‘rgb(0,40,244)’
    }
    $(this).css(cssobj);
    css(property, value) – Sets a single style property to a value of all mathed elements. If a number is provided, it is automatically converted into a pixel value, with the following expeptions: z-index, font-weight, opacity, zoom, and line-height.

    addClass(class) – Adds the specified class(es) to each of the set of matched elements
    hasClass(class) – Returns true if the specified class is present on at least one of the set pf matched elements
    removeClass(class) – Removes all the specified class(es) from the set of matched elements
    toggleClass(class) – Adds the specified class if is not present, removes the specified class if is present
    toggleClass(class,switch) – Adds the specified class if the switch is true, removes the specified class if the switch is false
    offset() – Gets the current offset of the first matched element, in pixels, relative to the document
    offsetParent() – Returns a jQuery collection with the positioned parent of the first matched element
    position() – Gets the top and left position of an element relative to its offset parent
    scrollTop() – Gets the scroll top offset of the first matched element
    scrollTop(val) – Sets the scroll top offset to the given value oon all matched elements
    scrollLeft() – Gets the scroll left offset of the first matched element
    scroll Left(val) – Sets the scroll left offset to the given value on all matched elements
    height() – Gets the current computed, pixel, height of the first matched element
    height(val) – Sets the CSS height of every matched element
    width() – Gets the current computed, pixel, width of the first matched element
    width(val) – Sets the CSS width of every matched element
    innerHeight() – Gets the inner height(excluding the border and including the padding)for the first matched element
    innerWidth() – Gets the inner width(excluding the border and including the padding)for the first matched element
    outerHeight(margin) - Gets the outer height(includes the border and padding by default) for the first matched element. If the margin argument is true, then the margin value are also included
    outerWidth(margin) – Gets the outer width(includes the border and padding by default)for the first matched element. If the margin argument is true, then the margin value are also included

    Examples:
    $("#height").html($("#theDiv").height()); – add the height as a number from an ID
    $("#width").html($("#theDiv").width()); - add the width as a number from an ID
    $("#innerH").html($("#theDiv").innerHeight());
    $("#innerW").html($("#theDiv").innerWidth());
    $("#outerH").html($("#theDiv").outerHeight());
    $("#outerW").html($("#theDiv").outerWidth());
    $("#offset").html($("#theDiv").offset().top + ", " + $("#theDiv").offset().left);
    $("#position").html($("#theDiv").position().top + ", " + $("#theDiv").position().left);

    Functions

    function showTicket(){
      //closest searches UP, find searches DOWN, slideDown will show stuff that have .ticket class (it starts in display: none)
      $(this).closest('.confirmation').find('.ticket').slideDown();
    }

    $(document).ready(function(){
      //Do not put () after the function name, otherwise it gets executed right away!
      $('.confirmation').on('click', 'button', showTicket);
    });

    Data()

    This is how you store:
    .data( key, value )
    .data( obj )

    This is how you retrieve:
    .data( key )
    .data()

    the function removeData() is used to empty the data

    Example (3 buttons called "store", "remove" and "show"):

    $("document").ready(function(){
      $("store").click(function(){
        $("#div1").data("key1", 1234);
        $("#div1").data("key2", "Joe Smith");
      });
      $("remove").click(function(){
        $("#div1").removeData();
      });
      $("show").click(function(){
        alert($("#div1").data("key1"));
        alert($("#div1").data("key2"));
      });
    });

    As part of HTML5, you can do the following:

    <div id="div1" data-key3="data attribute">Sample Div</div>

    So now key3 can be used by jQuery data(). You can show the value:
    alert(JSON.stringify($("#div1″).data(),null," " ));

    Results: "key3″ : "data attribute"

    Events

    Working with events through the DOM is complicated because each browser works differently

    Binding/Unbinding: Allows events to be wired up and torn down in a cross-browser fashion. Events are connected to and disconnected from elements using the bind() and unbind() functions.

    Unified Event Object:Provides an event object that exposes the most common properties in a cross-browser fashion.

    Convenience Functions: Provides functions that encapsulate common event features and cross-browser helper routines.

    .on(): attaches an event handler
    .off(): removes an event handler

    Note: bind/unbind, die/live are from older versions of jQuery

    Example: On mouse over, the class will be toggled between highlight and not. On click, the toggle event will be removed.

    <script type="text/javascript">
    $(function() {
      $("#evtTarget").on("mouseover mouseleave", highlight); //or you could have used $("#evtTarget").hover(highlight, highlight)
      $("#evtTarget").on("click", function(evt) {
        $("#evtTarget").off("mouseover mouseleave", highlight);
        $("#evtTarget").html("<p>You shut off the hover effect!</p>");
      });
    });

    function highlight(evt) {
    $("#evtTarget").toggleClass("highlighted");
    }

    On click can have several arguments:
    $('.vacation').on('click', button, function(){}); //will only launch when you click a BUTTON. This is called event delegation.

    Here is a list of Mouse Events:
    - click
    - dlbclick
    - focusin
    - focusout
    - mousedown
    - mouseup
    - mousemove
    - mouveout
    - mouveover
    - mouseleave
    - mouseenter (similar to hover?)

    List of Keyboard Events:
    - keypress
    - keydown
    - keyup

    List of Form Events:
    - blur
    - select
    - change
    - focus
    - submit

    jQuery Event Object

    type – Type of the event("click",e.g)
    target – Element that issued the event
    data – Data passed to bind function
    pageX, pageY – Coordinates of mouse when event happened, relative to document
    result – Value returned by the last handler function (unless it is undefined)
    timestamp – Time when event occurred (in milliseconds)
    preventDefault() – Prevents the browser from executing the default action
    isDefaultPrevented() – Returns whether preventDefault() was ever called on this object
    stopPropagation() – Stops the bubbling of an event to parent elements
    isPropagationStopped() – Returns whether stopPropagation() was ever called on this object

    Example:
    <script type="text/javascript">
    $(function() {
      $("div").click(function(evt) {
      $(this).html("pageX: " + evt.pageX + ", pageY: " + evt.pageY + ", type: " + evt.type + ", target: " + evt.target);
      });
    });
    </script>

    Prevent Default:
    For example if you click on "show comments", if the button is way below, the "a href=#" will cause the browser to jump back up at the top of the page because that's the default behaviour. Prevent Default will make sure you don't jump up at the top of the page.

    Miscellaneous jQuery Event Functions

    on(type,data,handler) - Works the same as bind(), but the event handler is only ever executed one time for each matched element

    trigger(event,data) - triggers an event on every matched element. This will also cause the default action of the browser to be executed. For example, passing 'click' to the trigger() function will also cause the browser to act as though the item were clicked.

    triggerHandler(event, data) - Triggers all bound event handlers on an element (for a specific event type) withouth executing the browser's default actions, bubbling, or live events. Only works on the first matched element in the result set for selector.

    <script type="text/javascript">
      $(function() { // onload handler
        $("div").on("click", function(evt){
          $(this).css({background: "red", cursor: "auto"});
        });
      });
    </script>

    Animation and effects

    Functions for showing and hiding elements:

    show() - Displays each of the set of matched elements, if they are hidden.
    show(speed,callback) - shows all matched elements using a graceful animation. Fires an optional callback after completion.
    hide(speed,callback) - Hides all matched elements using graceful animation. Fires an optional callback after completion
    toggle() - Toggles displaying each of the set of matched elements
    toggle(switch) - Toggles displaying each of the set of matched elements based upon the switch (true shows all elements, flase hides all elements)
    toggle(speed,callback) - toggles displaying each of the set of matched elements using a gracefuls animation and firing an optional callback after completion.

    Fade in an out functions:

    fadeIn(speed, callback) - Fades in all matched elements by adjusting their opacity and firing an optional callback after completion
    fadeOut(speed, callback) - Fades out all matched elements by adjusting their opacity to 0 and then setting display to "none" and firing an optional callback after completion
    fadeTo(speed, opacity, callback) - Fades the opacity of all matched elements to a specified opacity and fires an optional callback after completion.

    Examples:
    <script type="text/javascript">
      $(function() {
        $("#fadein").click(function() {
          $("#theDiv").fadeIn("normal");
        });
        $("#fadeout").click(function() {
          $("#theDiv").fadeOut(4000, function(){
          alert("Done fading out")});
        });
        $("#fadeto3").click(function() {
          $("#theDiv").fadeTo("slow", 0.3);
        });
        $("#fadeup").click(function() {
          $("#theDiv").fadeTo("slow", 1.0);
        });
      });
    </script>

    Slide functions:

    slideDown(speed, callback) - Reveals all, matched elements by adjusting their height and firing an optional callback after completion
    slideUp(speed, callback) - Hides all matched elements by adjusting their height and firing an optional callback after completion
    SlideToggle(speed, callback) - Toggles the visibility of all matched elements by adjusting their height and firing an optional callback after completion

    Examples:

    <script type="text/javascript">
      $(function() {
        $("#slideup").click(function() {
          $("#theDiv").slideUp(4000, function(){
            alert("slide complete");
          });
        });
        $("#slidedown").click(function() {
          $("#theDiv").slideDown("normal");
        });
        $("#toggle").click(function() {
          $("#theDiv").slideToggle("slow");
        });
      });
    </script>

    Custom animations:

    animate(params, duration, easing, callback) - Creates a custom animation
      a. params: the properties on the elements to animate
      b. duration: the number of milliseconds the animation should take. (if you don't set anything, default is 400). Pass "slow" for 600 ms, "fast" for 200 ms.
      c. easing: the type of easing function to use (linear or swing) [must install plugins for more functions]
      d. callback: the function to call when the animation is complete.
    animate(params,options) - Creates a custom animation
      a. params: the properties to animate
      b. options: set of options for the animation to take
    stop() - Stops all the currently running animations on all the specified elements.

    <script type="text/javascript">
      $(function() {
        $("#right").click(function() {
          $("#theDiv").animate({ width: "500px" }, 1000);
        });
        $("#text").click(function() {
          $("#theDiv").animate({ fontSize: "24pt" }, 1000);
        });
        $("#toggle").click(function() {
          $("#theDiv").animate({ left: "500" }, 1000, "swing");
        });

        $("#multiple").click(function() {
          $("#theDiv").animate({ width: "500px", fontSize: "24pt", left: "500" }, 1000, "linear");
        });
      });
    </script>

    JQUERY UI LIBRARY

    http://jqueryui.com/

    Provides a prebuild set of functionality that gives your pages a polished professional look and feel.

    1. Interactions:
      - draggable
      - droppable
      - resizable
      - selectable
      - sortable
    2. Widgets:
      - Accordia
      - Datepicker
      - Progressbar
      - Dialog
      - Slider
      - Tabs
    3. Effects:
      - Add class
      - Remove Class
      - Toggle Class
      - Switch Class
      - Hide
      - Show
      - Toggle
      - Color Animation
    Step 1: Download jQuery UI

    Several ways:
    1) Custom download button from the main page, let's you customize what to download
    2) Stable quick download (zip file of current library)
    3) Legacy download (1 version back)

    Step 2: Add the script and css calls in the head section of your html:

    <link href="css/jquery-ui.min.css" rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" />
    <script type="text/javascript" src="scripts/jquery-1.11.1.min.js"></script>
    <script type="text/javascript" src="scripts/jquery-ui.min.js"></script>

    Step 3: Use whatever you want from jQuery UI :)

    AJAX
    Using AJAX, your web pages can retrieve data from remote services and communicate with your web server without having to reload the entire page.

    $.ajax() to make a request to the server and get a response back.

    jQuery.get(): Load data from the server using a HTTP GET request.
    jQuery.getJSON(): Load JSON-encoded data from the server using a GET HTTP request.
    jQuery.getScript(): Load a JavaScript file from the server using a GET HTTP request, then execute it.
    jQuery.post(): Load data from the server using a HTTP POST request.
    .load(): Load data from the server and place the returned HTML into the matched element.

    Example:

    <script type="text/javascript">
      $(function() {
        getData();
      });

      function getData(){
        $.ajax({
          url: "testdata.txt",
          type: "GET",
          dataType: "text",
          success: successFn,
          error: errorFn,
          complete: function(xhr, status){
            console.log("The request is complete!");
          }
        });
      }

      function successFn(result){
        console.log("Setting result");
        $("#content").append(result);
      }


      function errorFn(xhr, status, strError){
        console.log("There was an error!");
      }

    </script>

    But, an even shorter way of doing the exact same thing as above would be:
    <script type="text/javascript">
    $(function() {
      getData();
    });

    function getData(){
      $("#content").load("testdata.txt");
    }

    </script>

    See ajax.html to ajax3.html for more examples (in jQuery folder > AJAX on Bluehost)

    Other Ajax functions, although these are not functions that you call, these are functions that get called FOR you (and if you define them, you can add behaviours to them)

    .ajaxComplete(): Register a handler to be called when Ajax requests complete. This is an AjaxEvent.
    .ajaxError(): Register a handler to be called when Ajax requests complete with an error. This is an Ajax Event.
    .ajaxSend(): Attach a function to be executed before an Ajax request is sent. This is an Ajax Event.
    .ajaxStart(): Register a handler to be called when the first Ajax request begins. This is an Ajax Event.
    .ajaxStop(): Register a handler to be called when all Ajax requests have completed. This is an Ajax Event.
    .ajaxSuccess(): Attach a function to be executed whenever an Ajax request completes successfully. This is an Ajax Event.

    Example:

    Chrome

    If you have a script you want to put a break point to, look under "source", find wherever your code is, put breakpoints and refresh the page.

    If you want to put some text in the console log, do it like this:
    console.log("AJAX starting");

    Then you can look at the console by doing "inspect element" anywhere and switching to the console tab

    Notes from Pluralsight training

    jquery 1.9: supports ie6+
    jquery 2.0: support ie9+

    you can actually use server side detection. If the browser used is ie8 or below, use jquery 1.9, otherwise use jquery 2.0 either using:
    - server side detection
    - client side contional comments

    <!--[if lt IE9]>
    <scrit src="jquery-10.2.1.min.js"></script>
    <![endif]-->
    <!--[if gte IE9]><!-->
    <script src="jquery-2.0.2.min.js"></script>
    <!--[endif]-->

    The jQuery document ready function fires when the DOM is done loading, regardless if images or other assets are still loading.









    [jQuery Plugins]

    parent nodes: Javascript

    j Query Plugins

    [camelCaseWordsEnabled: false]

    Finding good plugins:
    http://plugins.jquery.com
    http://jquery-plugins.net

    Plugin Considerations

    - Licences
    - Update history
      - Active updates?
    - Support
    - Documentation
    - Security reviews
    - Minimized

    Consider adding an abstraction layer. For example, if you use a pop-up plugin, put the plugin in a separate JS file and call that particular file every time you want to do a pop-up. This way, you only need to replace the plugin in one place as opposed to replacing it everywhere in case you decide to change the plugin.

    jQuery Cycle

    jQuery Cycle: http://jquery.malsup.com/cycle2/

    Overview
    Cycle2 is a versatile slideshow plugin for jQuery built around ease-of-use. It supports a declarative initialization style that allows full customization without any scripting. Simply include the plugin, declare your markup, and Cycle2 does the rest.

    Highlights:
    - Supports all browsers
    - Declarative: no scripting needed!
    - Responsive: fully control your slideshow via css (resize this page to see!)
    - Customizable: per-slide option overrides
    - Extensible: fully customizable API (on a per-slideshow basis if you wish)
    - Smart: supports image loading and delayed initialization
    - Smarter: supports progressive image loading
    - Out-of-the-box functionality for pagers, captions, overlays, and prev/next controls
    - Support for swipe gesture on mobile devices
    - Fade, scroll, shuffle, tile and carousel transitions
    - Bookmarkable slides
    - And lots more!

    How it Works
    It's very simple really, even your grandmother could use it. It goes like this:

    Include jQuery and the Cycle2 plugin on your page.
    Declare your slideshow markup as shown in the numerous demos.
    Sit back and enjoy your slideshow while sipping a cool beverage.
    Need more details? Ok, here's the deal: Cycle2 provides a plugin function called cycle. That function is invoked on a container element. Each image in the container becomes a "slide". Options control how and when the slides are transitioned. But here's the thing... you don't have to call cycle and pass your options. You declare your options as attributes on the slideshow element and Cycle2 grabs them from there.

    What's that you say? You'd rather set your options via script than in the markup? Ok fine, have it your way. You don't have to declare your options in the markup (but it's fun!), you can invoke cycle from your own code and pass your options in the old-fashioned way. You can even grab hold of the API object and inject your own implementation of any of the API methods that you choose.

    Responsive
    Use media queries... don't use media queries... whatever. Cycle2 doesn't care; it's the honeybadger of slideshows plugins. Most of the demos on this site use fluid slideshow designs where the slideshow size adjusts as the window is resized. This is accompolished by a simple style rule like this: .cycle-slideshow { width: 45% }. Your slideshows can be fixed-width or fluid-width, or they can adapt to media query breakpoints. You decide.

    jQuery Migrate

    jquery-migrate: Migrate older jQuery code to jQuery 1.9+
    This plugin can be used to detect and restore APIs or features that have been deprecated in jQuery and removed as of version 1.9. See the warnings page for more information regarding messages the plugin generates. For more information about the changes made in jQuery 1.9, see the upgrade guide and blog post.

    In your web page, load this plugin after the script for jQuery:

    <script src="http://code.jquery.com/jquery-1.9.0.js"></script>
    <script src="http://code.jquery.com/jquery-migrate-1.2.1.js"></script>

    The plugin can be included with versions of jQuery as old as 1.6.4 to identify potential upgrade issues via its JQMIGRATE console warnings. However, the plugin is only required for version 1.9.0 or higher to restore deprecated and removed functionality.

    The uncompressed version has diagnostics which will write warnings to developer tools console. You can also use the object jQuery.migrateWarnings to check what the warnings are.
    alert(jQuery.migrateWarnings);

    The jQuery team recommends that you always start updating your version of jQuery by including jQuery Migrate plugin to see if it gives you any warnings. Once you prove that there are no warnings, you can remove that plugin.

    Image plugins

    Slideshow: http://malsup.com/jquery/cycle2
    Image zoom: http://www.mind-projects.it/projects/jqzoom/
    Image overlays: http://www.sitepoint.com/30-text-captions-overlay-image-plugins/
    Lazy Load images: http://www.appelsiini.net/projects/lazyload










    [MVC Frameworks]

    parent nodes: Javascript

    MVC Frameworks

    Top three:

    AngularJS
    EmberJS
    [Backbone]

    Ember and Angular favours "convention over configuration"
    Extensive documentation
    Define core concepts

    Angular is easier to get started with

    Backbone is a "Library"
    Backbone requires more configuration, Ember requires less which means Backbone has more flexibility
    Ember has more docs











    [Node.js]

    parent nodes: Javascript

    Node.js

    [camelCaseWordsEnabled: false]

    What is Node.js? It allows you to build scalable network applications using JavaScript on the server-side.

    What can you build?
    - Websocket Server (like a chat server)
    - Fast File Upload Client
    - Ad Server
    - Any Real-Time Data Apps

    What it's NOT:
    - A Web Framework (it will not replace Rails or django)
    - For beginners
    - Multi-threaded

    Blocking Code:
    Read File from Filesystem and set equal to "contents"
    Print Contents
    Do Something else

    Non-Blocking code
    Read File from Filesystem
      Whenever you're complete, print the contents
    Do something else

    The "Whenever you're complete" part is a "callback"

    So basically it will start reading the file and start doing something else. When the file is done reading, it'll jump back to print the contents.

    In code, it would look like this

    Blocking code:
    var contents = fs.readFileSync('/etc/hosts');
    console.log(contents);
    console.log('Doing something else');

    Non-Blocking code:
    fs.readFileSync('/etc/hosts', function(err, contents){
      console.log("contents");
    });
    console.log('Doing something else');

    OR

    var callback = function(err, contents){
      console.log("contents");
    }

    fs.readFileSync('/etc/hosts', callback);

    First Hello World application

    hello.js
    var http = require('http');
    http.createServer(function(request, response){
      response.writeHead(200); //Status code in header
      response.write("Hello World!");
      response.end(); //Close the connection
    }).listen(8080); //Listen for connections on this port
    console.log('Listening on port 8080');

    $node hello.js

    $curl http://localhost:8080
    but for Bluehost, use: $curl http://69.195.124.238:8080

    The first time the computer goes through the code, node registers the events into a list of known events. In our case there is only one: Request. Once Node is done going through the script, it starts an Event Loop that basically constantly checks for new events. Once an event is fired, the callback code gets executed (that's what's in our function)

    Long running process example
    hello.js
    var http = require('http');
    http.createServer(function(request, response){
      response.writeHead(200); //Status code in header
      response.write("Dog is running");
      setTimeout(function(){
        response.write("Dog is done");
        response.end();
      }, 5000);
    }).listen(8080); //Listen for connections on this port
    console.log('Listening on port 8080');


    Now we have two events: Request and Timeout

    Other notes

    readFileSync is a "blocking" function. Use readFile instead.

    NodeJS training from Lynda.com

    nodejs is basically javascript without a browser
    It uses the same engine as Google Chrome

    Reason why using node: you can use javascript both for front end and back end

    Another reason to use node, is that it allows you to use the same JavaScript on the front end as the back end. Among other features the package called browserify allows you to bundle javascript from the back end and serve it to your front end application. And then finally another reason to use node is that it has native support for evented programming.

    You can install node through a normal install file. Disadvantage: when it's time to update, you have to go through that same install process again. Switching versions also requires reinstallation

    Another way of install node is through npm (which I think is what I did). Install any version quickly, switch between versions quickly, easily install on Linux.

    Differences between nodejs and javascript

    Node adds a few functions and objects not typically available in web browers. It also removes a few that you may be familar with.

    There are a few variables that you may be familiar with from the web browser. There's window, location, and document.

    The window object has functions and attributes that have to do with the window that's being drawn on the screen. And similarly, the location object has all the information about the URL that we've loaded. And then finally, there's a document object. This document object contains all of the HTML that's being displayed on the page. Those three objects do not exist in node.

    Now let's type "global". Now, depending on what page you're on, you're either going to get a reference error saying that global is not defined, or you're going to get an instance of a window object. That window object is going to be similar to the one that you get when you just type in window. On the other hand, when you go over to Node, type in global, and you get an entire object. This object has several functions that are not avalable in Google Chrome.

    Require is used to pull in different JavaScript files that you are using during the course of programming your application. It's not available in Google Chrome. There are other globals that have been provided in Node that are not available in Chrome. One of them is module, and the other one is process. And if we go back over here to Google Chrome and type in module, and if we type in process, both of those return reference errors. So module is used to define a self-contained piece of code, and it's something that's very handy in Node. And then there's also the process object. It has functions and properties that have to do with the running Node process.

    Require module

    Example 1.js

    var announce = require('./announce');

    announce('Node Essential Training');

    the first line means that the file announce.js will be called.

    In announce.js:

    module.exports = function (announcement) {
      console.log('Announcing: ' + announcement);
    };

    Everything in module.exports will be exported, if there was something else in the file, it wouldn't be exported. Right now module.exports is a function but it could be anything else (variable, object, etc.)

    back to example1.js, since we set the stuff exported as a function, announce in example1.js becomes a function

    What's located in require could be a js file or it could be a folder, as long as it contains an index.js file in it.

    Example2.js:
    var relay = require('./relay');

    prefix = "Attention: ";

    relay('Ticket counter closes at 10PM');

    relay.js:
    prefix = 'Relaying: ';

    module.exports = function (message) {
      console.log(prefix + message);
    };

    By running node example2.js, prefix from relay.js will get overwritten by example2.js because it behaves as a global variable. If you add "var" in front of it:
    var prefix = 'Relaying: ';

    module.exports = function (message) {
      console.log(prefix + message);
    };

    Now it acts as a local variable and it will say "relaying" not "attention".

    Here is a way of exporting objects with various properties (functions):
    exports.softly = function (message) {
      console.log('proclaiming: ' + message);
    };

    exports.loudly = function (message) {
      console.log('PROCLAIMING: ' + message);
    };

    Another type of require:
    var os = require('os');

    console.log('This code is running on: ' + os.type());

    When we don't use ./ it tells node that we want to use a core module.

    Modules form fundamental building blocks for programs running in Node. They give you a way of arranging code into convenient, self contained objects.

    Loop

    When a Node program starts, the event loop starts along with it automatically. Now, in contrast to many other environments, all input and output in Node is non blocking. So for instance, if you're making a call to a database, in many other environments, that call is going to block.

    The environment is going to wait for all those results to come back from the database, stop your program, and then resume your program once those results are ready. Node however, keeps running the program.

    server.js:
    var http = require('http');

    var handleRequest = function (req, res) {
      res.writeHead(200, {'Content-Type': 'text/plain'});
      res.end('Welcome to Node Essential Trainingn');
    };

    var server = http.createServer(handleRequest);

    server.listen(3000, 'localhost');

    The node program will never end unless you ask it to, it will constantly listen for new requests on port 3000. As soon as it has a request, it will run the handleRequest function.

    When I build a web server in Node, that server keeps running until I stop it. One of the side effects, is that when I set a variable to a specific value, it will still be set the next time someone reaches the page.

    Node runs all of the code in a program at once, then waits for all callback functions to finish. It's possible to write a callback function that never finishes, which keeps a program running until it's forcibly stopped.

    Project

    The best way to start a project in Node is to create a package.json file. We can use npm to generate a package.json file.

    Create a folder for your project, navigate to your folder in cmd and type npm init

    Fill the questionnaire (you can keep some defaults). test command will be used later to run some unit test, if you don't use it you can leave it blank. Git repository can also be left blank.

    Author: Claudie Larouche <claudielarouche@gmail.com>

    You now have your package.json file!

    Downloading modules

    The Node community provide thousands of modules beyond what's included in Node core. All of the community provided modules are available on npmjs.org.

    npm install --save express (the --save means that we will record the version of express that we're installing as we install it in package.json) A dependencies line was added to package.json

    Now we create a new file called index.js

    Express will allow us to create routes on this application.

    Common npm commands

    npm install -g express (this installs express as a global module)
    express airline

    This will create an Airline project for us. (please note that in order for these two steps to work, you actually need to install an older version of express: npm install -g express@3.4.x)

    There are two dependencies now in my airline project, express and jade. Jade is a templating engine that works with express.

    npm install to install the needed modules.

    Thanks to package.json, we can start the app by doing npm start, because package.json contains this:
    "scripts": {
      "start": "node app.js"
      },
    If you are cleaning up your json file and removing all sorts of module, you can then run npm prune to remove those folders from your node_modules folder.

    npm update will update all your dependencies that have a "*" to the latest version, it will also update everything else to the highest acceptable level.

    building your own module

    index.js
    var number, origin, destination;

    exports.setNumber = function(num){
      number = num;
    }

    exports.setOrigin = function(orig){
      origin = orig;
    }

    exports.setDestination = function(dest){
      destination = dest;
    }

    exports.getInfo = function(){
      return {
        number: number,
        origin: origin,
        destination: destination
      }
    }

    Those are getters and setters and they are set as exports so that I can access them. I put var in front of the variables to make them local instead of global.

    To use the module:

    app.js:
    var flight = require('./flight');

    flight.setOrigin('LAX');
    flight.setDestination('DCA');
    flight.setNumber('363');

    console.log(flight.getInfo());

    [PHP]

    parent nodes: WebDesign

    PHP

    [camelCaseWordsEnabled: false]

    Includes
    To add a link to a php file which contains your header or footer, you do like this

    <?php include("../includes/layouts/header.php"); ?>

    Or another option is to like this, which is good for functions that would fail if we include them more than once by mistake. You will also get an error if the page doesn't manage to include the file for some reason.

    <?php require_once("../includes/functions.php"); ?>

    5 steps of database connectivity

    1. Create a database connection
    2. Perform database query
    3. Use returned data (if any)
    4. Release returned data
    5. Close database connection

    Constants instead of variables

    define("DB_SERVER", "127.0.0.1");
    define("DB_USER", "onehour6_widget");
    define("DB_PASS", "xkVr5K45vhZND7rg%");
    define("DB_NAME", "onehour6_widget_corp");

    // 1. Create a database connection
    $connection = mysqli_connect(DB_SERVER, DB_USER, DB_PASS, DB_NAME);

    DB_SERVER instead of $db_server

    [Testing]

    [Testing Accessibility]

    parent nodes: Testing

    Testing Accessibility

    [camelCaseWordsEnabled: false]

    Install Firefox and following toolbars:

    - WAVE toolbar
    - web developer toolbar
    - accessibility evaluation toolbar

    1. Is the title related to the page content?

    2. Is the content still readable and functional when resized to 200%?
      View > Zoom > Zoom text only
    3. Can you navigate the page without the mouse?
      Make sure there are no traps
      Proper tab order
    4. Do all images have text version?
      Avoid use of image of text.
      Same image should not necessarily have same alt text
      Firefox extension: Images->Display alt Attributes
      If you have a complicated chart, you can add a text version link underneath which will open the data table or explain in words.
      Decorative images must have empty alt tags
    5. Is the page well structured with proper headings?
      heading should not be used to format the text
      WAVE toolbar: Outline
      Toolbar: CSS->Disable Style->Disable all style (make sure everything in proper order because screen reader will read the page in the order it's coded)
    6. Where is the link taking you?
      Click every single link to make sure it works
      You don't want to have two link texts going to same place
      Not just "read more", "read more about session 1"
    7. Can you see, hear, read and control the video?

    8. Is the form clear and easy to use?
      Also make sure there is error validation
      Make sure there is a label for each form control
      Toolbar: Form -> Display Form Details
      Toolbar: Errors, Features and Alerts which will tell you if labels are missing (and other potential problems I suppose)
    9. Is the colour contrast sufficient?
      Never use colour to give information ("click on the blue button")
      Colour Contrast Analyzer
    10. Can you identify the language in which your content is presented?
      Toolbar: Navigation > Language changes
    11. Is the page coded according to specifications?









    [Testing Speed]

    parent nodes: Testing

    Testing Speed

    [camelCaseWordsEnabled: false]

    1) Right click inspect element to go into Chrome's DevTools
    2) Go in the Network tab
    3) Hold SHIFT so that everything gets redownloaded even if you have them already on your machine
    4) Refresh the page
    5) Investigate!

    You can also do a new incognito window which will also make sure no cookies are used.

    The pale part of the graph is the start when the browser started requesting the resource
    The darker part is when the resource started being downloaded

    The colour code is the filetype.

    You can click on each filename to investigate if it has the proper cache settings.

    Consider adding async attribute to your javascript calls if you only need javascript for user interaction AFTER the page is done loading.

    Make sure your CSS comes before your Javascript

    Timeline

    The timeline tab allows you to figure out your frame per seconds. Click on the "recording" button to start recording, and then interact with your page. Stop the recording and go to the Frames tab. The page will be filled with colours:

    Green: Painting
    Purple: Rendering (style recalculation)
    Yellow: Scripting
    Blue: HTML

    The highest the frame rate, the better.

    CPU Profiling

    Click on the Profile page and select "Collect Javascript CPU Profile" to investigate which script is slow. Click start and interact with your page, then click stop.

    Finding Memory Leaks

    Click on the Timeline tab and click on Memory.
    Click recording, interact with the web page and stop the recording.
    If you notice something that looks like memory leak, you would need to use Heap Snapshot

    Go to the Profile tab and select Take Heap Snapshot
    Interact with the site and take another snapshot (recording button)
    Compare the two snapshots (arrow next to summary)
    One sign of memory leak is under Detached DOM tree

    (not sure about this...)

    C:Users<username>AppDataLocalGoogleChromeUser Data
