    [A/B Split Testing Post Title]

    parent nodes: Wordpress

    A/B Split Testing Post Title

    [camelCaseWordsEnabled: false]

    First thing you need to do is install and activate Title Experiments Free plugin. Upon activation, you need to visit Settings » Title Exp Settings to configure the plugin.

    If your site uses heavy caching, then you can choose to use JavaScript for post titles. This will ensure that the plugin works as intended instead of having the same title being shown to everyone due to caching issues.

    For SEO purposes, by default the plugin shows the first title to the search engines. However you can change this setting if you want.

    The plugin recalculates display probabilities every 5 minutes to ensure maximum results. You can increase or decrease this time if you want. However please understand that setting it below 5 minutes may cause our site to slow down.

    Once you are done, click on the save settings button to store your settings.

    Now you need to head over to Post » Add New to see the plugin in action. On the post edit screen, you can add multiple post titles for your post. Try creating different variations of SEO friendly post titles with different keywords.

    After you have added a few titles, you can save and publish your post.

    Once your post has attracted enough traffic, you can see which titles performed better by editing the post. The plugin calculates the click probability based on how many times a title is displayed, and how often it is clicked by the users.

    For busy websites, you will instantly start noticing which keywords trigger a more positive response from your users. You can then start using those keywords creatively into your post titles to write more effective headlines. For smaller sites, this kind of micro-testing might not be as useful because of the small sample size.

    How to Do A/B Split Testing in WordPress using Google Analytics

    Before we move forward, there are a few things you would need for this tutorial. If you haven’t already done so, then the first thing you need to do is install Google Analytics in WordPress. The second thing you would need is variations of the original page that you want to test. For example, if you are running tests on your registration page, then create another copy of the page with different copy, style, or layout. You can create multiple variations of a page with different layouts or copy. Make sure that you publish your original page and all its variations, so that they are publicly accessible.

    Setting up Content Experiment in Google Analytics

    A/B split testing is called Content Experiments in Google Analytics. Sign in to your Analytics account and then go to Content » Experiments. Provide the URL of your original page and click on create experiment button to get started.

    Start A/B Testing Content Experiment in Analytics

    On the next page you will be asked to provide a title for this A/B testing experiment and choose an objective for it. Objectives are goals which you can create in Google Analytics. You can create a new goal by clicking on add an objective link, or use an existing one. Analytics will track how many visitors to each variation of page meet your objective or goal. For example, if you have a registration page where users are redirected to a thank you page after registration, then you can set that as your objective. When a user on your website fills the form and gets redirected to the thank you page, then this equals to the completion of your goal.

    Setting up A/B testing or content experiments in Google Analytics
    After providing your original page URL and choosing objective or goal for this experiment, you can now add variations of this page. Create different variations of this page in WordPress and make sure all of them are live and publicly accessible. You can add multiple variations of the same page with different design, call to action, layout and copy.

    Adding page variations in Google Analytics Content Experiments for A/B Testing

    On the next screen you will be provided with a code to add to your WordPress website’s header. Click on Manually insert the code button and copy the code.

    Copy the code for A/B Testing content experiment code from Google Analytics

    Now all you need to do is add this code to your WordPress theme’s header.php file. Once added, this code will start redirecting all visitors to a variation of your testing page. To add the split test code, you need to paste this code in your theme’s header.php file:

    <?php if (is_page($page_id)) :
    //Add Google Analytics Content Experiment
      ?>
    Paste content experiment code here
    <?php endif; ?>

    Replace $page_id with the id of your original page. (Look at page in wp-admin editor and check the URL to get the ID)

    If you don’t want to modify the code in your theme, then you can use this plugin called Google Content Experiments.

    Once you have added the code to your original page and published the original and variation pages, go back to Google analytics and click the Next button. Analytics will now verify that you have the content experiment code properly installed on your pages. After that you can click on start experiment button to launch your A/B split testing content experiment.

    A/B Split Testing Content Experiment Launched in Google Analytics

    That’s all you need to get started. You have successfully installed A/B Split Testing on your WordPress site using Google Analytic’s content experiments. It will take some time before Google Analytics will start showing test data. Visitors to your original page will now be randomly redirected to one of the variation pages and some would still see the original page. Users will continue to see the same variation of the page on their next visits during the experimentation. Based on your goal settings, Google Analytics will show you which variation is working best towards achieving your goal and will choose a winner if it feels that one variation is out-performing other variations of the page.









    [Add Google Analytics Code]

    parent nodes: Wordpress

    Add Google Analytics Code

    [camelCaseWordsEnabled: false]

    1. Login to your Google Analytics Account
    This tutorial assumes you’ve already signed up for Google Analytics. If you haven’t already got one, it only takes a second to sign up, especially if you’ve already got an account with Google. Head to the Google Analytics site and create a new account.
    After you’ve signed up, you’ll be given a piece of Javascript code to add to your site.

    After signing up for Google Analytics, you’ll be given some code to put in your site.

    2. Add the Google Analytics Code to Your WordPress Theme

    Copy the tracking code. Go to your WordPress Admin and then Appearance > Editor.
    Open your theme’s header.php file and directory underneath the < body > tag, paste the tracking code. Click “Update File”.
    Add the tracking code directly below the <body> tag.

    3. Check Analytics is Working On Your Site

    Receiving data
    Once you’ve insert the tracking code into your theme, your Google Analytics tracking should change.
    Go back to your Google Analytics account. Click on “Admin” at the top of the page and under “Property” choose your site and then click “Tracking Info”.
    If the Tracking Status is “Receiving Data,” then you’ve successfully added Google Analytics to your site.
    You can now click on the “Reporting” tab at the top of the page to see your site’s analytics overview. It may take Google up to 12-24 hours to start providing you with site stats.


    From a different document

    There are 3 ways to install Google analytics in WordPress. Direct paste, functions.php, and plugins.

    Plugins Method (Recommended)
    There are tons of plugins available to add Google Analytics to your site. However, it is probably best to just use a simple light-weight plugin like:
    Insert Header and Footer (https://wordpress.org/plugins/insert-headers-and-footers/)

    Paste the Google Analytics code in the plugin’s setting page.

    Direct Paste Method

    Copy the code that you received in Step 6, and paste it in your theme’s header.php right after the tag.

    Functions.php Method

    Note: only use this if you know what you are doing.

    Add the following code in your theme’s functions.php file and don’t forget to paste your Google Analytics code from Step 6 here. Before you paste it, please make sure that you have read our Beginner’s Guide to Pasting Snippets from the Web.

    <?php
    add_action('wp_footer', 'add_googleanalytics');
    function add_googleanalytics() { ?>
    // Paste your Google Analytics code from Step 6 here
    <?php } ?>

    You can now click on the Reporting tab in Google Analytics to see your site’s analytics overview. It takes Google up to 12 – 24 hours to start providing you with the awesome site stats that you need.









    [Backing up and restoring]

    parent nodes: Wordpress

    Backing up and restoring

    [camelCaseWordsEnabled: false]

    Why backups matter
    - Hacking
    - Server malfunction
    - Hosting company ends service
    - Quickly move site to new host

    What to back up
    - Database (contains all your content and settings)
    - wp-content folder (hold themes, plugins and uploads)
    - wp-config.php file
    - .htaccess file

    Step by step
    1. Install Plugin BackWPUp
    2. BackWPUp > Add new job
    3. Keep defaults:
      - Database backup
      - File backup
      - Installed plugin list
    4. Change to ZIP
    5. Backup to Dropbox
    6. Uncheck "Send e-mail with log when error" so that you receive all e-mails
    7. Click save
    8. Click on schedule, start job with Wordpress Cron, basic, weekly
    9. Under DB Backup, check Backup File Name
    10. Go through files, uncheck root folder, check rest to see if it's all good
    11. Dropbox configuration is now a new tab (you can send different backup jobs to different dropbox accounts)
    12. Reauthenticate (full Dropbox)
    13. Pick folder location, save


    To force the job to run:
    BackWPUp > Jobs
    Hover over job and click Run Now

    Usually no need to change settings on BackWPUp, but you could uncheck BackWPUp in admin bar.
    You can also check where the logs are saved

    Restoring=

    Before you do a site restore, check with your host if they can do it for you

    1. Do a MANUAL backup of database and files (don't go through the plugin)
      - Copy every single file in your manual backup folder. Get db name from config.php
      - Go to phpMyAdmin
      - Click export
      - Check Add drop table, uncheck add create procedure. Go!
    2. Delete stuff
      - Go to Filezilla and delete everything under wp-content
      - Note down from wp-config.php the username and password for the database
    3. Restore wp-content folder and system files
      - If not done, get db name from wp-config.php
      - Copy wp-config.php and .htaccess files through Filezilla from BackWPUp
      - Copy wp-content folder through Filezilla from BackWPUp
    4. Delete all tables from database
      - Go to your database in phpMyAdmin (make sure it is the right database!)
      - Scroll down and click "Check all". With selected, select Drop, Yes.
    5. Import database backup to restore database
      - Open the SQL file and rename stuff following this logic:
        - Search and replace http://localhost/wordpress with http://mor10.com/migration
        - Search and replace /wordpress with /migration
      - In phpMyAdmin, click on Import, choose file, and select the sql file located in the BackWPUp backup
      - Go!
    7. Fix wp-config.php if needed with things you noted down in step 1, don't overwrite the whole file though, just the database information

    If a professional backing up strategy is needed, suggested is vaultpress.com


    =If SQL file is bigger than 50 mb=
    Using SSH can be a superior way to manage the files and databases on your account. Using a simple command you can import or export a MySQL database into an existing database on your account. Click Here (https://my.bluehost.com/cgi/help/180) for information about getting SSH access.If you are looking for instructions for importing or exporting databases using phpMyAdmin, please see Import Databases with phpMyAdmin

    Import A MySQL Database

    The file must be in .sql format. It can not be compressed in a .zip or .tar.gz file.
    Start by uploading the .sql file onto the Bluehost server
    If you haven't already done so, create the MySQL database via the cpanel. Click Here for further instructions
    Using SSH, navigate to the directory where your .sql file is.
    Next run this command:
      mysql -p -u username database_name < file.sql
    To import a single table into an existing database you would use the following command:

    mysql -u username -p -D database_name < tableName.sql









    [Building a responsive theme]

    parent nodes: Wordpress

    Building a responsive theme

    [camelCaseWordsEnabled: false]

    All the exercises from the video were done on Anaximander theme under wplisa

    Wordpress mobile:
      - Responsive theme
      - Theme switcher
      - Mobile plug-in (most popular as of 2012: WPtouch) The problem with that is that the mobile experience looks nothing like your main design
    Standard screen sizes:
      - Standard monitor, 1280x1040
      - HD monitor, 1920x1080
      - Typical laptop, 1360x768
      - Typical smartphone, 320x480 (easy to switch from 320x480 to 480x320)
      - iPad 1 and 2, 768x1024
      - iPad retina, 1536x2048
      - Android tablet, 1280x800
      - HD Android tablet, 1920x1200
      - etc. etc.
    Basically you can never guess what the resolution will be, so you have to design your website in such a way that it will look nice on any screen resolution.

    When designing a responsive site, start with the mobile look first. You will end up getting rid of everything that does not matter. Once you know what your design will look like on a small design, you can scale your design UP to fit larger screens. Once you have the small and the large figured out, you can work on the middle size.

    Your markup needs to accommodate all your different layouts simultaneously without becoming unnecessarily cluttered in the process.

    Superfish library: Allows you to create responsive and accessible menus using jquery
    http://users.tpg.com.au/j_birch/plugins/superfish/

    Morten: In my opinion, drop-down menus are a bad idea and should be avoided at all costs
    - Difficult to deal with on cell phones
    - If you put a drop down menu, you are hiding content on the page.

    The alternative: Only make the first element of the menu clickable and put the rest of the links in that page.

    Media query
    Example:

    @media only screen and (max-width: 900px){
      body{
        font-family: Georgia, Times, Times New Roman, serif;}
    }

    Changes the font-family for anything that is smaller than 900px

    Speaker recommends to put media query at the bottom and organize them from the biggest screens to the smallest screen


    This code is not responsive...
    #wrapper {
      display: block;
      width: 1040px;
      margin: 0 auto;
      background: #fff;
    }

    but it becomes way better if you make this small change:
    #wrapper {
      display: block;
      max-width: 1040px; //change here
      margin: 0 auto;
      background: #fff;
    }

    Asking the screen how big it is:
    Add these lines in header.php, just on top of <title>

    <!-- Check device width for responsive media query -->
    <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, intial-scale=1.0, maximum-scale=1.0, user-scalable=no" />

    To know the percentage of space you need for something, you do:
    (width * 100) / (total width) = percentage

    Making sure all images are resizing automatically:

    --START--

    img.size-auto,
    img.size-full,
    img.size-large,
    img.size-medium,
    .attachment img,
    #sidebar img,
    .wp-caption {
      max-width: 100%; /* When images are too wide for containing element, force them to fit. */
      height: auto; /* Override height to match resized width for correct aspect ratio. */
    }

    img.aligncenter,
    .wp-caption.aligncenter {
      margin: 0 auto 1.5em auto;
      max-width: 100%;
      height: auto;
    }

    --END--

    To make a video responsive
    1. You need to add a javascript library that you can find here: http://fitvidsjs.com/

    2. Place the file jquery.fitvids.js in your theme folder under the folder called "js"

    3. In functions.php, add the following code:

    --START--
    // Add FitVids to allow for responsive sizing of videos
    function anaximander_fitvids() {
      if (!is_admin()) {
        wp_register_script( 'fitvids', get_template_directory_uri() . '/js/jquery.fitvids.js', array('jquery'), '1.0', true);
          wp_enqueue_script( 'fitvids');
          add_action('wp_head', 'add_fitthem');

          function add_fitthem() { ?>
            <script type="text/javascript">
              jQuery(document).ready(function() {
                jQuery('.video').fitVids();
              });
            </script><?php
          }
      }
    }

    add_action('init', 'anaximander_fitvids');


    // Automatically append .video class to embed content (not a perfect solution, but close), will only work to new videos (old ones you have to reupdate them
    function anaximander_embed_filter( $html, $data, $url ) {
      $return = '<div class="video">'.$html.'</div>';
      return $return;
    }
    add_filter('oembed_dataparse', 'anaximander_embed_filter', 90, 3 );

    --END--

    4. Go to your post and make sure your video has the class "video". In the text view:

    <div class=video>
    https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=F3kImL2gDkI
    </div>

    If you hide something (display: none;) it still gets loaded on the browser. Could be big... For example, hiding sidebar which contains ads from Google etc.

    Link in the footer to go back to top
    Add this line to footer.php: <p><a href="#content">You have reached the bottom. Click here to get back on top.</a></p>

    Right now it points to "Content" which is an ID but you can point to something else because it doesn't truly bring back to the TOP TOP.

    Adding a responsive slider
    1. Go to http://www.woothemes.com/flexslider/ and click download

    2. Place the following files on your website:
    flexslider.css (in theme > CSS)
    jquery.flexslider-min.js
    images folder (in theme > CSS)

    3. In functions.php, add following code:

    // FLEXSLIDER

    function anaximander_flexslider() {
      if (!is_admin()) {
        // Enqueue FlexSlider JavaScript
        wp_register_script('jquery_flexslider', get_template_directory_uri(). '/js/jquery.flexslider-min.js', array('jquery') );
        wp_enqueue_script('jquery_flexslider');

        // Enqueue FlexSlider Stylesheet
        wp_register_style( 'flexslider-style', get_template_directory_uri() . '/CSS/flexslider.css', 'all' );
        wp_enqueue_style( 'flexslider-style' );

        // FlexSlider custom settings
        add_action('wp_footer', 'anaximander_flexslider_settings');

        function anaximander_flexslider_settings() { ?>
          <script>
            jQuery(document).ready(function($){
              $('.flexslider').flexslider();
            });
          </script>
        <?php
        }
      }
    }

    add_action('init', 'anaximander_flexslider');

    //END FLEXSLIDER

    OK now you have a few options...

    --OPTION 1--

    4. In index.php, add following code under <div id="content" role="main">:

    <!-- Flexslider demo content -->

    <div class="flexslider">
      <ul class="slides">
        <li>
          <img src="" />
          <p class="flex-caption">Caption goes here</p>
        </li>
        <li>
          <img src="" />
          <p class="flex-caption">Caption goes here</p>
        </li>
        <li>
          <img src="" />
          <p class="flex-caption">Caption goes here</p>
        </li>
        <li>
          <img src="" />
          <p class="flex-caption">Caption goes here</p>
        </li>
      </ul>
    </div>

    <!-- END Flexslider demo content

    --OPTION 2--

    4. Create a php file called featureflexslider.php (it will create a flex slider with images from the featured content). Here is the code:

    --START--

    <?php

    // Custom loop for featured items in the slider on the front page.
    // Slider will show up to 6 posts marked as "sticky"

    ?>

    <div class="flexslider">
      <ul class="slides">
        <?php
        // Get all sticky posts, but only sticky posts
        $sticky = get_option( 'sticky_posts' );
        $args = array(
          'numberposts' => 6, // Display up to 6 posts. Change at will
          'post__in' => $sticky
        );
        $postQuery = get_posts($args);

        foreach( $postQuery as $post ) : setup_postdata($post);
          if ( has_post_thumbnail() ) { ?>
            <li>
              <a href="<?php echo get_permalink(); ?>" title="Go to <?php echo the_title(); ?>" rel="bookmark">
                <?php the_post_thumbnail('feature-slider'); ?>
                <p class="flex-caption"><?php the_title(); ?></p>
              </a>
            </li>
          <?php
          }
        endforeach; ?>
      </ul>
    </div>

    --END--

    5. If necessary, install plugin called "regenerate thumbnails" and activate. Run it: Tools > Regenerate Thumbnaisl

    6. In index.php, add following code under <div id="content" role="main">:

    <!-- Flexslider featured content -->

    <?php
    // Check if this is the front page and that it is not page 2 or higher
    if ( is_front_page() && !is_paged() ) {
      // Add featured content slider
      get_template_part( 'featureflexslider' );
    }
    ?>

    <!-- END Flexslider featured -->

    USING MASONRY (mostly working but not fully on wplisa.org)

    1. Go to the website: http://masonry.desandro.com/index.html

    2. Download masonry and place it in js folder in your theme folder.

    3. In functions.php, put the following code:

    // MASONRY START

    function anaximander_masonry() {
      if (!is_admin()) {
        wp_register_script('jquery_masonry', get_template_directory_uri(). '/js/masonry.pkgd.min.js', array('jquery'), '2.0.110526' );
        wp_enqueue_script('jquery_masonry');
        add_action('wp_footer', 'anaximander_add_masonry'); //in footer to make sure all content is on page before we start reorg

        function anaximander_add_masonry() { ?>
          <script>
            jQuery(document).ready(function($){
              $('#masonry-index').masonry({
                itemSelector: '.index-post-container',
                isAnimated: true; /*This line controls whether the widget will move by animation or not. Check masonry website for other functions */
              });
                });
          </script>
        <?php
        }
      }
    }

    add_action('init', 'anaximander_masonry');

    // MASONRY END

    4. So now in Anaximander theme, we want to do a few things: get rid of the sidebar, arrange content in three columns, show image for each post and make sure that the page nav stays at the bottom. So it's too long to go through everything, just check index.php in wplisa.org

    5. Add the following code to style.css

    /*
    Index - Masonry
    */

    #masonry-index {
      width: 105%;
    }

    #masonry-index .textwidget {
      padding:0;
    }

    #masonry-index .index-post-container {
      width: 298px;
      border: 1px #e3e3e3 solid;
      float: left;
      margin: 0 20px 20px 0;
    }

    #masonry-index .index-title,
    #masonry-index .index-name-date,
    #masonry-index .index-content {
      margin: 20px;
    }

    --END--

    Examples of websites that are responsive: http://mediaqueri.es/









    [Building Themes from scratch with Underscores]

    parent nodes: Wordpress

    Building Themes from scratch with Underscores

    [camelCaseWordsEnabled: false]

    Underscores website: http://www.underscores.me

    Test data: http://codex.wordpress.org/Theme\_Unit\_Test
    Tools > Import > Wordpress
    Follow the steps...
    Leave Author blank
    Check "Download and Import the attachments"

    Install the "Developer" plugin by automattic

    Install the following:
    - Debug bar
    - Debug bar console
    - Debug bar cron
    - Debug bar extender
    - Monster widget
    - Regenerate thumbnails

    Notepad++ replacement: netbeans.org (requires JDK)

    single.php calls all sorts of other files:
    - header.php
    - content.php
    - sidebar.php
    - footer.php

    DRY: Don't Repeat Yourself

    Wordpress Template Hierarchy:

    If no template is available, Wordpress will always default to Index.php

    The strict minimum files a theme needs:
    - style.css
    - functions.php
    - index.php

    Adding theme information

    Do this so that when you go appearance > Theme > Theme details, there is actually something there!

    1. Open style.css and change the top information from the comment section:

    Theme Name: My Simone
    Theme URI: http://lynda.com
    Author: Claudie Larouche
    Author URI: http://claudiewebdesign.com
    Description: Custom responsive theme based on Underscores
    Version: 1.0
    License: GNU General Public License v2 or later
    License URI: http://www.gnu.org/licenses/gpl-2.0.html
    Text Domain: my-simone
    Domain Path: /languages/
    Tags: two-columns, responsive-layout, left-sidebar, white, blue, black

    For a list of tags you are allowed to use: https://wordpress.org/themes/tag-filter

    Make changed to functions.php
    Please see My Simone theme and search for "Claudie" for changes that were made

    Use custom fonts

    It is recommended to put the font calls into the head, so you could be tempted to put them in header.php. But it is better to actually enqueue them in functions.php. By enqueuing styles and scripts, we can control where, when and how each style sheet and each script is called, and what dependencies each of them have.


    When I build WordPress themes, I try to work in a systematic fashion.
    - First, apply CSS to the existing elements to get the existing theme to match my designs as closely as possible
    - Then add new elements and change those existing elements one at a time and style them as they appear.

    The underscore theme comes with a folder called Layout. This will control the look of the page (sidebar, header, footer, etc.) It's good to keep it separate from style.css in case you want to have different layout for different type of pages. Please note that these CSS sheets are not applied to the website until you actually enqueue them in functions.php

    Header typically contain 3 elements:
    - Site title
    - Site tagline
    - Main menu

    The custom header feature in WordPress enables the site owner to interact with how the header is displayed

    Sometimes the customizer needs to be modified to mimic the behaviour of the site. If that's the case, you can modify it in theme folder > js > customizer.js

    Menus are registered in functions.php. Out of the box, underscores come with one primary menu. (register_nav_menus). Once the menu is registered, it has to be displayed somewhere. In this case, it is in header.php. wp_nav_menu, theme location, primary -> that's the function that calls the menu.

    Superfish

    To make menus accessible (being able to tab through the menu), download Superfish: http://users.tpg.com.au/j_birch/plugins/superfish/download/ The only file you actually need is located here: superfish-masterdistjs and is called superfish.min.js. Put it in your theme's js folder. Now you must enqueue the script in functions.php:
    wp_enqueue_script( 'my-simone-superfish', get_template_directory_uri() . '/js/superfish.min.js', array('jquery'), '20140328', true );

    array('jquery') means that jquery is a dependancy
    20140328 is the version number (today's date)
    true means footer, false would mean header.

    Now you need to create a new file under js called superfish-settings.js. Must enqueue this one as well in functions.php.

    Creating a social media menu

    Step 1:
    - Make Wordpress aware that there is a new menu (in functions.php)
    add this line: 'social' => __( 'Social Menu', 'my-simone' ),
    into register_nav_menus

    Step 2:
    - Add the menu information in wordpress dashboard (create menu and add links to twitter and facebook), and set location to social menu

    Step 3:
    - Go to inc folder, edit the file called template-tags.php
    Go to the very bottom of the file and add the following code:

    /*
      * Social media icon menu as per http://justintadlock.com/archives/2013/08/14/social-nav-menus-part-2
      */
    function my_simone_social_menu() {
      if ( has_nav_menu( 'social' ) ) {
      wp_nav_menu(
        array(
          'theme_location' => 'social',
          'container' => 'div',
          'container_id' => 'menu-social',
          'container_class' => 'menu-social',
          'menu_id' => 'menu-social-items',
          'menu_class' => 'menu-items',
          'depth' => 1,
          'fallback_cb' => '',
        )
      );
        }
    }

    Step 4:
    - Call the new function in header.php
    The following line is added under <?php wp_nav_menu...
    <?php my_simone_social_menu() ?>

    Step 5:
    - Replace the text of each social media thingy with the equivalent icon from FontAwesome.io

    We can use unicode (example twitter unicode is f099) and then using this code in style.css
    .menu-social li a:before {
      display: inline-block;
      padding: 0 5px;
      vertical-align: top;
      font-family: 'Fontawesome';
      font-size: 20px;
      color: #fff;
      -webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased;
      content: 'f0c0';
    }

    and then add these lines (and others if needed) for each social media

    .menu-social li a[href*="facebook.com"]::before { content: 'f09a'; }

    .menu-social li a[href*="twitter.com"]::before { content: 'f099'; }

    Step 6:
    - Make the menu responsive with the following code:

    @media screen and (max-width: 600px) {
      #menu-social ul {
        position: absolute;
          top: 0;
          right: 6rem;
          display: block;
      }

      #menu-social li a {
        padding-left:.5em;
        padding-right: .5em;
      }
    }

    Adding a search button

    Step 1:
    - In header.php, add the following code under the closing nav tag
    <div id="search-container" class="search-box-wrapper clear">
      <div class="search-box clear">
        <?php get_search_form(); ?>
      </div>
    </div>

    Step 2:
    Style it with this code in the header section of style.css:
    /* Header search */

    input[type="search"] {
      box-sizing: border-box;
      width: 100%;
    }

    .search-box-wrapper {
      z-index: 2;
      width: 100%;
    }

    .search-box {
      padding: 1em;
      background: #4d4d4d;
      background: hsl(0, 0%, 30%);
    }

    .search-box .search-field {
      max-width: 362px;
      float: right;
      padding: 1rem 2rem 1rem 4rem;
      font-size: 20px;
      font-size: 2rem;
      background-color: #fff;
      border: 0;
    }

    .error404 .search-submit,
    .search .search-submit,
    .search-box .search-submit {
      display: none;
    }

    Step 2: Adding the search icon
    In header.php, place following code between nav menu and social menu (code from Font awesome wrapped around classes so that we can style it):
    <div class="search-toggle">
      <i class="fa fa-search"></i>
      <a href="#search-container" class="screen-reader-text"><?php _e( 'Search', 'my-simone' ); ?></a>
    </div>

    Step 3: Style the search icon
    .search-toggle {
      float: right;
      width: 54px;
      height: 54px;
      padding: 12px;
      margin-right: 20px;
      color: #fff;
      text-align: center;
      cursor: pointer;
    }

    .search-toggle:hover,
    .search-toggle.active {
      background: #4d4d4d;
      background: hsl(0, 0%, 30%);
    }

    @media screen and (max-width: 600px) {
      .search-toggle {
        position: absolute;
        top: 0;
        right: 0;
        margin-right: 0;
      }
    }

    Step 4: Adding toggle functionality with javascript

    Step 4.1: Create a file called hide-search.js that you save in the js folder with the following code:
    /*
      * Toggles header search on and off
      */

      jQuery(document).ready(function($){
      $(".search-toggle").click(function(){
        $("#search-container").slideToggle('slow');
      });
      });
    Step 4.2: Enqueue the script
    Add this line to functions.php:
    wp_enqueue_script( 'my-simone-hide-search', get_template_directory_uri() . '/js/hide-search.js', array('jquery'), '20141102', true );

    Step 4.3: Hide the search field by default
    In style.css, add this line in .search-box-wrapper {
    display: none;

    Step 4.4: Search button highlighted when search box is toggled on
    Change the jquery to this:
    jQuery(document).ready(function($){
      $(".search-toggle").click(function(){
        $("#search-container").slideToggle('slow', function(){
          $(".search-toggle").toggleClass('active')
        });
      });
    });

    Adding a widgetized area to the footer

    Step 1: Register the sidebar in functions.php
    register_sidebar( array(
      'name' => __( 'Footer widgets', 'my-simone' ),
      'description' => __( 'Footer widget', 'my-simone' ),
      'id' => 'sidebar-2',
      'description' => '',
      'before_widget' => '<aside id="%1$s" class="widget %2$s">',
      'after_widget' => '</aside>',
      'before_title' => '<h1 class="widget-title">',
      'after_title' => '</h1>',
    ) );

    Step 2: Create a new sidebar file called sidebar-footer.php (saved directly under theme folder)
    put this code in:
    <?php
    /**
      * The footer sidebar
      *
      */
    if ( ! is_active_sidebar( 'sidebar-2' ) ) {
      return;
    }
    ?>

    <div id="supplementary">
      <div id="footer-widgets" class="footer-widgets widget-area clear" role="complementary">
        <?php dynamic_sidebar( 'sidebar-2' ); ?>
      </div><!-- #footer-sidebar -->
    </div><!-- #supplementary -->

    Step 3: In footer.php
    Add this line:
    <?php get_sidebar('footer'); ?>

    It is recommended to test your widgetized area by adding every single possible widget to them. You can use the developer plugin called Monster widget for this purpose. Add the Monster widget from Appearance > Widget.

    Step 4: Style the footer
    See style.css in the footer section

    Step 5: Style the widgets and individual widgets
    See style.css Widget section

    Turn on masonry for the footer
    Step 1: Create a new file in the JS folder called masonry-settings.js with following code:
    // Masonry settings to organize footer widgets
    jQuery(document).ready(function($){
      var $container = $('#footer-widgets');
      var $masonryOn;
      var $columnWidth = 400;

      if ($(document).width() > 879) {;
        $masonryOn = true;
        runMasonry();
      };

      $(window).resize( function() {
        if ($(document).width() < 879) {
          if ($masonryOn){
            $container.masonry('destroy');
            $masonryOn = false;
          }
        } else {
          $masonryOn = true;
          runMasonry();
        }
      });

      function runMasonry() {
        // initialize
        $container.masonry({
          columnWidth: $columnWidth,
          itemSelector: '.widget',
          isFitWidth: true,
          isAnimated: true
        });
      };
    });

    Step 2: Enqueue masonry in functions.php
    wp_enqueue_script( 'my-simone-masonry', get_template_directory_uri() . '/js/masonry-settings.js', array('masonry'), '20140401', true );

    Step 3: make footer widget responsive
    in style.css
    /* Footer widgets responsive */
    @media screen and (max-width: 879px) {
      #footer-widgets { width: 100%!important; }

      .footer-widgets .widget {
        float: none;
        width: 100%;
        margin: 0 0 8rem;
      }
    }

    Work on the single post template

    Step 1:
    In content-single.php right under header class = entry header
    <?php
      /* translators: used between list items, there is a space after the comma */
      $category_list = get_the_category_list( __( ', ', 'my-simone' ) );

      if ( my_simone_categorized_blog() ) {
        echo '<div class="category-list">' . $category_list . '</div>';
      }
    ?>

    And I made a variety of changes to my_simone_posted_on in inc > template-tag

    All sorts of styles were also added to section 10.1 in style.css and to the Meta section and alignment and caption and section 12

    Step 2: Changes to the post navigation at the bottom of the post
    In inc > template-tags.php, replace the entire nav section of my_simone_post_nav with this:

    <nav class="navigation post-navigation" role="navigation">
      <div class="post-nav-box clear">
        <h1 class="screen-reader-text"><?php _e( 'Post navigation', 'my-simone' ); ?></h1>
        <div class="nav-links">
          <?php
          previous_post_link( '<div class="nav-previous"><div class="nav-indicator">' . _x( 'Previous Post:', 'Previous post', 'my-simone' ) . '</div><h1>%link</h1></div>', '%title' );
          next_post_link( '<div class="nav-next"><div class="nav-indicator">' . _x( 'Next Post:', 'Next post', 'my-simone' ) . '</div><h1>%link</h1></div>', '%title' );
          ?>
        </div><!-- .nav-links -->
      </div><!-- .post-nav-box -->
    </nav><!-- .navigation -->

    And change a few things in style.css as always :)

    Comments

    Comments are controlled by the function comments_template() in single.php. That is a very smart function. If there is a file called comments.php in the theme, it will use that, if not it will use Wordpress default.

    Gravatars are controlled in wp_list_comments in comments.php. By default, the gravatar that's output is 32 X 32 pixels.

    wp_list_comments( array(
      'style' => 'ol',
      'short_ping' => true,
      ) );
    Just add a line for avatar_size if you want to change the size. It is possible to target post author comments in the CSS (bypostauthor class)

    Remember to apply styles to both comments form: when people are logged in and when people are NOT logged in.

    Featured images

    the_content() function returns the whole post content along with images.
    the_post_thumbnail() function returns only the featured image.

    The featured image can have different sizes and you can call them like this:
    the_post_thumbnail('index-thumb')
    the_post_thumbnail('single-thumb')

    The first step in setting up featured images is to enable theme support for post thumbnails (functions.php) and define the featured image sizes (add add_image_size)

    add_image_size('large-thumb', 1060, 650, true);

    If I set the crop value to true then WordPress will take an image that's much larger. Scale it down to match the width, and then crop it to match the height. That also means if the image is really wide but is not the full height, then the image will just be scaled down. If I set this value to false however and I upload a very, very large image, then WordPress will just take the large image as it is and just display it as 1060 by 650. So in most cases it's a good idea to set this value to true, but if you don't want WordPress to crop the image you may want to set it to false

    In some rare cases, you may want the ability to upload feature images. That have variable height and will allow any height of image. In that case, what you want to do is change the height value here to 9999. That way, WordPress will never crop the height of an image. Well, it'll crop it if it's bigger than 9,999 pixels but that's a very, very large image and you would never use it in a WordPress site. So by setting this value this big. You ensure that no matter what size of image people upload, so that way the height of the object will never be cropped

    Each feature image is associated to a post through the post ID. Featured image is in content-single.php. To add a featured image, add this line:
      <?php
      if (has_post_thumbnail()) {
        echo '<div class="single-post-thumbnail clear">';
        echo '<div class="image-shifter">';
        echo the_post_thumbnail('large-thumb');
        echo '</div>';
        echo '</div>';
      }
      ?>
    'large-thumb' is a size we already specified (in functions.php)

    INDEX PAGES

    If you want to make changes to Wordpress's front page, chances are you want to deal with index.php

    Here is the "edit" button: <?php edit_post_link( __( 'Edit', 'my-simone' ), '<span class="edit-link">', '</span>' ); ?>

    When you have a "continue reading" link, you don't need to put continue reading [post title] for everybody. Just put the [post title] as the "title" of the link and people with reading devices will "see" that whereas people that see the normal view will just see "continue reading". Very clever :)

    The navigation at the bottom of index pages is called my_simone_paging_nav and it is located in template-tags.php (in inc)

    Post formats

    Morten said he is very reluctant to use post fomats other than "aside" because each theme control them widely differently.

    If you create a file called content-aside.php, this content will automatically be used for the Asides. Possible post formats: Aside, gallery, link, image, quote, status, video, audio and chat. Don't forget to enable them in functions.php

    Custom page templates

    Custom page templates may be one of the most powerful tools available to you as a WordPress developer because you can build as many as you like and add any code you like within them.

    1. Create a new folder for the new page template (page-templates)
    2. Copy page.php into that new folder
    3. Rename page.php in new folder to page-nosidebar
    4. Open page-nosidebar.php
    5. Replace the comment at the top with this:
    /**
      * Template Name: Page with No Sidebar
      */
    6. Now you should have a Template option when you modify pages in Wordpress
    7. Copy-paste content-sidebar under "layout" and rename the new one no-sidebar.css
    8. Change the content of no-sidebar accordingly
    9. Enqueue no-sidebar.css by adding the following lines to functions.php

    if (is_page_template('page-templates/page-nosidebar.php')) {
      wp_enqueue_style( 'my-sinome-layout-style' , get_template_directory_uri() . '/layouts/no-sidebar.css');
    } else {
      wp_enqueue_style( 'my-sinome-layout-style' , get_template_directory_uri() . '/layouts/content-sidebar.css');
    }

    Adding editor styles to match front-end styles

    1. in inc folder, create a new file called editor-style.css
    2. put proper styles in editor-style.css. They will be the same as style.css but simplified. Use Morten's file as a template
    3. In functions.php add this code into my_simone_setup()

    // This theme styles the visual editor to resemble the theme style.
    $font_url = 'http://fonts.googleapis.com/css?family=Lato:300,400,400italic,700,900,900italic|PT+Serif:400,700,400italic,700italic';
    add_editor_style( array( 'inc/editor-style.css', str_replace( ',', '%2C', $font_url ) ) );

    Other resources

    http://codex.wordpress.org/Theme\_Development
    And don't forget that I have the code snippets for every section in Dropbox



    List of steps
    Getting and installing Underscores
    Installing WordPress Theme Unit Test data
    Installing the Developer plugin
    Setting up style.css
    Configuring baseline settings and functions
    Enabling custom fonts and font icons
    Applying global styles
    Styling basic layout components

    [Creating a child theme]

    parent nodes: Wordpress

    Creating a child theme

    [camelCaseWordsEnabled: false]

    1. Create a new folder under wp-content/themes called childoftwentytwelve
    2. Create a file called style.css under the new folder childoftwentytwelve
    3. Type the following in the style.css file:

    /*
      Theme Name: Child of simone
      Theme URI: https://wordpress.org/themes/simone
      Description: Simone Child Theme
      Author: Claudie Larouche
      Author URI: http://claudiewebdesign.com
      Template: simone
      Version: 1.0.0
      Tags: light, dark, two-columns, right-sidebar, responsive-layout, accessibility-ready
      Text Domain: simone-child
    */


    /* =Theme customization starts here
    -------------------------------------------------------------- */


    In functions.php:

    <?php

    add_action( 'wp_enqueue_scripts', 'enqueue_parent_theme_style' );
    function enqueue_parent_theme_style() {
      wp_enqueue_style( 'parent-style', get_template_directory_uri().'/style.css' );
    }

    4. Now from Chrome, just right click on something and click inspect element to get the CSS code of that particular element. Copy that code in style.css and change it to modify the behaviour of your child theme. If you don't change some of the lines, you can take them off completely and your parent theme will take care of that part. Very neat!!

    Notes:
    - Body styles should be high up on your style.css file
    - Some themes have several places where the font is defined
    - When you add a function related to a plugin, always wrap it into conditional test (see below)

    This:
    <?php
      if (function_exists('related_posts')){
        related_posts();
      }
    ?>

    Instead of this:
    <?php related_posts(); ?>

    To create custom header, sidebar and footer in the site, use the following calls to call the appropriate php files:

    header-[name].php -> <?php get_header('[name]'); ?>
    sidebar-[name].php -> <?php get_sidebar('[name]'); ?>
    footer-[name].php -> <?php get_footer('[name]'); ?>

    You can modify the way posts or pages are shown by making copies of some of the php files related to them...
    - category.php (to modify the way posts appear when you click on the category)
    - author.php
    - archive.php
    - index.php (the main one)
    - page.php
    - search.php
    - content.php
    - single.php
    - tag.php

    Favicon stuff go in header.php in the head section like this:

    <head>
    <link rel="shortcut icon" href="<?php echo get_stylesheet_directory_uri(); ?>/favicon.ico" />

    To add a theme screenshot, just add screenshot.png file directly under your child theme folder.

    Consider adding this line to the footer:
    Copyright © <?php echo date('Y'); ?> <a href="<?php echo home_url(); ?>" title="<?php bloginfo('name'); ?>"> <?php bloginfo('name');?></a>.

    Picture caption: Photo by Chris RubberDragon from Flickr
    Alternative text: Photo of 6 kayaks on a beach, link to Flickr page

    Overriding functions

    Source: http://code.tutsplus.com/tutorials/a-guide-to-overriding-parent-theme-functions-in-your-child-theme--cms-22623

    If the functions in your parent theme are written this way:
    <?php
    if ( ! function_exists ( 'my_function' ) ) {
      function my_function() {
        // Contents of your function here.
      }
    }
    ?>

    You can simply write a function with the same name and it will override the parent's version:

    <?php
    function my_function() {
      // Contents for your function override here.
    }
    ?>



    If the function in your parent theme is not pluggable:

    <?php
    function parent_function() {
      // Contents for your function here.
    }
    add_action( 'init', 'parent_function' );
    ?>

    You can rewrite the function by giving it a higher priority:

    <?php
    function child_function() {
      // Contents for your function here.
    }
    add_action( 'init', 'child_function', 15 );
    ?>

    By default, Wordpress gives a priority of 10 to functions that don't have a priority specified.

    Sometimes overriding is not sufficient, in which case, you can unhook it:

    Parent theme function:

    <?php
    function parent_function() {
      // Contents for your function here.
    }
    add_action( 'init', 'parent_function' );
    ?>

    Your code:

    <?php
    remove_action( 'init', 'parent_function' );
    ?>

    BUT, you need to attach this function to a hook which will fire after the hook which the parent theme function is attached to. This is because you can't remove the action before it's been fired.

    <?php
    function child_remove_parent_function() {
      remove_action( 'init', 'parent_function' );
    }
    add_action( 'wp_loaded', 'child_remove_parent_function' );
    ?>

    NOTE: You can also use remove_filter if that's how the parent function was added in the first place.

    Once you've done this, you can simply write an alternative function to replace the parent theme function in your child theme's functions file, or you can do nothing if all you wanted to do was remove the functionality from the parent theme.

    Note that if you're trying to remove a function using remove_action() or remove_filter() and the function has had a priority assigned to it, you must include the priority when removing it, or it won't work.

    <?php
    function child_remove_parent_function() {
      remove_action( 'widgets_init', 'parent_function', 15 );
    }
    add_action( 'wp_loaded', 'child_remove_parent_function' );
    ?>









    [Customizing Themes with Genesis]

    parent nodes: Wordpress

    Customizing Themes with Genesis

    [camelCaseWordsEnabled: false]

    Genesis folder structure
    Everything here is located under theme > genesis > lib

    init.php: This file loads all the other files
    framework.php: Contains the core hooks used by the Framework

    -FOLDERS-
    admin: Folder that contains stuff that you will see in your Wordpress dashboard
    classes: Folder that contains the files that define classes used by the theme
    css: CSS for the admin section
    functions: Folder that contains general functions of the Framework
    js: Handles script loading for the theme
    languages: Handles the translation files
    structure: Handles the output on the front end of the site. Gold mine when it comes to figuring out customization for child theme.
    widgets: Controls Genesis specific widgets

    -INSIDE THE STRUCTURE FOLDER-
    archive.php: Handles all the actions specific to archive pages
    header.php: Actions that load on hooks and the header.php template including the site title
    layout.php: Handles the loading of sidebars
    loops.php: Handles the 3 loops available in Genesis (standard, custom, grid)
    menu.php: Registers the menu areas to be used on your site. By default, Genesis comes with a primary nav and a secondary nav areas
    post.php: Once you're in the loop, post will spit out all the post content
    search.php: Controls functionality of search bar
    sidebar.php: Contains hooks and actions to create sidebars if they've been loaded by the layout.php file

    Whenever you see the genesis() function, it's loading the framework.php file

    Child theme
    Usually with child theme, when you want to replace certain functionality of the parent, you would copy the .php file associated to that functionality and replace it or add something to it. In Genesis, you don't have to do that. Modifications to Genesis behaviour can be done in one single file, functions.php. In addition to function.php, the only other file you need to create in your child theme is style.css. Only 2 files and you have a fully functional child theme.

    In functions.php, you initialize the Genesis engine through this line of code:

    <?php
    //Start the engine
    include_once( get_template_directory() . '/lib/init.php');

    In addition to functions.php and style.css, a lot of Genesis child theme will include a template for the home page.

    Removing website description
    Usually in child theme, you would copy header.php and remove the website description there. In Genesis, all you have to do is add this function to functions.php:

    remove_action('genesis_site_description', 'genesis_seo_site_description');

    Using the Genesis loop

    The simplest Wordpress loop:

    <?php
    get_header();
    if (have_post()) :
      while (have_post()) :
        the_post();
          the_content();
      endwhile();
    endif();
    get_sidebar();
    get_footer();
    ?>

    The Genesis loop works the same way as the Wordpress loop in the sense that it loops through the posts and pages to display the content. The only difference is that it contains various action hooks that give us the flexibility to jump into the page at any time to add, move or modify what's coming out. The Genesis loops are located here: genesis > lib > structure > loops.php.

    For example, if you want to add something before each post, you would look in loops.php, find the genesis_standard_loop() function. In there, you have do_action( 'genesis_before_while' ). That piece of code gives us a place to hook into Genesis via our child theme and inject a little code before each post entry. For example, we could add a featured image.

    -STANDARD LOOP-
    The Standard loop is used in most circumstances when content needs to be displayed. If you're not doing anything special, this is the loop you get. It outputs all the basic wrapping HTML you need and uses hooks to output most of the content like the title, the post content and the post information.

    -CUSTOM LOOP-
    The custom loop exists for when you need to run a custom query. It's basically a wrapper for the standard loop that lets you pass new WP arguments. Things like changing the sort order, or excluding categories. It's a quick way to customize the loop, without having to create a brand new loop from scratch with wp_query.

    -GRID LOOP-
    The grid loop is used to display your content in a multi-column format. It's a riff on the custom loop in that it takes your argument and passes them on to the standard loop. The difference is that it also adds some extra markup to style the grid format. It's a little confusing to work with and is left in the code for backward compatibility. If you want a grid layout for your post, there are better ways to achieve the same result such as using the grid loop plugin (http://www.wordpress.org/plugins/genesis-grid-loop)

    If the loops don't fit your purpose, you can always remove or unhook the Genesis loops and add in your own Wordpress loops.

    Hooks
    Review hooks here: http://codex.wordpress.org/Plugin_API/Hooks

    There are two types of Wordpress hooks: Action hooks and Filter hooks. In addition to those, Genesis add more hooks

    Action hooks
    Hooks that are called when something happens in Wordpress (ex: Saving a post, Echoeing a site description to the header...) Whenever wordpress encounters an action hook, any code that's associated with the hook gets executed.

    Two basic kinds of action:
    - add_action()
    - remove_action()

    Example:
    add_action('hook', 'callback_function', 10, 1);

    function callback_function($arg1){
      /*stuff */
    }

    From the example:
    hook = name or location of the hook. It's ok if it does not exist, it will just be ignored.
    callback_function: name of the callback_function we want to attach to the hook. Must exist otherwise error.
    10: priority. The lowest the number, the highest the priority. Default priority number is 10.
    1: number of accepted arguments. Default is 1.

    10 and 1 don't really have to be part of the action call, they are not mandatory.

    There is a plugin called Genesis Visual Hook Guide that you can download to see where hooks are taking place.

    remove_action: In order for a remove action to work, there has to be a corresponding add_action with the exact same hook and the exact same function, priority and arguments.

    to change the priority of an action (example):
    remove_action('genesis_entry_header', 'genesis_post_info', 12);
    add_action('genesis_entry_header', 'genesis_post_info', 9);
    //now the post info will appear on top of the title because it has a higher priority

    To change an action:

    remove_action('genesis_entry_header', 'genesis_post_info', 12);
    add_action('genesis_entry_header', 'my_custom_function', 12); //my custom function must exist!

    Challenge: remove the post meta function from the footer and add the post meta function under the post info

    remove_action( 'genesis_entry_footer', 'genesis_post_meta' );
    add_action( 'genesis_entry_header', 'genesis_post_meta', 13 );

    Bravo!

    Filter hooks

    Two basic kinds of filters:
    - add_filter()
    - remove_filter()

    Example:
    add_filter('hook_name', 'function_to_filter', 10, 1);

    function function_to_filter($arg1){
      /*stuff */
    }

    Real example:
    add_filter('genesis_title_comments', 'my_title_comments');

    function my_title_comments(){
      $title = "<h3>These are the comments</h3>";
      return $title;
    }

    Actions are about adding or removing chunks of code, filters are about replacing specific pieces of data. You can use the Genesis Visual Hook Guide plugin to help you find the filter hooks.

    Example of removing seo site description except on the home page
    /* remove site description */
    remove_action('genesis_site_description', 'genesis_seo_site_description');

    /* add the site description conditionally */
    add_action('genesis_site_description', 'maybe_site_description');

    function maybe_site_description(){
      if (is_home() ) {
        genesis_seo_site_description();
      }
    }

    Example adding a widget area
    /* 1. Register widget area called 'after-post' (in functions.php) */
    genesis_register_sidebar(array(
      'id' => 'after-post',
      'name' => __( 'After Post', 'sample'), /* "sample" should be theme name*/
      'description' => __( 'This is a widget area that can be placed after the post', 'sample'), /* "sample" should be theme name*/
    ));

    /* 2. Hook after-post widget area after post content (in functions.php) */
    add_action('genesis_before_comments', 'after-post_widget');

    function after_post_widget(){
      if (is_singular('post'){ /*only show this area on single posts */
        genesis_widget_area('after-post', array(
          'before' => '
          ',
          'after' => '
          ',
          ));
      }
    }

    The array thing is used to add some HTML markup before and after the widget area

    After that you can go in wp-admin and widget to add something to your new widget area

    Customizing the footer Copyright
    add_filter ('genesis_footer_creds_text', 'my_custom_footer_creds');

    function my_custom_footer_creds(){
      $creds = '[footer_copyright] Claudie Larouche'; /[footer-copyright] is a Genesis shortcode that outputs the copyright symbol and the current year
      return $creds;
    }

    Add logo
    To change the size of the custom logo image, look for this piece of code in functions.php:

    add_theme_support('genesis-custom-header', array(
      'width' => 320,
      'height' => 120
    ));

    If you change those values, you will probably need to change something in the css as well

    If your theme does not support header image, you can go under Genesis > Theme settings and under header, change to image logo. Then you can add the following stuff in your CSS:

    .header-image .site-title > a {
      background: url(images/logo.png) no-repeat left;
      float: left;
      min-height: 60px;
      width: 100%;
    }

    Change the favicon
    Place your favicon.ico file in your child theme's images folder.

    Other Notes
    Every time you see this in the code: __( it identifies a string that can be translated into another language.

    In your child theme, functions.php should have an opening <?php tag but it should NOT have a closing one

    If your child theme has a file called front_page.php or home.php, that means you have a custom home page.

    There is a plugin called Simple Custom CSS (http://wordpress.org/plugins/simple-custom-css/) or Jetpack (http://wordpress.org/plugins/jetpack/) allow you to modify the CSS without modifying your theme.

    Every WordPress site comes with a default RSS feed that can be found at yourdomain.com/feed









    [Migration through the database]

    parent nodes: Wordpress

    Migration through the database

    [camelCaseWordsEnabled: false]

    ==THIS SET OF INSTRUCTIONS IS OLD AND HAS NOT BEEN REVISED==

    Normally you would use Export / Import function.

    1. Set up empty Wordpress site on new host

    2. Copy plugins, themes and uploads to new host
      Seems like just replacing wp-content folder should do it!
    3. Export database from current host through phpMyAdmin
      - Go to phpMyAdmin on source
      - If you're not sure you're in the right database, check wp_options table
      - Click on "Databases"
      - Click on the proper database that's running the wordpress site
      - Click on Export
      - Select Custom
      - Make sure all the database tables are selected
      - Make sure it's set to save output to a file
      - Compression: none
      - Format: SQL
      - Check Add drop table etc.
      - Uncheck Add create procedure etc.
      - Click Go
    4. Fix database URLs in text editor
      - Open the file created in step 3 using Notepad++
      - Go to your source and target website main page and get the URL from both, you'll have to replace source with target in the SQL script
      - Search and replace http://localhost/wordpress with http://mor10.com/migration
      - Search and replace /wordpress with /migration
    5. Import database on new host through phpMyAdmin
      - Go to phpMyAdmin on target
      - If you're not sure you're in the right database, check wp_options table
      - Check all the tables (under Structure)
      - Click on the arrow next to "with selected", Drop
      - Yes
      - Click Import
      - Browse for file
      - Find your modified SQL script
      - Go
    Go to wp-admin
    You will see a database update required screen
    Click Update
    And then you should be good to go but click on links to make sure it's going to the right place (check URL too)

    You might have to go to settings > Permalinks and then just change something and put it back as it was and click "Save".

    Sometimes the file extension being capital or not makes an image appear properly or not

    It's good to match # of posts, # of media, # of comments, etc.









    [Notes - Wordpress]

    parent nodes: Wordpress

    Notes - Wordpress

    [camelCaseWordsEnabled: false]

    Should have a Privacy Policy page and terms and conditions page

    Digging into Wordpress is a good book

    Plugin to see Word-like options: TinyMCE Advanced

    Multisite version could be used to make website bilingual. Although there are plugins for that...

    Best social sharing plugin: https://wordpress.org/plugins/dc-simple-share-buttons

    If you are looking for a theme-specific function and it is not in functions.php, check in inc > template-tags.php









    [SEO - Wordpress]

    parent nodes: Wordpress

    SEO - Wordpress

    [camelCaseWordsEnabled: false]

    Install the plugin Wordpress SEO by Yoast

    Under General Settings, enter Webmaster Tools information

    Under titles and meta, don't make changes to the General page. There is a list of macros under Help.

    Under media, click Add Facebook Admin and fill rest of the information for Facebook, Twitter and Google+

    If Social Media features are configured properly, it's a powerful option to bring in more people to your site

    Under permalink, Redirect attachment URL's to parent post URL will send people to the post if they found the image somewhere and clicked on it (instead of them seeing ONLY the image). Strip Category is ok to change too but all the other settings on this page may mess up your website so use with caution.

    Edit Files: Don't touch it :)

    Now when you create a new post or page, you have new options at the bottom of the page. Social tab is interesting, you can create a custom description of your post just for Facebook or just for Google+

    Focus keyword: As you type, plugin will give you suggestions. As soon as you enter those keywords, SEO plugin will tell you where the keywords are missing.

    After you fill in your focus keyword and add it to various places on your post, click on Page Analysis and review advices.

    Backlinks
    Yelp
    infogroup
    hotfrog
    acxiom
    judy's book
    neustar
    white pages
    factual
    foursquare
    super
    best of the web









    [Useful Snippets]

    parent nodes: Wordpress

    Useful Snippets

    [camelCaseWordsEnabled: false]

    Table des matières:
    - Exclude Pages from WordPress Search Results
    - Redirect To Post If Search Results Return One Post
    - Change the Number of Default Post Revisions
    - Empty Your WordPress Trash

    Exclude Pages from WordPress Search Results
    File to Edit: Functions.php

    By default, WordPress includes pages in search results. This means that pages such as about, contact, privacy, etc, will be included in search results. These types of pages are not necessary if they are linked in your main navigation menu. WordPress will also include private pages in search results too. For example, a newsletter confirmation page or an eBook download page.

    To remove all pages from WordPress search, simple add the snippet below to your theme functions.php file.

    function filter_search($query) {
      if ($query->is_search) {
        $query->set('post_type', 'page');
      }
      return $query;
    }
    add_filter('pre_get_posts', 'filter_search');

    Redirect To Post If Search Results Return One Post
    File to Edit: Functions.php

    When you search for something on a WordPress website, a search results page is displayed with all relevant posts, posts, and other post types. The problem with this setup is that WordPress will still display a results page if there is only one blog post result.

    This code snippet addresses this issue. If only one blog post is found for a search, the visitor will be taken directly to the blog post in question.

    add_action('template_redirect', 'redirect_single_post');
    function redirect_single_post() {
      if (is_search()) {
        global $wp_query;
        if ($wp_query->post_count * 1 && $wp_query->max_num_pages * 1) {
          wp_redirect( get_permalink( $wp_query->posts['0']->ID ) );
          exit;
        }
      }
    }

    Change the Number of Default Post Revisions
    File to Edit: WP-Config.php

    The WordPress revision system saves a copy of your posts and pages every time you update them. This is handy as it allows you to refer back to previous versions of your article, compare drafts, and correct mistakes.

    The problem is that WordPress does not limit how many revisions it saves. Therefore, if you have saved an article 100 times, your website will store 100 revisions of the article. This can greatly increase the size of your database as one article with 100 revisions will take up just as much room as 100 articles with no revisions.

    It is therefore practical to limit the number of revisions that are stored. On my own websites, I limit revisions to two. This allows me to refer back to the last few copies of an article, without taking up too much room in the database.

    You can limit revisions by adding the code snippet below to wp-config.php.

    define( 'WP_POST_REVISIONS', 2 );
    Revisions can be disabled altogether by using the following code.

    define( 'WP_POST_REVISIONS', false );
    Be careful about disabling post revisions. If you lose your internet connection or accidentally close your browser tab, you could lose everything you had written since you last saved your article.

    Empty Your WordPress Trash
    File to Edit: WP-Config.php

    When you delete something in WordPress, such as a comment, post, image, or link; it is not permanently deleted. Instead, it is sent to the trash folder. This fail safe system is used to allow you to retrieve items that were deleted in error. The downside to this is that deleted items will remain in your database until trash is emptied.

    Items that are sent to the trash folder are automatically deleted after 30 days. You can reduce the number of days before trash items are deleted by adding the following code to wp-config.php.

    define( 'EMPTY_TRASH_DAYS', 10 ); // 10 days
    The trash system can be completely disabled if you wish. You can do this by using this code.

    define( 'EMPTY_TRASH_DAYS', 0 ); // Zero days
    Be careful of disabling the trash system completely as it means that there is no way of recovering an item once you have deleted it. At the very least, I recommend setting trash to be emptied after one day. This will let you recover any items you deleted by accident.

    parent nodes:

    Image manipulation











    [ScratchPad]

    Scratch Pad











    [WikiSettings]

    parent nodes:

    Wiki Settings

    These are your default global settings.

    [global.importance.low.color: grey]
    [global.importance.high.bold: true]
    [global.contact.icon: contact]
    [global.wrap: 70]

    [icon: cog]
